instructions: Season the beef fillet and sear in a very hot pan with olive oil until browned all over; brush with English mustard and chill.
Finely chop mushrooms, shallots, garlic, and thyme; fry until all moisture has evaporated to make a dry duxelles.
Lay cling film on a surface, overlap Parma ham slices, spread duxelles evenly, place beef at one end, and roll tightly into a log; chill for 30 minutes.
Roll out puff pastry, remove cling film from the beef log, and wrap the pastry around it, sealing the edges with egg wash.
Score the pastry lightly with a knife in a decorative pattern and brush all over with beaten egg yolk.
Bake at 220C for 25-30 minutes until the pastry is deep golden and the internal temperature reaches 52C for medium-rare.
Rest for 10 minutes before slicing into thick portions and serving.

recipes.name: Sunday Roast Dinner
recipes.description: The cornerstone of British cuisine: roast beef with Yorkshire puddings, roast potatoes, seasonal vegetables, and rich gravy.
instructions: Remove beef from the fridge 1 hour before cooking. Rub with oil, salt, and pepper, then roast at 220C for 20 minutes.
Reduce oven to 170C and roast for 15 minutes per 500g for medium-rare; rest the beef for at least 30 minutes.
Par-boil potatoes for 8 minutes, drain and shake to roughen edges, then roast in goose fat at 200C for 45 minutes until crispy.
Toss carrots and parsnips in oil and roast alongside the potatoes for the last 35 minutes.
Whisk eggs, milk, flour, and a pinch of salt for Yorkshire pudding batter; pour into a hot, oiled muffin tin and bake at 220C for 20 minutes.
Deglaze the beef roasting tin with red wine, add stock, and simmer until reduced to a rich gravy; strain.
Carve the rested beef and serve with roast potatoes, vegetables, Yorkshire puddings, gravy, and horseradish sauce.

recipes.name: Yorkshire Pudding
recipes.description: Light, crisp, and airy batter puddings that puff up dramatically in the oven, an essential accompaniment to roast beef.
instructions: Sift flour and salt into a large bowl, make a well in the centre.
Beat eggs and milk together, then pour into the well and whisk until a smooth batter forms with no lumps.
Rest the batter in the fridge for at least 30 minutes, or up to overnight for best results.
Preheat oven to 230C. Add a teaspoon of oil to each cup of a 12-hole muffin tin and heat in the oven until smoking hot.
Quickly pour batter into each cup, filling to about one-third, and immediately return to the oven.
Bake for 20-25 minutes without opening the oven door, until puffed up, golden, and crisp.

recipes.name: Toad in the Hole
recipes.description: Pork sausages baked in a risen Yorkshire pudding batter, served with onion gravy for a hearty British supper.
instructions: Whisk together flour, eggs, milk, and salt to make a smooth batter; rest in the fridge for 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 220C. Pour oil into a large roasting tin and brown the sausages in the oven for 10 minutes.
Remove the tin, quickly pour the batter around the sausages, and return immediately to the oven.
Bake for 25-30 minutes until the batter is puffed, golden, and crisp; do not open the oven door during baking.
Meanwhile, caramelise sliced onions in butter, stir in a tablespoon of flour, then add stock and thyme for a gravy.
Simmer the gravy until thickened, season, and serve alongside generous portions of toad in the hole.

recipes.name: Cornish Pasty
recipes.description: A traditional hand-crimped shortcrust pastry parcel filled with beef skirt, potato, swede, and onion from Cornwall.
instructions: Rub lard into flour and salt until it resembles breadcrumbs, add cold water, and bring together into a firm pastry dough; chill for 30 minutes.
Cut beef skirt into small cubes, dice potato and swede into similar-sized pieces, and finely chop the onion.
Combine beef, potato, swede, and onion in a bowl; season generously with salt and pepper.
Divide pastry into 4 pieces, roll each into a circle about 25cm across.
Place filling on one half of each circle, brush edges with egg wash, fold pastry over, and crimp the edges tightly.
Brush the pasties with beaten egg, cut a small steam hole in each, and bake at 190C for 50 minutes until golden.

recipes.name: Ploughman's Lunch
recipes.description: A classic British cold lunch plate of mature Cheddar, crusty bread, Branston pickle, ham, and salad.
instructions: Slice the mature Cheddar into thick wedges and arrange on a large plate or board.
Halve the crusty bread rolls and spread with butter.
Fold the ham slices and place alongside the cheese.
Add a generous spoonful of Branston pickle, pickled onions, halved cherry tomatoes, and celery sticks.
Slice the apple into wedges and add to the plate with a handful of salad leaves.
Serve immediately as a complete cold lunch.

recipes.name: Steak and Kidney Pie
recipes.description: A rich and deeply flavoured pie filled with braised beef and lamb kidneys in ale gravy beneath a flaky suet pastry crust.
instructions: Cut beef into chunks, core and dice kidneys, then toss both in seasoned flour.
Brown the meat in batches in butter in a heavy casserole dish; remove and set aside.
Fry diced onion until softened, return the meat, add ale, stock, Worcestershire sauce, and bay leaves.
Cover and simmer gently for 1.5 hours until the beef is very tender and the gravy is thick.
Allow the filling to cool, then transfer to a pie dish.
Roll out puff pastry, lay over the top of the dish, trim and crimp edges, and brush with beaten egg.
Bake at 200C for 30-35 minutes until the pastry is risen, golden, and crisp.

recipes.name: Lancashire Hotpot
recipes.description: A slow-cooked casserole of lamb chops and onions topped with sliced potatoes that crisp beautifully on top.
instructions: Season lamb chops with salt and pepper, then brown in a hot pan; transfer to a deep casserole dish.
Layer sliced onion and carrot over the lamb, add thyme, bay leaves, and Worcestershire sauce.
Pour over the lamb stock until the meat is just covered.
Arrange thinly sliced potatoes in overlapping layers on top, brush with melted butter.
Cover with a lid and bake at 160C for 2 hours.
Remove the lid for the last 30 minutes and increase heat to 200C to crisp and brown the potato topping.

recipes.name: Bubble and Squeak
recipes.description: A thrifty British classic of leftover mashed potato and cabbage fried together into a crispy golden cake.
instructions: Finely chop the onion and fry in butter until softened and lightly golden.
Chop the cooked cabbage and mix thoroughly with the mashed potato; season well.
Heat oil in a large non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat.
Press the potato mixture into the pan to form a thick cake.
Fry for 5-6 minutes until the bottom is deeply golden and crispy, then flip and cook the other side.
Serve hot, cut into wedges, alongside eggs or cold meats.

recipes.name: Kedgeree
recipes.description: A mildly spiced Anglo-Indian breakfast dish of smoked haddock, rice, boiled eggs, and fresh parsley.
instructions: Poach smoked haddock in milk with a bay leaf for 8 minutes until it flakes easily; reserve the poaching liquid.
Cook basmati rice according to packet instructions; drain well.
Boil eggs for 7 minutes for a slightly soft yolk, then peel and quarter.
Fry finely diced onion in butter until soft, stir in curry powder, and cook for 1 minute.
Add cooked rice and flaked haddock to the pan with a splash of poaching liquid; toss gently.
Fold in chopped parsley and lemon juice, top with quartered eggs, and serve warm.

recipes.name: Welsh Rarebit
recipes.description: A savoury cheese sauce spiked with mustard, Worcestershire sauce, and ale, grilled until bubbling on thick toast.
instructions: Toast the bread slices on one side under a hot grill.
Melt butter in a saucepan, stir in flour, and cook for 1 minute to make a roux.
Gradually add ale, stirring constantly until smooth and thick.
Remove from heat and stir in grated Cheddar, mustard, Worcestershire sauce, egg yolk, and pepper until smooth.
Spread the cheese mixture thickly on the untoasted side of the bread.
Grill for 3-4 minutes until puffed up, golden, and bubbling; serve immediately.

recipes.name: Coronation Chicken
recipes.description: A creamy curried chicken salad created for Queen Elizabeth II's coronation in 1953, served cold with rice or in sandwiches.
instructions: Poach chicken breasts in simmering salted water for 20 minutes until cooked through; allow to cool, then shred or dice.
Gently fry finely diced onion with curry powder for 2 minutes until fragrant; allow to cool completely.
Mix mayonnaise, Greek yoghurt, mango chutney, apricot jam, and lemon juice in a bowl.
Stir in the cooled curry-onion mixture and sultanas.
Fold in the chicken pieces until evenly coated; season with salt.
Chill for at least 30 minutes, then serve garnished with fresh coriander.

recipes.name: Scotch Eggs
recipes.description: Soft-boiled eggs encased in seasoned pork sausage meat, coated in breadcrumbs, and deep-fried until golden.
instructions: Boil 4 eggs for exactly 6 minutes for a runny yolk, then plunge into ice water and peel carefully.
Mix sausage meat with chopped sage, mustard, nutmeg, salt, and pepper.
Divide sausage meat into 4 portions, flatten each, and wrap evenly around a peeled egg.
Beat the remaining 2 eggs. Roll each Scotch egg in flour, then beaten egg, then breadcrumbs.
Heat oil to 170C and deep-fry for 7-8 minutes until the coating is deep golden and the sausage is cooked through.
Drain on kitchen paper and serve warm or cold, halved to reveal the runny yolk.

recipes.name: Full English Breakfast
recipes.description: The ultimate cooked breakfast with bacon, eggs, sausages, beans, toast, tomatoes, mushrooms, and black pudding.
instructions: Preheat oven to 180C. Place sausages on a baking tray and cook for 20 minutes, turning halfway.
Fry bacon in a large pan until crispy to your liking; keep warm.
Halve the tomatoes, season, and grill cut-side up for 5 minutes; fry mushrooms in butter.
Fry black pudding slices for 2 minutes each side until crispy.
Heat baked beans gently in a small saucepan.
Fry eggs in a little oil to your preference, basting with hot fat for crispy edges.
Toast bread and butter generously. Arrange everything on warm plates and serve with HP sauce.

recipes.name: Scones with Clotted Cream
recipes.description: Light, fluffy buttermilk scones served warm with clotted cream and strawberry jam for a classic cream tea.
instructions: Sift flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt into a bowl; rub in cold diced butter until it resembles fine crumbs.
Make a well and pour in buttermilk; mix quickly with a knife until just combined, being careful not to overwork.
Turn onto a floured surface, pat to 3cm thick, and stamp out rounds with a 6cm cutter without twisting.
Place on a baking tray, brush tops with beaten egg, and bake at 220C for 12 minutes until risen and golden.
Cool slightly on a wire rack, then split in half.
Serve warm with generous dollops of clotted cream and strawberry jam.

recipes.name: Sticky Toffee Pudding
recipes.description: A moist sponge studded with dates and drenched in warm toffee sauce, often served with vanilla custard or ice cream.
instructions: Chop dates and soak in boiling water with bicarbonate of soda for 10 minutes; mash lightly with a fork.
Cream 50g butter with 75g sugar until light and fluffy, then beat in eggs and vanilla.
Fold in flour, then stir in the date mixture; pour into a greased baking dish.
Bake at 180C for 30-35 minutes until a skewer comes out clean.
For the sauce, heat 80g butter, 125g muscovado sugar, cream, and treacle, stirring until smooth and bubbling.
Poke holes in the warm sponge, pour over half the toffee sauce, and serve the rest alongside.

recipes.name: Eton Mess
recipes.description: A delightful tumble of crushed meringue, whipped cream, and fresh strawberries, originating from Eton College.
instructions: Hull and halve the strawberries; crush one-third lightly with a fork and mix with the sugar to create a coulis.
Whip double cream with vanilla extract until it holds soft peaks.
Roughly crush the meringue nests into chunky pieces.
Gently fold the crushed meringue, remaining strawberry halves, and strawberry coulis into the cream, leaving it streaky.
Spoon into glasses or bowls and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Treacle Tart
recipes.description: A golden syrup-filled tart with breadcrumb topping and a hint of lemon, a traditional British dessert beloved for its sweet simplicity.
instructions: Roll out pastry and line a 23cm tart tin; prick the base with a fork and chill for 20 minutes.
Blind bake the pastry shell at 190C for 15 minutes with baking beans, then remove beans and bake for 5 more minutes.
Warm the golden syrup gently, then stir in breadcrumbs, lemon zest, lemon juice, ground ginger, and cream.
Beat the egg and stir into the syrup mixture.
Pour the filling into the pastry case and bake at 180C for 25-30 minutes until set and golden.
Serve warm with custard or clotted cream.

recipes.name: Victoria Sponge
recipes.description: The quintessential British cake: two light sponge layers sandwiched with raspberry jam and whipped cream, dusted with icing sugar.
instructions: Preheat oven to 180C and grease and line two 20cm round sandwich tins.
Cream butter and caster sugar together until pale and fluffy.
Beat in eggs one at a time, adding a tablespoon of flour with each to prevent curdling; stir in vanilla.
Fold in the remaining flour gently until just combined; divide evenly between the tins.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden and springy to the touch; cool on wire racks.
Whip cream until it holds soft peaks, spread jam on one sponge, top with cream, and sandwich together.
Dust the top with icing sugar and serve.

recipes.name: Bread and Butter Pudding
recipes.description: Layers of buttered bread baked in a rich vanilla custard with sultanas, a warming and economical British dessert.
instructions: Butter the bread slices generously, cut each diagonally, and arrange overlapping in a buttered baking dish.
Scatter sultanas between the bread layers.
Whisk eggs, caster sugar, vanilla, milk, and cream together to make a custard.
Pour the custard evenly over the bread and let it soak for 20 minutes.
Sprinkle with demerara sugar and grated nutmeg.
Bake at 180C for 35-40 minutes until the custard is set and the top is golden and crispy.

recipes.name: Spotted Dick
recipes.description: A traditional steamed suet pudding studded with currants and served with lashings of hot custard.
instructions: Mix flour, suet, sugar, salt, currants, and lemon zest together in a large bowl.
Add milk gradually, mixing until you have a soft but not sticky dough.
Shape the dough into a log and wrap loosely in greased baking parchment, then in foil, leaving room to expand.
Steam over simmering water for 1.5 hours, topping up the water as needed.
Unwrap carefully, slice into thick rounds.
Serve hot with generous amounts of warm custard.

recipes.name: Schnitzel (Wiener and Jäger)
recipes.description: A pounded veal or pork cutlet coated in seasoned flour, egg, and breadcrumbs, fried to golden perfection. Serve plain with lemon as Wiener Schnitzel or topped with mushroom cream sauce as Jägerschnitzel.
instructions: Place veal escalopes between cling film and pound with a meat mallet until very thin, about 5mm thick.
Season flour with salt and pepper. Set up three shallow dishes: flour, beaten eggs, and breadcrumbs.
Coat each escalope in flour, shake off excess, dip in egg, and press into breadcrumbs on both sides.
Heat clarified butter in a large pan over medium-high heat until shimmering.
Fry each schnitzel for 2-3 minutes per side, gently swirling the pan so the coating puffs up and turns golden.
Drain on kitchen paper and serve immediately with lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Sauerbraten
recipes.description: A traditional German pot roast marinated in a tangy vinegar and spice mixture for days, then braised until meltingly tender.
instructions: Combine vinegar, wine, sliced onion, carrot, celery, juniper, cloves, bay leaves, peppercorns, sugar, and salt to make the marinade.
Place beef in a non-reactive dish, pour over the marinade, cover, and refrigerate for 3-5 days, turning daily.
Remove the beef, pat dry, and sear in hot oil on all sides until deeply browned.
Strain the marinade, reserving both the liquid and the vegetables. Add vegetables to the pot and fry briefly.
Pour in the reserved marinade liquid, bring to a simmer, cover, and braise at 160C for 2.5-3 hours until fork-tender.
Remove the beef. Crush gingersnap biscuits and stir into the sauce to thicken; simmer for 10 minutes.
Slice the beef and serve with the tangy gravy alongside potato dumplings or red cabbage.

recipes.name: Bratwurst
recipes.description: Juicy grilled German pork sausages seasoned with marjoram and caraway, served in a crusty roll with senf mustard.
instructions: Bring a pot of water to a gentle simmer and poach the bratwurst for 5 minutes to cook them through.
Heat a grill pan or barbecue to high heat and brush sausages with a little oil.
Grill the bratwurst for 3-4 minutes per side until nicely charred and the skin is crisp.
Slice onion into rings and quickly grill alongside the sausages.
Warm the sauerkraut gently in a small pan.
Serve two bratwurst per roll with a generous smear of German mustard, grilled onions, and sauerkraut.

recipes.name: Currywurst
recipes.description: Berlin's iconic street food: sliced grilled bratwurst doused in a tangy curry ketchup sauce, dusted with curry powder.
instructions: Fry or grill bratwurst until cooked through and the skin is nicely browned.
For the sauce, fry finely diced onion in oil until softened, add ketchup, passata, Worcestershire sauce, and sugar.
Stir in half the curry powder, paprika, and cayenne; simmer for 10 minutes until thickened.
Slice the bratwurst into bite-sized pieces.
Pour the warm curry sauce generously over the sliced sausage.
Dust with the remaining curry powder and serve with a crusty roll or chips.

recipes.name: Rouladen
recipes.description: Thin slices of beef rolled around mustard, bacon, onion, and pickles, then braised slowly in a rich brown gravy.
instructions: Lay beef slices flat, season with salt and pepper, and spread each with a thin layer of mustard.
Top each slice with bacon, sliced onion, and a quartered dill pickle, then roll up tightly and secure with toothpicks or kitchen string.
Brown the rouladen in hot oil on all sides in a heavy casserole; remove and set aside.
Fry diced carrot and remaining onion in the same pot, add tomato puree, and cook for 2 minutes.
Deglaze with red wine, add stock, and return the rouladen to the pot; bring to a simmer.
Cover and braise at 160C for 1.5-2 hours until the beef is very tender.
Remove rouladen, whisk flour into the sauce to thicken, and serve with potato dumplings or red cabbage.

recipes.name: Schweinshaxe
recipes.description: A whole roasted pork knuckle with impossibly crispy crackling skin and tender, juicy meat, a Bavarian beer hall favourite.
instructions: Score the skin of the pork knuckles in a diamond pattern and rub generously with salt and caraway seeds.
Place halved onions, carrots, celery, and garlic in a roasting tin and sit the knuckles on top.
Pour in the dark beer and add enough water to come halfway up the knuckles.
Roast at 160C for 2.5 hours, basting regularly with the pan juices.
Increase the oven temperature to 220C for the final 30 minutes to achieve a glass-like, crispy crackling.
Rest for 10 minutes, then serve with the pan juices, sauerkraut, and a pretzel.

recipes.name: Königsberger Klopse
recipes.description: Delicate veal meatballs poached in a creamy white caper sauce, a refined East Prussian classic.
instructions: Soak the bread roll in water, squeeze dry, and combine with minced veal, finely diced onion, 1 egg, chopped anchovies, salt, and pepper.
Shape the mixture into golf ball-sized meatballs with wet hands.
Bring beef stock to a gentle simmer and carefully poach the meatballs for 15 minutes.
Remove meatballs and reserve the stock. Melt butter, stir in flour, and cook for 2 minutes to make a roux.
Gradually whisk in the reserved stock, then add cream, capers, and lemon juice; simmer until smooth and creamy.
Beat the remaining egg yolk and temper with a little sauce before stirring back in. Return meatballs to the sauce.
Serve with boiled potatoes and rice.

recipes.name: Kartoffelpuffer
recipes.description: Crispy German potato pancakes made from grated raw potato and onion, fried golden and served with apple sauce.
instructions: Peel and coarsely grate the potatoes and onion; squeeze out as much liquid as possible using a clean tea towel.
Allow the potato starch in the squeezed liquid to settle, pour off the water, and add the starch back to the potato mixture.
Mix in the egg, flour, salt, pepper, and nutmeg until combined.
Heat a generous layer of oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat.
Drop spoonfuls of the mixture into the pan, flatten slightly, and fry for 3-4 minutes per side until crispy and golden.
Drain on kitchen paper and serve hot with apple sauce on the side.

recipes.name: Spätzle
recipes.description: Soft, irregular German egg noodles scraped directly into boiling water, tossed in butter as a comforting side dish.
instructions: Combine flour, eggs, milk, salt, and nutmeg; beat vigorously until the batter is smooth, elastic, and pulls away from the spoon.
Rest the batter for 10 minutes.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a rolling boil.
Using a Spätzle press, colander, or cutting board, push or scrape small portions of batter into the boiling water.
Cook until the Spätzle float to the surface, about 2-3 minutes, then scoop out with a slotted spoon.
Toss with melted butter and chopped chives; serve immediately.

recipes.name: Maultaschen
recipes.description: Large Swabian filled pasta parcels stuffed with a savoury mix of pork, spinach, and bread, served in broth or pan-fried.
instructions: Make dough from flour, 2 eggs, a pinch of salt, and a splash of water; knead until smooth, wrap, and rest for 30 minutes.
Defrost and squeeze dry the spinach. Soak the bread roll in water and squeeze out.
Mix minced pork, spinach, bread, fried diced onion, parsley, 1 egg, nutmeg, salt, and pepper to make the filling.
Roll dough very thinly, cut into large squares (about 10cm), place a spoonful of filling on each, fold, and press edges to seal.
Simmer the Maultaschen in beef stock for 10-12 minutes until the pasta is cooked through.
Serve in the broth with fresh chives, or pan-fry in butter until golden for a crispy alternative.

recipes.name: Leberkäse
recipes.description: A Bavarian baked meat loaf made from finely ground beef, pork, and bacon, sliced thick and served in a bread roll.
instructions: Blend pork, beef, back fat, diced onion, and garlic in a food processor until very fine and paste-like.
Add ice water, marjoram, salt, and white pepper; process until smooth and emulsified.
Pack the mixture firmly into a greased loaf tin, smoothing the top.
Bake at 180C for 1 hour 15 minutes until the top forms a golden-brown crust.
Allow to rest for 10 minutes, then slice into thick slabs.
Serve each slice in a crusty bread roll with a generous smear of German mustard.

recipes.name: Flammkuchen
recipes.description: Alsatian-style thin flatbread topped with creme fraiche, thinly sliced onions, and lardons, baked until crispy.
instructions: Mix flour, oil, warm water, and salt to form a smooth dough; knead briefly and rest for 15 minutes.
Preheat oven to its highest setting, ideally 250C, with a baking sheet inside.
Roll the dough out on a floured surface as thinly as possible into a large rectangle or oval.
Spread creme fraiche evenly over the surface, leaving a small border; season with nutmeg and pepper.
Scatter thinly sliced onion rings and lardons over the top.
Slide onto the hot baking sheet and bake for 10-12 minutes until the edges are charred and crispy.

recipes.name: Labskaus
recipes.description: A hearty Northern German hash of corned beef, beetroot, potatoes, and pickled herring, topped with a fried egg.
instructions: Boil potatoes until tender, drain, and mash roughly.
Fry diced onion in butter until soft, then add crumbled corned beef and cook for 5 minutes.
Dice the beetroot and stir into the corned beef mixture along with the mashed potato.
Mix everything together until well combined but still slightly chunky; season with salt and pepper.
Fry eggs sunny-side up in a separate pan.
Serve the hash on plates, top each portion with a fried egg, and garnish with pickled herring slices and dill pickle.

recipes.name: Eintopf
recipes.description: A thick, warming one-pot German stew of vegetables, potatoes, and smoked sausage, perfect for cold winter days.
instructions: Dice potatoes, slice carrots, chop leek, trim green beans, and finely dice the onion and garlic.
Fry onion and garlic in a large pot until softened.
Add potatoes, carrots, and bay leaves, pour in beef stock, and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes, then add green beans and sliced leek.
Slice the smoked sausage and add to the pot; simmer for another 15 minutes until all vegetables are tender.
Season with salt and pepper, ladle into deep bowls, and garnish with chopped parsley.

recipes.name: Gulasch
recipes.description: German-style beef goulash with paprika, onions, and peppers, slowly simmered into a thick, deeply flavoured stew.
instructions: Cut beef into large chunks, pat dry, and brown in batches in hot oil in a heavy casserole; set aside.
Fry sliced onions in the same pot for 10 minutes until deeply caramelised.
Stir in paprika, caraway seeds, and garlic; cook for 1 minute, being careful not to burn the paprika.
Add tomato puree, red wine, and diced bell peppers; cook for 2 minutes.
Return beef to the pot, pour in stock, bring to a simmer, cover, and cook at 160C for 2 hours until very tender.
Adjust seasoning and serve with bread dumplings, Spätzle, or boiled potatoes.

recipes.name: Käsespätzle
recipes.description: The German answer to mac and cheese: layers of fresh Spätzle baked with melted Emmentaler and crispy fried onions.
instructions: Make Spätzle batter from flour, eggs, milk, salt, and nutmeg; beat until smooth and elastic.
Press or scrape batter into boiling salted water, cook until they float, and drain.
Slice onions into thin rings and fry in butter over medium heat until deeply golden and crispy; set aside.
Layer warm Spätzle and grated Emmentaler in a baking dish, finishing with cheese on top.
Bake at 200C for 15 minutes until the cheese is melted and bubbling.
Top with the crispy fried onions and chopped chives; serve immediately.

recipes.name: Himmel und Erde
recipes.description: A Rhineland classic meaning 'Heaven and Earth': a comforting mix of mashed potato, apple sauce, and fried blood sausage.
instructions: Peel and boil potatoes until tender; mash with half the butter, salt, pepper, and nutmeg.
Peel, core, and slice apples; cook gently with sugar and a splash of vinegar until soft but not mushy.
Slice onions into rings and fry in remaining butter until deeply golden and caramelised.
Slice the blood sausage into thick rounds and pan-fry until crispy on both sides.
Combine the mashed potato and apple sauce gently, keeping some texture.
Serve the Himmel und Erde topped with fried blood sausage and caramelised onion rings.

recipes.name: Zwiebelkuchen
recipes.description: A savoury German onion tart with a yeasted dough base, topped with caramelised onions, sour cream, bacon, and caraway.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm milk, add to flour with melted butter and salt; knead into a smooth dough and prove for 45 minutes.
Slice onions thinly and sweat in butter over low heat for 20 minutes until very soft but not browned.
Fry bacon lardons until crispy; add to the onions.
Mix sour cream, eggs, caraway seeds, salt, and pepper; stir into the cooled onion-bacon mixture.
Roll out the proved dough and press into a greased 30cm tart tin or baking tray.
Spread the onion filling evenly over the dough and bake at 200C for 30-35 minutes until golden and set.

recipes.name: Brezel (Pretzel)
recipes.description: Traditional Bavarian lye pretzels with a chewy, dark brown crust, soft interior, and a generous sprinkle of coarse salt.
instructions: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water, then combine with flour, salt, and oil; knead for 8 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Cover and prove for 1 hour until doubled in size.
Divide dough into 8 pieces, roll each into a 60cm rope, and twist into the classic pretzel shape.
Dissolve baking soda in 1 litre of boiling water. Dip each pretzel in the solution for 30 seconds.
Place on a lined baking tray, slash the thick base, and sprinkle generously with coarse salt.
Bake at 220C for 12-15 minutes until deeply browned and glossy.

recipes.name: Stollen
recipes.description: A rich, fruit-laden German Christmas bread with marzipan centre, dusted thickly with icing sugar to resemble snow.
instructions: Soak raisins and candied peel in rum overnight. Warm milk, dissolve yeast, and mix with flour, sugar, softened butter, cardamom, and lemon zest.
Knead the dough for 10 minutes, then fold in the soaked fruit and chopped almonds.
Prove for 1.5 hours until doubled in size.
Roll out into an oval, shape marzipan into a log, place off-centre, and fold the dough over to create the classic Stollen shape.
Prove for another 30 minutes, then bake at 180C for 45-50 minutes until golden and a skewer comes out clean.
Brush the hot Stollen liberally with melted butter, then dust thickly with icing sugar.
Wrap in foil and let mature for at least 3 days before slicing.

recipes.name: Schwarzwälder Kirschtorte
recipes.description: The iconic Black Forest gateau: layers of chocolate sponge soaked in Kirsch, filled with cherries and whipped cream.
instructions: Whisk eggs and sugar over a bain-marie until thick, pale, and tripled in volume; fold in sifted flour, cocoa, and melted butter.
Divide between 3 greased and lined 23cm cake tins and bake at 180C for 12-15 minutes; cool completely.
Drain cherries, reserving juice. Thicken juice with cornflour over heat; fold in cherries and set aside.
Whip cream with vanilla until it holds firm peaks.
Brush each sponge layer with Kirsch. Place one layer on a plate, spread with cream and cherry filling; repeat.
Cover the entire cake with whipped cream, decorate with chocolate shavings and whole cherries.
Chill for at least 2 hours before serving.

recipes.name: Apfelstrudel
recipes.description: Paper-thin stretched pastry rolled around a spiced apple, raisin, and breadcrumb filling, baked until flaky and golden.
instructions: Make dough from flour, 1 egg, oil, a pinch of salt, and warm water; knead for 10 minutes until very elastic, then rest for 30 minutes.
Peel, core, and thinly slice the apples; toss with sugar, raisins, cinnamon, and lemon juice.
Toast breadcrumbs in half the butter until golden.
On a floured cloth, stretch the dough gently with your hands until paper-thin and translucent.
Brush with melted butter, sprinkle with toasted breadcrumbs, and spread the apple filling along one edge.
Using the cloth, roll the strudel up tightly, transfer to a baking tray, brush with remaining butter.
Bake at 190C for 30-35 minutes until golden and crispy; dust with icing sugar and serve warm with custard.

recipes.name: Bienenstich
recipes.description: Bee Sting Cake: a yeasted cake with a crunchy caramelised almond topping, split and filled with vanilla custard cream.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm milk with a pinch of sugar. Mix with flour, 30g sugar, 50g softened butter, 1 egg, and salt; knead into a soft dough and prove for 1 hour.
Press the proved dough into a greased 25cm springform tin.
Melt 80g butter with honey and sugar in a pan, stir in flaked almonds, and spread evenly over the dough.
Bake at 180C for 22-25 minutes until the almond topping is golden and caramelised.
Make custard from custard powder, milk, and remaining sugar; cool, then fold in whipped cream.
Once the cake is cooled, slice horizontally, fill generously with the custard cream, and replace the almond-topped half.

recipes.name: Kaiserschmarrn
recipes.description: A fluffy shredded Austrian-German pancake caramelised with sugar and served with plum compote, a favourite imperial dessert.
instructions: Separate eggs. Whisk yolks with milk, vanilla, flour, and salt until smooth.
Whisk egg whites with half the sugar until stiff peaks form, then gently fold into the batter.
Melt butter in a large ovenproof pan and pour in the batter; scatter raisins on top.
Cook over medium heat for 2 minutes, then transfer to the oven at 200C for 5 minutes until puffed and set.
Tear the pancake into rough pieces with two forks, sprinkle with remaining sugar, and caramelise briefly in the pan.
Dust with icing sugar and serve immediately with plum jam or compote.

recipes.name: Dampfnudeln
recipes.description: Steamed yeast dumplings with a golden, caramelised bottom, served with vanilla sauce or stewed fruit.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm milk with a pinch of sugar. Mix with flour, sugar, 30g melted butter, egg, and salt; knead until smooth.
Prove for 1 hour until doubled, then divide into 8 equal balls.
Prove the balls on a floured tray for 20 minutes until puffy.
Melt remaining butter with sugar and milk in a wide pan with a tight-fitting lid.
Place the dumplings in the pan, cover tightly, and cook over low heat for 20-25 minutes without lifting the lid.
The bottoms should be golden and caramelised, the tops fluffy and steamed. Serve with warm vanilla custard.

recipes.name: Jerk Chicken
recipes.description: Fiery, aromatic grilled chicken marinated in a blend of scotch bonnet peppers, allspice, and thyme. A cornerstone of Jamaican street food and backyard cookouts.
instructions: Blend scotch bonnet peppers, green onions, garlic, ginger, thyme leaves, allspice, cinnamon, black pepper, soy sauce, lime juice, brown sugar, and oil into a smooth jerk marinade.
Score the chicken pieces deeply with a knife and rub the marinade thoroughly into every cut and crevice.
Marinate the chicken in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight, in a sealed container.
Preheat a charcoal grill or oven to 190C (375F). If grilling, set up for indirect heat.
Grill the chicken over indirect heat for 35-45 minutes, turning occasionally, until the internal temperature reaches 75C (165F).
Move the chicken to direct heat for the last 5 minutes to char the skin lightly.
Rest the chicken for 5 minutes before serving with rice and peas or festival.

recipes.name: Jerk Pork
recipes.description: Succulent pork shoulder slow-roasted with an intense jerk spice paste, delivering a smoky heat balanced by warm island spices. Traditionally cooked over pimento wood.
instructions: Blend scotch bonnets, green onions, garlic, ginger, thyme leaves, allspice, nutmeg, soy sauce, vinegar, brown sugar, and oil into a thick jerk paste.
Score the pork shoulder deeply in a crosshatch pattern and massage the paste into every incision.
Wrap tightly in plastic wrap and marinate in the refrigerator for 12-24 hours.
Preheat the oven to 150C (300F). Place the pork on a rack in a roasting pan and cover with foil.
Slow-roast for 2.5-3 hours, basting every 45 minutes with the accumulated pan juices.
Remove the foil for the last 30 minutes and increase the temperature to 200C (400F) to crisp the exterior.
Rest for 15 minutes, then pull or slice the pork and serve with hard dough bread and pickled vegetables.

recipes.name: Ackee and Saltfish
recipes.description: Jamaica's national dish featuring buttery ackee fruit sauteed with flaked salt cod, tomatoes, scotch bonnet, and fresh thyme. A beloved breakfast staple across the island.
instructions: Soak the salt cod in cold water overnight, changing the water at least twice to remove excess salt.
Boil the salt cod for 15 minutes until tender, then drain, flake into pieces, and remove any bones.
Heat coconut oil in a large skillet over medium heat and saute the diced onion, garlic, and bell pepper until softened.
Add the diced tomatoes, sliced green onions, whole scotch bonnet pepper, and thyme sprigs. Cook for 3 minutes.
Add the flaked saltfish and stir gently to combine with the vegetables.
Carefully fold in the drained ackee, being gentle to keep the pieces intact, and cook for 3-4 minutes.
Remove the scotch bonnet and thyme sprigs. Season with black pepper and serve with fried dumplings, boiled green bananas, or bammy.

recipes.name: Curry Goat
recipes.description: Tender goat meat slow-braised in a rich Jamaican curry sauce with potatoes, allspice, and scotch bonnet. A celebratory dish served at parties and family gatherings.
instructions: Season the goat meat with curry powder, allspice, minced garlic, grated ginger, chopped onion, green onion, thyme, and salt. Marinate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Heat vegetable oil in a heavy-bottomed Dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering.
Sear the marinated goat pieces in batches until browned on all sides, about 4 minutes per batch.
Return all the meat to the pot, add the water and whole scotch bonnet pepper, and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 1.5 hours, stirring occasionally.
Add the peeled and cubed potatoes and continue cooking for another 30 minutes until the goat is fall-off-the-bone tender and the potatoes are soft.
Adjust the seasoning and serve over white rice or with roti.

recipes.name: Oxtail Stew
recipes.description: Rich, gelatinous oxtail pieces braised low and slow with butter beans, carrots, and a deeply savory gravy. One of Jamaica's most beloved comfort dishes.
instructions: Season the oxtail with allspice, soy sauce, minced garlic, chopped green onions, thyme, and black pepper. Marinate for at least 2 hours.
Soak the butter beans in water for 8 hours or overnight, then drain.
Heat oil in a large Dutch oven and brown the oxtail pieces on all sides in batches.
Return all oxtail to the pot, add beef broth, browning sauce, ketchup, whole scotch bonnet, and diced onion. Bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat, cover tightly, and simmer on low for 2 hours, checking occasionally.
Add the soaked butter beans and sliced carrots. Continue simmering for 1 more hour until the meat is falling off the bone and the beans are tender.
Remove the scotch bonnet. Adjust seasoning and serve with white rice and steamed vegetables.

recipes.name: Rice and Peas
recipes.description: Fragrant coconut rice cooked with red kidney beans, allspice, thyme, and scotch bonnet. The essential side dish served at every Jamaican Sunday dinner.
instructions: Rinse the rice under cold water until the water runs clear, then drain.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, combine coconut milk, water, drained kidney beans, garlic, green onions, thyme sprigs, whole scotch bonnet pepper, allspice, and salt. Bring to a boil.
Add the rinsed rice and stir once. Return to a boil.
Reduce the heat to the lowest setting, cover with a tight-fitting lid, and cook for 20-25 minutes without lifting the lid.
Remove from heat and let the rice steam for 10 minutes with the lid on.
Remove the scotch bonnet, thyme sprigs, and green onion pieces. Fluff with a fork and serve.

recipes.name: Bammy
recipes.description: Traditional Jamaican flatbread made from grated cassava root, pressed and fried until golden. An indigenous Taino recipe that predates European colonization.
instructions: Peel the cassava, grate it finely, and squeeze out as much liquid as possible using a cheesecloth or clean kitchen towel.
Season the dried cassava meal with salt and mix thoroughly.
Pack the cassava tightly into round molds or form by hand into flat discs about 1 cm thick and 12 cm in diameter.
Cook the bammy on a dry griddle or skillet over medium heat for about 5 minutes on each side until set and lightly golden.
Soak the cooked bammy in coconut milk for 2-3 minutes on each side.
Fry the soaked bammy in coconut oil over medium heat until golden and crispy on both sides, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm alongside ackee and saltfish or escovitch fish.

recipes.name: Festival
recipes.description: Sweet, slightly dense fried dumplings made with cornmeal and flour. A beloved Jamaican street food typically paired with jerk chicken or fried fish.
instructions: Combine flour, cornmeal, sugar, baking powder, and salt in a large mixing bowl.
Add vanilla extract and gradually add water, mixing until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms.
Divide the dough into 8 equal portions and roll each into an elongated oval shape, about 10 cm long.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep pot or fryer to 170C (340F).
Fry the festivals in batches for 4-5 minutes, turning occasionally, until deep golden brown all over.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Serve warm alongside jerk meats or fish.

recipes.name: Callaloo
recipes.description: A hearty Jamaican leafy green stew made with callaloo leaves, okra, coconut milk, and scotch bonnet. A nourishing dish often served at breakfast alongside dumplings.
instructions: Wash and roughly chop the callaloo leaves. Trim and slice the okra into rounds.
Heat coconut oil in a large pot over medium heat. Saute the diced onion and minced garlic until fragrant.
Add the callaloo, okra, thyme, green onions, and whole scotch bonnet pepper.
Pour in the coconut milk, season with salt and black pepper, and stir to combine.
Cover and simmer on medium-low heat for 20-25 minutes until the greens are very tender.
Remove the scotch bonnet and thyme sprigs. Mash the callaloo lightly with a fork for a slightly chunky texture or leave as is.
Serve warm as a side dish with boiled dumplings, yam, or breadfruit.

recipes.name: Escovitch Fish
recipes.description: Crispy fried whole fish topped with a vibrant, tangy pickled vegetable medley of onions, carrots, and scotch bonnet in spiced vinegar. A Jamaican Good Friday tradition.
instructions: Clean and score the fish on both sides. Rub with lime juice, salt, black pepper, and allspice. Let sit for 15 minutes.
Julienne the onions, carrots, bell pepper, cho cho, and slice the scotch bonnet into rings.
Heat oil in a large skillet and fry the fish until golden and crispy on both sides, about 5-6 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels.
In a separate pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil and saute the sliced vegetables for 2-3 minutes until slightly softened but still crisp.
Add white vinegar and a pinch of salt to the vegetables, bring to a quick boil, then remove from heat.
Place the fried fish on a serving platter and spoon the hot escovitch pickle over the top.
Let the dish rest for at least 15 minutes to allow the flavors to meld before serving with bammy or hard dough bread.

recipes.name: Rum Punch
recipes.description: A tropical Jamaican cocktail blending dark rum with tropical fruit juices, grenadine, and a grating of nutmeg. Follows the classic Caribbean ratio: one of sour, two of sweet, three of strong, four of weak.
instructions: Combine the dark rum, pineapple juice, orange juice, and lime juice in a large pitcher.
Add the grenadine and simple syrup and stir well to combine.
Add the Angostura bitters and stir again.
Fill serving glasses with ice cubes and pour the punch over the ice.
Grate fresh nutmeg over each glass and garnish with a pineapple wedge and a cherry.
Stir gently before drinking. Serve immediately while cold.

recipes.name: Plantain Tarts
recipes.description: Flaky pastry turnovers filled with sweet ripe plantain spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla. A cherished Jamaican bakery treat enjoyed as a snack or dessert.
instructions: Make the pastry by cutting cold butter into flour and salt until crumbly, then add ice water gradually until the dough just comes together. Wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Peel and slice the ripe plantains. Simmer in a small amount of water with brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla for 15 minutes until very soft.
Mash the cooked plantain into a smooth filling and stir in a few drops of red food coloring for the traditional pink hue. Let cool.
Roll out the pastry dough and cut into 12 circles about 12 cm in diameter.
Place a spoonful of plantain filling on one half of each circle, fold over, and crimp the edges with a fork to seal.
Preheat the oven to 190C (375F). Place the tarts on a lined baking sheet and bake for 20-25 minutes until golden brown.
Cool on a wire rack for 5 minutes before serving. Best enjoyed warm.

recipes.name: Ropa Vieja
recipes.description: Cuba's national dish of slow-braised flank steak shredded into tender strands and simmered in a rich tomato sauce with bell peppers and olives. The name means 'old clothes' for its shredded appearance.
instructions: Place the flank steak in a large pot, cover with water, add bay leaves and half the onion. Bring to a boil, then simmer for 1.5-2 hours until very tender.
Remove the steak, let cool slightly, then shred the meat into thin strands with two forks. Reserve 1 cup of the braising liquid.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet. Saute the sliced onion, bell peppers, and minced garlic until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add cumin, oregano, crushed tomatoes, white wine, and the reserved braising liquid. Stir and bring to a simmer.
Add the shredded beef and olives to the sauce. Stir to combine.
Simmer uncovered for 20-25 minutes until the sauce thickens and the flavors meld.
Season with salt and serve over white rice with black beans and fried sweet plantains.

recipes.name: Cuban Sandwich
recipes.description: A pressed sandwich layered with roasted pork, ham, Swiss cheese, pickles, and yellow mustard on Cuban bread. Born in the Cuban immigrant communities of Tampa and Miami.
instructions: Slice the Cuban bread loaves in half lengthwise.
Spread yellow mustard generously on both cut sides of the bread.
Layer the roasted pork, ham, Swiss cheese, and dill pickle slices on the bottom half of each loaf.
Close the sandwiches with the top half of bread and press down lightly.
Butter the outside of the sandwiches on both top and bottom.
Heat a plancha, panini press, or heavy skillet over medium heat. Press and grill the sandwiches for 3-4 minutes per side until the bread is golden and crisp and the cheese is melted.
Slice each loaf diagonally into portions and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Arroz con Pollo
recipes.description: A vibrant Cuban one-pot rice dish with chicken, beer, saffron-tinted broth, and a sofrito base. The rice is cooked to absorb every bit of flavor from the seasoned chicken.
instructions: Season the chicken thighs with salt, cumin, and minced garlic. Let sit for 15 minutes.
Heat olive oil in a large caldero or Dutch oven. Brown the chicken on all sides, then remove and set aside.
In the same pot, saute the diced onion, bell pepper, and remaining garlic until soft to create the sofrito base.
Add tomato sauce, bijol or saffron, beer, chicken broth, and bay leaf. Bring to a boil.
Add the rice, stir once, and nestle the browned chicken pieces on top. Return to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover tightly, and cook for 25-30 minutes until the rice is tender and the liquid is absorbed.
Scatter the frozen peas and strips of roasted red pepper over the top. Cover for 5 more minutes to warm through, then serve.

recipes.name: Picadillo
recipes.description: A savory-sweet Cuban ground beef hash cooked with tomatoes, green olives, raisins, and capers in a fragrant sofrito. A weeknight staple throughout Cuban homes.
instructions: Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Saute the diced onion, bell pepper, and minced garlic until softened.
Add the ground beef, breaking it apart with a spoon, and cook until browned throughout.
Stir in the cumin, oregano, and salt.
Add the white wine and cook for 1 minute, scraping any browned bits from the bottom of the pan.
Pour in the tomato sauce and stir to combine. Add the olives, raisins, and capers.
Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer for 15-20 minutes until the sauce has thickened and the flavors have melded.
Serve over white rice with fried plantains and a side of black beans.

recipes.name: Lechon Asado
recipes.description: Cuban-style roast pork marinated in a tangy mojo criollo of sour orange, garlic, cumin, and oregano, then slow-roasted until the skin crackles and the meat is impossibly tender.
instructions: Blend the garlic, sour orange juice, cumin, oregano, olive oil, salt, pepper, and chopped onion into a smooth mojo criollo marinade.
Pierce the pork shoulder all over with a sharp knife and place in a large roasting pan. Pour the mojo over the pork, working it into every incision.
Tuck the bay leaves around the pork. Cover tightly and marinate in the refrigerator for at least 12 hours, preferably 24.
Preheat the oven to 165C (325F). Cover the roasting pan tightly with foil.
Roast for 3.5-4 hours, basting every hour with the pan juices, until the meat is fall-apart tender.
Remove the foil, increase the oven temperature to 220C (425F), and roast for an additional 20-30 minutes to crisp the skin.
Rest for 20 minutes before pulling or slicing. Serve with moros y cristianos, yuca con mojo, and tostones.

recipes.name: Black Beans and Rice (Moros y Cristianos)
recipes.description: A foundational Cuban dish of black beans slowly cooked with sofrito and spices, served together with fluffy white rice. The name references the historical Moors and Christians.
instructions: Soak the dried black beans overnight in plenty of water. Drain and rinse.
Place the beans in a pot with fresh water, bay leaf, and half the onion. Boil then simmer for 1 hour until tender. Drain, reserving the cooking liquid.
Heat olive oil in a pot and saute the diced remaining onion, bell pepper, and garlic until soft to make the sofrito.
Add cumin, oregano, and the cooked beans. Pour in enough reserved bean liquid to just cover. Stir in vinegar and sugar.
Simmer for 20 minutes until the sauce is thick and creamy. Season with salt.
Meanwhile, cook the white rice separately according to package directions.
Serve the black beans ladled over or alongside the white rice.

recipes.name: Yuca con Mojo
recipes.description: Boiled cassava root drenched in a punchy mojo sauce of olive oil, garlic, sour orange, and cumin. A simple yet essential Cuban side dish bursting with flavor.
instructions: Peel the yuca, cut into 8 cm chunks, and remove the tough fibrous core from each piece.
Boil the yuca in salted water for 25-30 minutes until fork-tender and slightly translucent.
While the yuca boils, prepare the mojo: heat olive oil in a small pan and saute the thinly sliced onion and minced garlic over medium heat until the garlic is golden, about 2 minutes.
Immediately add the sour orange juice and cumin to the garlic oil (it will sizzle). Season with salt.
Drain the yuca and arrange on a serving platter.
Pour the hot mojo sauce over the yuca and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Cuban Flan
recipes.description: A silky, caramel-crowned custard made with sweetened condensed milk, evaporated milk, eggs, and vanilla. The quintessential Cuban dessert with an impossibly smooth texture.
instructions: Preheat the oven to 165C (325F). Place a kettle of water on to boil for the water bath.
In a saucepan over medium heat, melt the sugar, swirling (not stirring) until it turns a deep amber caramel. Immediately pour into a 23 cm round baking dish, tilting to coat the bottom evenly.
In a blender, combine the eggs, sweetened condensed milk, evaporated milk, cream cheese, vanilla extract, and salt. Blend until completely smooth.
Pour the custard mixture over the hardened caramel in the baking dish.
Place the dish in a larger roasting pan and pour boiling water into the roasting pan until it reaches halfway up the sides of the flan dish.
Bake in the water bath for 55-60 minutes until the flan is set around the edges but still slightly jiggly in the center.

Remove from the water bath, cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight. To serve, run a knife around the edges and invert onto a plate, letting the caramel cascade over the flan.

recipes.name: Mofongo
recipes.description: Mashed fried green plantains pounded with garlic, pork cracklings, and olive oil in a pilon (wooden mortar). Puerto Rico's most iconic dish, often served with a rich broth.
instructions: Peel the green plantains and cut into 2.5 cm thick rounds.
Heat vegetable oil to 170C (340F) and fry the plantain pieces for 5-7 minutes until golden but not crispy. Drain on paper towels.
In a pilon or large mortar, pound the garlic cloves with olive oil and salt into a paste.
Add the fried plantains and chicharrones to the mortar in batches, pounding and mashing until combined but still slightly chunky.
Shape the mofongo into rounded mounds using the mortar or a small bowl as a mold.
Heat the chicken broth and serve the mofongo in a bowl with the hot broth poured around it.

recipes.name: Pernil
recipes.description: Slow-roasted pork shoulder marinated in a pungent adobo of garlic, oregano, vinegar, and sazon. The centerpiece of every Puerto Rican Christmas and holiday celebration.
instructions: Blend the garlic, oregano, cumin, black pepper, vinegar, olive oil, sazon, achiote, salt, and sofrito into a thick adobo paste.
Pierce the pork shoulder all over with a knife, making deep pockets. Rub the adobo paste into every incision and all over the surface.
Place in a large roasting pan, cover tightly with plastic wrap and then foil. Marinate in the refrigerator for 24-48 hours.
Remove the pork from the refrigerator 2 hours before cooking to come to room temperature. Preheat the oven to 165C (325F).
Cover the pan tightly with foil and roast for 4-5 hours, basting with pan juices every hour.
Remove the foil, increase the oven to 220C (425F), and roast for 30-45 minutes more until the skin is deeply browned and crackled.
Rest for 20 minutes before carving. Serve with arroz con gandules and pasteles.

recipes.name: Arroz con Gandules
recipes.description: Puerto Rico's signature rice dish cooked with pigeon peas, sofrito, sazon, and pork in a caldero. A non-negotiable presence at every family gathering and holiday feast.
instructions: Heat olive oil and achiote oil in a caldero or heavy pot. Cook the diced salt pork until rendered and golden.
Add the sofrito and cook for 2-3 minutes until fragrant.
Stir in the tomato sauce, sazon, olives, capers, and culantro. Cook for 2 minutes.
Add the drained pigeon peas and chicken broth. Bring to a boil.
Add the rinsed rice and stir well. When the liquid returns to a boil and the rice is visible above the liquid, reduce the heat to the lowest setting.
Cover tightly and cook for 25-30 minutes without lifting the lid.
Fluff the rice with a fork from bottom to top, scraping the prized pegao (crispy bottom layer). Serve with pernil or roasted chicken.

recipes.name: Tostones
recipes.description: Twice-fried green plantain discs that are crispy on the outside and starchy-tender within. An indispensable Puerto Rican side dish served with garlic mayo or mojo.
instructions: Peel the green plantains and cut into 3 cm thick rounds.
Dissolve the salt and crushed garlic in the water to make garlic salted water (agua con ajo).
Heat vegetable oil in a deep skillet to 165C (330F). Fry the plantain pieces for 3-4 minutes until light golden. Remove and drain.
Using a tostonera or the flat bottom of a glass, press each fried piece to flatten to about 6 mm thickness.
Dip each flattened plantain briefly into the garlic salted water.
Increase the oil temperature to 180C (360F) and fry the tostones again for 2-3 minutes until deep golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels, sprinkle with salt, and serve immediately with mayo-ketchup or garlic mojo.

recipes.name: Pasteles
recipes.description: Puerto Rican tamale-like parcels of green banana and root vegetable masa filled with seasoned pork, wrapped in banana leaves and boiled. A labor-of-love holiday tradition.
instructions: Prepare the filling: dice the pork and saute with sofrito and sazon until cooked through. Add a splash of broth, olives, and simmer until flavorful. Set aside to cool.
Peel and grate the green bananas, plantains, yautia, and calabaza. Process in a food processor until smooth.
Mix the achiote oil and a little salt into the masa until the color is even and the mixture is spreadable.
Soften the banana leaves by passing them briefly over a flame or dipping in hot water.
Layer parchment paper on a work surface, place a banana leaf on top. Spread about 80 g of masa in a rectangle, add a spoonful of pork filling and 2 olives.
Fold the banana leaf and parchment to enclose the filling, then tie securely with kitchen twine.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Submerge the pasteles and cook for 45-60 minutes.
Remove from water, let rest for 10 minutes, then unwrap and serve.

recipes.name: Tembleque
recipes.description: A silky Puerto Rican coconut milk pudding thickened with cornstarch and dusted with cinnamon. This jiggly, refreshing dessert is a Christmas season essential.
instructions: In a bowl, whisk together the cornstarch with 200 ml of the coconut milk until completely smooth with no lumps.
In a saucepan, heat the remaining 600 ml coconut milk with sugar and salt over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Slowly pour the cornstarch mixture into the warm coconut milk while stirring constantly.
Continue stirring over medium heat for 8-10 minutes until the mixture thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon and pulls away from the sides.
Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla extract.
Pour into a mold or individual ramekins. Let cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 4 hours until set.
Unmold onto a plate and dust generously with ground cinnamon before serving.

recipes.name: Doubles
recipes.description: Trinidad's iconic street food: two soft, pillowy turmeric-spiced fried breads (bara) filled with curried chickpeas (channa) and drizzled with tamarind and pepper sauce.
instructions: Make the bara dough: dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water for 5 minutes. Combine flour, turmeric, cumin, and salt, then mix in the yeast water to form a soft dough. Knead for 5 minutes. Cover and let rise for 1 hour.

Make the channa: heat oil in a pot, saute diced onion and garlic, add curry powder and cook for 1 minute. Add drained chickpeas and enough water to partially cover. Add whole scotch bonnet and simmer for 20 minutes.
Mash some of the chickpeas against the pot to thicken the curry. Remove the scotch bonnet and season with salt.
Divide the risen dough into 20 small balls. Flatten each into a thin disc about 10 cm across.
Heat oil to 175C (350F) and fry each bara for about 30 seconds per side until puffed and golden.
To assemble each double: place two bara slightly overlapping, spoon channa filling in the center, and drizzle with tamarind sauce and pepper sauce.
Serve immediately. Eat with hands, folded like a taco.

recipes.name: Trinidadian Roti (Dhalpuri)
recipes.description: Soft, layered flatbread filled with seasoned ground split peas, served as a wrap for curries. Brought to Trinidad by Indian indentured laborers and now a national staple.
instructions: Boil the split peas until very soft, about 30 minutes. Drain completely and grind in a food processor with cumin, turmeric, and garlic into a dry, seasoned paste.
Mix the flour, baking powder, salt, and 2 tablespoons of oil. Gradually add warm water to form a soft dough. Knead for 5 minutes, then rest for 20 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6 balls. Flatten each ball, place a spoonful of the split pea filling in the center, and seal by gathering the edges together.
Carefully roll out each filled ball into a thin circle about 25 cm in diameter, being gentle not to tear the dough.
Cook each roti on a hot tawa or cast-iron skillet, brushing with oil, for about 2 minutes per side until browned with dark spots.
Remove from the heat and clap between your hands or fold in a towel to keep soft and pliable.
Serve filled with curry chicken, curry goat, or channa and potato.

recipes.name: Pelau
recipes.description: Trinidad's beloved one-pot dish of caramelized chicken, pigeon peas, and rice cooked in coconut milk with browning. Smoky-sweet with a rich depth of flavor from the burnt sugar base.
instructions: Season the chicken with green seasoning, browning sauce, garlic, and salt. Marinate for at least 30 minutes.
In a large heavy pot, heat oil and add the brown sugar. Stir continuously over medium-high heat until the sugar melts and turns a dark caramel color.
Immediately add the marinated chicken pieces to the caramelized sugar, stirring to coat. Cook for 5 minutes, turning to brown all sides.
Add the diced onion, thyme, ketchup, and whole scotch bonnet. Stir for 2 minutes.
Add the coconut milk, drained pigeon peas, and enough water to total about 700 ml liquid. Bring to a boil.
Add the rinsed rice, stir once, and when the liquid reduces to the level of the rice, reduce heat to the lowest setting and cover tightly.
Cook for 25-30 minutes without lifting the lid. Fluff with a fork and serve hot.

recipes.name: Trinidadian Callaloo
recipes.description: A thick, creamy soup of dasheen (taro) leaves simmered with okra, coconut milk, crab, and pumpkin. Distinctly different from Jamaican callaloo, this version is pureed to a velvety consistency.
instructions: Strip the dasheen leaves from their stems and wash thoroughly. Roughly chop the leaves.
In a large pot, combine the dasheen leaves, sliced okra, diced pumpkin, diced onion, garlic, green onions, thyme, and whole scotch bonnet.
Pour in the coconut milk and enough water to just cover the ingredients. Bring to a boil.
Add the cleaned crabs, reduce heat, and simmer for 30-35 minutes until the leaves are very tender and the crab is cooked through.
Remove the crabs and scotch bonnet. Use an immersion blender or swizzle stick (le le) to puree the callaloo to a thick, smooth consistency.
Return the crabs to the pot, season with salt and black pepper, and simmer for 5 more minutes.
Serve hot as a side dish with rice, macaroni pie, or as a sauce over provisions.

recipes.name: Macaroni Pie
recipes.description: Trinidadian baked macaroni and cheese enriched with eggs, mustard, and sharp cheddar, baked until firm enough to slice. A creamy, dense side dish that's a fixture at every lime and fete.
instructions: Preheat the oven to 180C (350F). Grease a 23x33 cm baking dish with butter.
Cook the macaroni in salted boiling water until just al dente, about 7 minutes. Drain well.
In a large bowl, whisk together the evaporated milk, eggs, mustard, ketchup, salt, black pepper, and paprika.
Grate the cheddar cheese. Reserve a handful for topping and add the rest to the milk mixture along with the butter.
Add the cooked macaroni to the cheese mixture and stir until well combined. Pour into the prepared baking dish.
Scatter the reserved cheese over the top.
Bake for 35-40 minutes until set, golden on top, and firm enough to slice. Let cool for 10 minutes before cutting into squares.

recipes.name: Griot
recipes.description: Haiti's signature dish of pork shoulder cubes marinated in sour orange and epis, braised until tender, then fried to a gloriously crispy finish. Served with pikliz, a fiery pickled slaw.

ingredients.name: sour orange juice (or lime and orange mix)

instructions: Blend the onion, shallots, garlic, scotch bonnet, parsley, green onions, and sour orange juice into a smooth epis (seasoning base).
Cut the pork shoulder into 5 cm cubes. Toss with the epis, thyme sprigs, cloves, salt, and black pepper. Marinate for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Place the marinated pork and all its juices in a heavy pot. Add just enough water to barely cover. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer, covered, for 45-60 minutes until the pork is very tender and the liquid has almost completely evaporated.
Remove the thyme sprigs and cloves. Heat vegetable oil in a deep skillet or pot to 180C (360F).
Fry the braised pork cubes in batches until deep golden and crispy on all sides, about 4-5 minutes per batch.
Drain on paper towels and serve with diri ak djon djon, fried plantains, and pikliz.

recipes.name: Diri ak Djon Djon
recipes.description: Haitian black mushroom rice made with dried djon djon mushrooms that dye the rice an inky black color while imparting a deep, earthy umami flavor. A dish served at celebrations and special occasions.
instructions: Rinse the djon djon mushrooms, then boil them in 750 ml of water for 15 minutes to extract their inky black liquid. Strain, discard the mushroom stems, and reserve the black broth.
If using dried lima beans, boil separately until tender. If canned, drain and rinse.
In a heavy pot, melt the butter and saute the diced onion, minced shallots, and garlic until softened.
Add the thyme, cloves, parsley, chicken bouillon, salt, and pepper. Stir for 1 minute.
Add the rinsed rice and stir to coat in the aromatics. Pour in the reserved djon djon broth (it should be about 2 cm above the rice level).
Add the lima beans. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to the lowest setting and cover tightly.
Cook for 20-25 minutes without lifting the lid. Fluff with a fork and serve alongside griot or stewed chicken.

recipes.name: Mangu
recipes.description: Mashed boiled green plantains finished with butter and topped with sauteed red onions (cebolla). The heart of the Dominican breakfast 'Los Tres Golpes' alongside fried salami, eggs, and cheese.
instructions: Peel the green plantains and cut into 5 cm chunks. Boil in salted water for 20-25 minutes until very tender.
While the plantains boil, slice the red onion into thin rings. Heat olive oil in a skillet and saute the onion rings with a pinch of salt for 3-4 minutes until softened.
Add the apple cider vinegar to the onions, toss to coat, and remove from heat. Set aside.
Drain the plantains, reserving about 120 ml of the cooking water.
Mash the plantains with butter and enough reserved cooking water to reach a smooth, creamy consistency.
Serve the mangu mounded on a plate, topped with the pickled sauteed red onions. Traditionally accompanied by fried Dominican salami, fried eggs, and queso frito.

recipes.name: Sancocho
recipes.description: A hearty Dominican seven-meat stew loaded with root vegetables, plantains, and corn simmered in a rich herb broth. The ultimate comfort soup, traditionally served at large family gatherings.
instructions: Season the chicken, beef, and pork with minced garlic, sour orange juice, sazon, salt, and chopped cilantro stems. Marinate for at least 30 minutes.
In a very large pot, bring 3 liters of water to a boil. Add the beef and pork first, as they take the longest to cook. Simmer for 45 minutes, skimming any foam from the surface.
Add the chicken pieces and continue simmering for 20 minutes.
Peel and cut the yuca, yautia, plantains, and pumpkin into large chunks. Cut the corn into 5 cm rounds.
Add the yuca and yautia to the pot and cook for 15 minutes.
Add the plantains, pumpkin, and corn. Continue simmering for 20-25 minutes until all the vegetables are tender and the broth has thickened naturally from the starches.
Stir in chopped cilantro leaves. Adjust salt and serve in deep bowls with white rice on the side and a squeeze of lime.

recipes.name: Kung Pao Chicken
recipes.description: Spicy Sichuan stir-fry with chicken, peanuts, and dried chilies in a savory-sweet sauce.
instructions: Cut chicken into 2cm cubes and marinate with 1 tbsp soy sauce, shaoxing wine, and cornstarch for 15 minutes.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat until smoking. Stir-fry chicken until golden, about 3 minutes. Remove and set aside.
In the same wok, toast dried chilies and Sichuan peppercorns until fragrant, about 30 seconds.
Add garlic and ginger, stir-fry for 30 seconds until aromatic.
Return chicken to wok. Add remaining soy sauce, vinegar, and sugar. Toss to coat evenly.
Add peanuts and scallions, stir-fry for 1 minute until combined.
Serve immediately over steamed rice.

recipes.name: Mapo Tofu
recipes.description: Silky tofu in a fiery Sichuan sauce with ground pork, doubanjiang, and Sichuan peppercorns.
instructions: Cut tofu into 2cm cubes and gently blanch in salted boiling water for 2 minutes. Drain carefully.
Heat oil in a wok, brown the pork over high heat, breaking it into small pieces.
Push pork to the side, add doubanjiang and fermented black beans. Stir-fry until oil turns red.
Add minced garlic and ginger, cook 30 seconds until fragrant.
Pour in chicken stock and soy sauce. Bring to a simmer.
Gently slide tofu into the sauce. Simmer for 5 minutes without stirring too vigorously.
Mix cornstarch with 2 tbsp water, stir into the sauce to thicken. Finish with sesame oil, ground Sichuan peppercorn, and sliced scallions.

recipes.name: Dan Dan Noodles
recipes.description: Sichuan street-food noodles with spicy sesame-peanut sauce, preserved vegetables, and ground pork.
instructions: Mix sesame paste, chili oil, soy sauce, vinegar, minced garlic, and Sichuan peppercorn powder in a bowl for the sauce.
Heat oil in a wok, stir-fry ground pork until browned and crispy.
Add ya cai and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Cook noodles according to package directions. Drain, reserving 100ml cooking water.
Divide sauce among four bowls. Add a splash of noodle water to each bowl and stir.
Top with noodles, then pork and ya cai mixture.
Garnish with crushed peanuts and sliced scallions. Toss before eating.

recipes.name: Twice-Cooked Pork
recipes.description: Sichuan classic of boiled then wok-fried pork belly with leeks and doubanjiang.
instructions: Boil pork belly whole in water with ginger slices for 20 minutes until just cooked through. Let cool.
Slice the cooled pork belly into thin pieces about 3mm thick.
Cut leeks into diagonal slices and green pepper into pieces.
Heat wok with a little oil, add pork slices and fry until edges curl and fat renders.
Push pork aside, add doubanjiang and black beans, fry until oil turns red.
Add garlic, leeks, and pepper. Stir-fry on high heat for 2 minutes.
Add soy sauce, shaoxing wine, and sugar. Toss everything together and serve.

recipes.name: Sichuan Boiled Fish
recipes.description: Tender fish fillets poached in a fiery broth of chili oil, Sichuan peppercorns, and dried chilies.
instructions: Slice fish into thin pieces, marinate with egg white, cornstarch, and a pinch of salt for 15 minutes.
Blanch bean sprouts and place in the bottom of a large serving bowl.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in wok, fry doubanjiang with ginger and half the garlic until fragrant.
Add stock and soy sauce, bring to a boil. Gently slide fish slices in and poach for 2 minutes.
Pour fish and broth over bean sprouts in the bowl.
Top with remaining sliced garlic, scallions, dried chilies, and Sichuan peppercorns.
Heat remaining oil until smoking and pour over the toppings to sizzle and bloom the spices.

recipes.name: Bang Bang Chicken
recipes.description: Cold shredded chicken in a nutty, spicy Sichuan sesame sauce, a classic appetizer.
instructions: Poach chicken breasts in simmering water with ginger and scallion for 15 minutes. Remove and let cool completely.
Shred the chicken by hand into thin strips.
Smash and slice cucumber, arrange on a serving plate.
Mix sesame paste, chili oil, soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, minced garlic, and Sichuan peppercorn powder into a smooth sauce.
Pile shredded chicken on top of cucumber.
Pour the sauce generously over the chicken.
Garnish with sesame seeds and sliced scallions. Serve cold.

recipes.name: Hot and Sour Soup
recipes.description: A warming soup balancing spicy white pepper, tangy vinegar, silky tofu, and egg ribbons.
instructions: Soak wood ear mushrooms and lily buds in hot water for 20 minutes. Drain and slice.
Cut tofu, pork, and bamboo shoots into thin matchstick strips.
Bring chicken stock to a boil. Add pork strips and cook 2 minutes.
Add tofu, mushrooms, lily buds, and bamboo shoots. Simmer 5 minutes.
Season with soy sauce, vinegar, and white pepper.
Mix cornstarch with 3 tbsp water and stir into soup to thicken.
Slowly drizzle beaten eggs into the simmering soup while stirring gently. Finish with sesame oil and chili oil.

recipes.name: Char Siu (Cantonese BBQ Pork)
recipes.description: Sweet and savory Cantonese roasted pork with a glossy caramelized glaze of honey and five spice.
instructions: Cut pork shoulder into long strips about 3cm thick.
Mix all remaining ingredients except 1 tbsp honey to make the marinade.
Coat pork strips thoroughly and marinate in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
Preheat oven to 220C. Place pork on a wire rack over a foil-lined baking tray.
Roast for 15 minutes, then flip and baste with marinade.
Continue roasting for another 15 minutes, basting once more.
Mix remaining honey with warm water, brush over pork. Broil for 2 minutes until charred. Rest 5 minutes before slicing.

recipes.name: Wonton Soup
recipes.description: Delicate pork and shrimp wontons in a clear, aromatic broth topped with scallions and sesame oil.
instructions: Mince shrimp and combine with ground pork, 1 sliced scallion, grated ginger, soy sauce, 1 tsp sesame oil, and white pepper.
Place a teaspoon of filling in each wonton wrapper. Moisten edges with water and fold into desired shape.
Bring chicken stock to a boil with dried shrimp. Season with salt.
In a separate pot, boil water and cook wontons for 3-4 minutes until they float.
Transfer wontons to serving bowls using a slotted spoon.
Ladle hot broth over the wontons.
Garnish with sliced scallions and a drizzle of sesame oil.

recipes.name: Cantonese Congee
recipes.description: Silky smooth rice porridge slow-cooked until creamy, served with savory toppings.
instructions: Rinse rice and soak for 30 minutes. Drain.
Bring stock and water to a boil. Add rice and sliced ginger.
Reduce heat to low, cover and simmer for 1 hour, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Slice pork thinly and marinate with soy sauce. Dice century eggs.
When congee is thick and creamy, add pork slices and stir. Cook 5 more minutes.
Stir in century egg pieces and white pepper.
Serve topped with scallions, fried shallots, and a drizzle of sesame oil.

recipes.name: Cantonese Steamed Fish
recipes.description: Whole fish steamed to perfection and finished with hot oil poured over ginger, scallion, and soy.
instructions: Clean and score the fish on both sides with diagonal cuts. Rub with shaoxing wine and white pepper.
Place fish on a heatproof plate. Lay half the ginger slices on and around the fish.
Steam over rapidly boiling water for 10-12 minutes until flesh is opaque and flakes easily.
Carefully drain off any liquid from the plate.
Top fish with julienned ginger, shredded scallions, and cilantro. Pour soy sauce mixed with sugar around the fish.
Heat vegetable oil until smoking and pour directly over the ginger and scallions to sizzle.
Serve immediately with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Har Gow (Crystal Shrimp Dumplings)
recipes.description: Translucent-skinned Cantonese dim sum dumplings filled with juicy seasoned shrimp.
instructions: Devein shrimp, chop half roughly and dice half finely for texture. Mix with minced bamboo shoots, sesame oil, sugar, white pepper, and salt.
Combine wheat starch and tapioca starch. Pour in boiling water and stir quickly. Add oil and knead into a smooth dough.
Divide dough into 20 pieces. Roll each into a thin circle using an oiled cleaver blade.
Place a spoonful of filling in the center of each wrapper.
Pleat one side of the wrapper to form the classic crescent shape, pressing edges to seal.
Line a steamer with parchment paper. Place dumplings without touching.
Steam over high heat for 6-8 minutes until wrappers turn translucent. Serve with soy-vinegar dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Siu Mai (Pork and Shrimp Dumplings)
recipes.description: Open-topped Cantonese dim sum dumplings with pork, shrimp, and a dot of orange roe.
instructions: Soak shiitake mushrooms in hot water for 20 minutes. Drain and finely dice.
Chop shrimp into small pieces. Mix with ground pork, mushrooms, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sesame oil, sugar, cornstarch, and white pepper.
Place a wrapper on your palm. Add a tablespoon of filling in the center.
Gather the wrapper around the filling, forming a cup shape with the top open.
Flatten the bottom and top. Place a small dot of tobiko or grated carrot on top.
Arrange in a lined steamer basket.
Steam over high heat for 8-10 minutes until pork is cooked through. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Char Siu Bao (BBQ Pork Buns)
recipes.description: Fluffy steamed buns filled with sweet and savory Cantonese BBQ pork.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, and baking powder. Add warm water and oil, knead into a soft dough. Rest for 1 hour until doubled.
Dice char siu pork into small cubes.
Heat a pan, cook oyster sauce, hoisin, soy sauce, and sugar. Add pork and stir. Thicken with cornstarch slurry. Add sesame oil. Cool completely.
Divide dough into 12 pieces. Flatten each into a circle thicker in the center.
Place a spoonful of filling in the center. Gather edges and twist to seal.
Place each bun on a small square of parchment, sealed side down. Rest 20 minutes.
Steam over high heat for 12-15 minutes until buns are puffy and split slightly. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Clay Pot Rice
recipes.description: Cantonese comfort food with rice, Chinese sausage, and a prized layer of crispy scorched rice.
instructions: Rinse rice and soak for 30 minutes. Drain.
Brush the inside of a clay pot with vegetable oil. Add rice and water.
Bring to a boil uncovered, then reduce to the lowest heat. Cover and cook 10 minutes.
Slice Chinese sausage diagonally. Cut chicken into thin slices.
When rice is almost done, lay sausage and chicken on top. Cover and cook another 10 minutes.
Blanch bok choy separately and place on top.
Mix soy sauces, oyster sauce, sugar, and sesame oil. Drizzle over the dish. Serve in the clay pot.

recipes.name: Lo Mai Gai (Sticky Rice in Lotus Leaf)
recipes.description: Steamed glutinous rice parcels wrapped in lotus leaf, filled with chicken, mushrooms, and Chinese sausage.
instructions: Soak glutinous rice for at least 4 hours. Soak lotus leaves in warm water for 1 hour.
Soak mushrooms and dried shrimp in hot water for 20 minutes. Dice mushrooms, sausage, and chicken.
Steam the soaked rice for 20 minutes until cooked. Mix with oyster sauce, dark soy, and sesame oil.
Stir-fry chicken, sausage, mushrooms, and shrimp with soy sauce and five spice until cooked.
Lay out a lotus leaf. Place a layer of rice, then filling, then more rice.
Wrap tightly into a parcel and tie with kitchen string.
Steam the parcels for 25-30 minutes. Unwrap at the table to enjoy the lotus fragrance.

recipes.name: Xiaolongbao (Soup Dumplings)
recipes.description: Shanghai's famous steamed dumplings with thin skins enclosing pork filling and rich, hot broth.
instructions: Make dough: mix flour with warm water, knead until smooth and elastic. Rest covered for 30 minutes.
Mix ground pork with soy sauce, shaoxing wine, sesame oil, sugar, white pepper, minced ginger, and scallions.
Dice pork skin jelly finely and fold into the meat mixture. Refrigerate 15 minutes.
Divide dough into 24 small pieces. Roll each into a thin circle, thicker in the center.
Place filling in center, pleat edges with at least 12 folds and pinch closed at the top.
Place dumplings on parchment squares in a steamer, not touching.
Steam over high heat for 8-10 minutes. Serve with Chinkiang vinegar and ginger slivers.

recipes.name: Lion's Head Meatballs
