Serve immediately with chopped parsley, lemon wedges, and a drizzle of olive oil.

recipes.name: Pollo alla Cacciatora
recipes.description: Hunter-style braised chicken with tomatoes, bell peppers, onions, olives, and herbs. A rustic one-pot dish found across central Italy.
instructions: Season the chicken pieces with salt and pepper and brown in olive oil on all sides.
Remove the chicken and saute sliced onion, peppers, and garlic until softened.
Deglaze with white wine and let it reduce by half.
Add crushed tomatoes, olives, and rosemary, and return the chicken to the pan.
Cover and simmer for 35-40 minutes until the chicken is cooked through and tender.
Adjust seasoning and serve with crusty bread or polenta.

recipes.name: Polenta con Gorgonzola
recipes.description: Creamy slow-cooked cornmeal polenta from Northern Italy topped with melted gorgonzola cheese. Rich, comforting, and indulgent.
instructions: Bring salted water to a boil, then slowly pour in the polenta in a thin stream while whisking.
Reduce heat to low and cook for 40-45 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent lumps.
Stir in butter and grated Parmigiano until melted and incorporated.
Spoon the creamy polenta into warm bowls.
Top each serving with crumbled gorgonzola dolce and let it melt into the hot polenta.

recipes.name: Carpaccio di Manzo
recipes.description: Paper-thin slices of raw beef tenderloin dressed with lemon, olive oil, arugula, and shaved Parmigiano. Invented at Harry's Bar in Venice.
instructions: Wrap the beef tenderloin tightly in plastic wrap and freeze for 30 minutes to firm up.
Using a very sharp knife, slice the beef as thinly as possible.
Arrange the slices on chilled plates, covering the entire surface.
Drizzle generously with olive oil and lemon juice.
Scatter arugula, shaved Parmigiano, and capers over the top.
Season with flaky sea salt and freshly cracked pepper and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Prosciutto e Melone
recipes.description: A classic Italian summer antipasto pairing sweet ripe cantaloupe melon with silky, salty prosciutto di Parma. Effortlessly elegant.
instructions: Cut the cantaloupe in half, remove the seeds, and slice into wedges.
Drape slices of prosciutto over each melon wedge.
Arrange on a serving platter.
Drizzle with a little olive oil and finish with freshly cracked black pepper.
Serve immediately at room temperature.

recipes.name: Salsiccia e Peperoni
recipes.description: Italian pork sausages pan-fried with sweet and hot peppers, onions, and garlic. A beloved street food and family dinner staple.
instructions: Brown the sausages in olive oil over medium heat on all sides.
Remove sausages and add sliced peppers and onions to the pan.
Cook peppers and onions for 8 minutes until softened and lightly charred.
Add garlic and oregano, cook for 1 minute.
Return sausages, pour in wine, and simmer for 10 minutes until sausages are cooked through.
Season with salt and pepper, and serve with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Zabaglione
recipes.description: A warm, frothy Piedmontese custard made with egg yolks, sugar, and Marsala wine, whisked over a double boiler until thick and airy.
instructions: Set a heatproof bowl over a pot of gently simmering water, ensuring the bowl does not touch the water.
Whisk egg yolks and sugar vigorously until pale and thick.
Gradually add the Marsala wine while continuing to whisk constantly.
Continue whisking for 8-10 minutes until the mixture triples in volume and holds soft peaks.
Spoon the warm zabaglione into glasses and serve immediately with fresh berries.

recipes.name: Affogato al Caffe
recipes.description: The simplest Italian dessert: a scoop of vanilla gelato drowned in a shot of hot espresso. A perfect balance of hot and cold, bitter and sweet.
instructions: Brew two shots of strong espresso.
Place a generous scoop of vanilla gelato into each serving glass or cup.
Pour the hot espresso immediately over the gelato.
Serve at once with amaretti biscuits on the side for crumbling.

recipes.name: Gelato alla Stracciatella
recipes.description: Classic Italian ice cream with a smooth fior di latte (milk) base and fine shards of dark chocolate folded throughout.
instructions: Heat milk and cream together until just steaming.
Whisk egg yolks with sugar until pale, then temper with the hot milk mixture.
Cook the custard over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it coats the back of a spoon.
Strain through a sieve, cool completely, and refrigerate overnight.
Churn in an ice cream maker according to manufacturer instructions.
Melt chocolate with cocoa butter and drizzle into the churning gelato in the last minute to form thin shards.
Transfer to a container and freeze for at least 2 hours before serving.

recipes.name: Brasato al Barolo
recipes.description: Piedmontese pot roast of beef braised slowly in Barolo wine with aromatic vegetables until meltingly tender. A quintessential Northern Italian celebration dish.
instructions: Marinate the beef in Barolo with onion, carrot, celery, garlic, cinnamon, bay leaves, and cloves overnight.
Remove the beef and pat dry, strain and reserve the wine and vegetables separately.
Brown the beef on all sides in butter and olive oil in a heavy Dutch oven.
Add the marinated vegetables and cook until softened.
Pour in the reserved wine and bring to a simmer.
Cover tightly and braise in a 150C oven for 3 to 3.5 hours until fork-tender.
Remove beef, strain the sauce, reduce it until glossy, and serve sliced with the sauce.

recipes.name: Porchetta
recipes.description: Herb-stuffed rolled pork roast from central Italy with crispy crackling and succulent meat flavored with fennel, garlic, and rosemary.
instructions: Score the skin of the pork belly in a crosshatch pattern and rub with salt.
Pulse garlic, fennel seeds, rosemary, sage, chili, lemon zest, pepper, and olive oil into a paste.
Open the pork belly skin-side down and spread the herb paste evenly over the meat.
Roll the pork tightly and tie securely with kitchen twine at 3cm intervals.
Roast at 220C for 30 minutes to crisp the skin, then reduce to 160C and cook for 2.5 hours.
Rest for 20 minutes before slicing into thick rounds.

recipes.name: Piccata di Pollo
recipes.description: Thin chicken cutlets dredged in flour, pan-fried in butter, and sauced with lemon, white wine, and capers. Light and tangy.
instructions: Pound chicken cutlets thin, season with salt and pepper, and dredge in flour.
Cook in a mix of olive oil and half the butter for 3 minutes per side until golden.
Remove chicken and set aside.
Deglaze the pan with wine and lemon juice, scraping up any browned bits.
Add chicken broth and capers, simmer until reduced by half.
Swirl in remaining butter, return the chicken to the sauce, and heat through.
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve with lemon slices.

recipes.name: Panzanella
recipes.description: Tuscan bread salad with chunks of stale bread soaked in tomato juices and vinaigrette, tossed with ripe tomatoes, cucumbers, red onion, and basil.
instructions: Tear or cube the stale bread and briefly soak in water, then squeeze out the excess.
Cut tomatoes into chunks, collecting their juices, and dice the cucumber.
Thinly slice the red onion and soak in cold water for 10 minutes to tame its bite.
Toss the bread, tomatoes with their juices, cucumber, and drained onion in a large bowl.
Dress with olive oil, red wine vinegar, salt, and pepper.
Let the salad sit for at least 30 minutes for the bread to absorb the flavors, then add basil and serve.

recipes.name: Bagna Cauda
recipes.description: A warm Piedmontese dip of anchovies, garlic, and olive oil served with raw vegetables for dipping. A convivial dish shared at the table.
instructions: Slice garlic very thinly and simmer gently in olive oil over the lowest heat for 15 minutes, never letting it color.
Add the anchovy fillets and stir until they completely dissolve into the oil.
Add butter and stir until melted and combined.
Cut vegetables into sticks and arrange on a platter around the warm dipping pot.
Serve the bagna cauda warm in a traditional terracotta pot or fondue-style warmer.
Dip the raw vegetables into the warm sauce and eat.

recipes.name: Zuppa Toscana
recipes.description: A hearty Tuscan soup with Italian sausage, potatoes, and kale in a flavorful broth. Warming and deeply satisfying.
instructions: Remove sausage from casings and brown in olive oil, breaking it into crumbles.
Add diced onion and garlic, cooking until softened.
Pour in chicken broth and add thinly sliced potatoes.
Simmer for 15 minutes until potatoes are tender.
Add torn cavolo nero and chili flakes, cooking for another 5 minutes.
Stir in cream, adjust seasoning with salt, and serve hot.

recipes.name: Pasta alla Norma
recipes.description: Sicily's signature pasta dish with fried eggplant, tomato sauce, basil, and shavings of salty ricotta salata. Named after Bellini's opera.
instructions: Cut eggplant into 2cm cubes, salt, and drain for 20 minutes, then pat dry.
Fry eggplant cubes in olive oil until deep golden on all sides and set aside.
In the same pan, saute garlic in a little oil, add crushed tomatoes and basil, and simmer for 15 minutes.
Cook rigatoni in salted boiling water until al dente.
Toss the drained pasta with the tomato sauce and most of the fried eggplant.
Serve topped with remaining eggplant, torn basil, and grated ricotta salata.

recipes.name: Linguine al Limone
recipes.description: A bright and creamy Amalfi Coast pasta tossed with lemon juice, lemon zest, cream, and Parmigiano. Quick, elegant, and refreshing.
instructions: Cook linguine in salted boiling water until al dente.
Zest and juice the lemons.
Warm cream and butter in a large pan, then add lemon zest and juice.
Drain pasta and toss in the lemon cream sauce with a splash of pasta water.
Add grated Parmigiano and toss until creamy and glossy.
Serve with torn basil and freshly cracked pepper.

recipes.name: Crostini di Fegato
recipes.description: Tuscan chicken liver crostini spread on toasted bread. A rich, savory appetizer traditionally served as part of an antipasto spread.
instructions: Clean chicken livers, removing any sinew, and roughly chop.
Saute finely diced onion in olive oil until softened.
Add chicken livers and cook over medium-high heat for 5 minutes until browned but still slightly pink inside.
Add anchovies and capers, then deglaze with Vin Santo.
Remove from heat, add butter, and chop or pulse to a rough paste.
Toast bread slices and spread the warm liver paste on top.

recipes.name: Suppli al Telefono
recipes.description: Roman fried rice croquettes filled with mozzarella that stretches like telephone wires when pulled apart. A beloved street food snack.
instructions: Cook rice in tomato sauce diluted with water, then mix with ragu, Parmigiano, and one beaten egg, and let cool.
Cut mozzarella into small cubes.
Take a handful of rice, flatten, place a cube of mozzarella in the center, and form into an oval shape.
Beat the remaining eggs, dip each suppli in egg, then coat in breadcrumbs.
Deep fry at 180C for 3-4 minutes until deep golden.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot, pulling apart to reveal the stretchy mozzarella.

recipes.name: Pappa al Pomodoro
recipes.description: A thick Tuscan tomato and bread soup made with stale bread, ripe tomatoes, garlic, and basil. Humble peasant food elevated to art.
instructions: Saute smashed garlic cloves in olive oil until golden, then remove.
Add peeled and roughly chopped tomatoes and cook for 10 minutes.
Tear stale bread into chunks and add to the pot with warm broth.
Simmer for 15 minutes, stirring frequently, until the bread breaks down into a thick porridge.
Stir in torn basil, season with salt and pepper.
Serve warm or at room temperature with a generous drizzle of olive oil.

recipes.name: Fegato alla Veneziana
recipes.description: Thinly sliced calf liver cooked with slowly caramelized onions, white wine, and a touch of vinegar. A specialty of Venice.
instructions: Slice onions into very thin half-moons and cook slowly in butter and olive oil for 20 minutes until golden and caramelized.
Slice the liver very thinly, removing any membranes.
Push the onions to the side, increase heat, and sear the liver for 1 minute per side.
Deglaze with white wine and vinegar, tossing everything together.
Season with salt and pepper, garnish with parsley, and serve immediately with polenta.

recipes.name: Torta della Nonna
recipes.description: Grandmother's custard tart with a buttery shortcrust pastry filled with lemon-scented pastry cream and topped with pine nuts and powdered sugar.
instructions: Make shortcrust pastry by rubbing cold butter into flour with sugar and salt, then binding with 1 egg.
Wrap dough and chill for 30 minutes.
Make pastry cream by whisking egg yolks with sugar and cornstarch, then cooking with milk, lemon zest, and vanilla until thick.
Roll out two-thirds of the dough and line a tart pan, fill with cooled pastry cream.
Roll out remaining dough for the lid, seal edges, and scatter pine nuts on top.
Bake at 180C for 30-35 minutes until golden.
Cool and dust with powdered sugar before serving.

recipes.name: Crespelle alla Fiorentina
recipes.description: Florentine crepes filled with ricotta and spinach, rolled, covered in bechamel sauce, and baked until golden. A Tuscan comfort classic.
instructions: Make crepe batter by whisking flour, eggs, and milk until smooth, then rest for 30 minutes.
Cook thin crepes in a buttered pan, stacking them as they are done.
Wilt spinach, squeeze dry, chop, and mix with ricotta, half the Parmigiano, nutmeg, and salt.
Make bechamel by melting butter, stirring in flour, and gradually adding milk while whisking.
Fill each crepe with the ricotta-spinach mixture and roll up.
Arrange the rolls in a baking dish, cover with bechamel and remaining Parmigiano.
Bake at 190C for 25 minutes until golden and bubbling.

recipes.name: Scaloppine al Marsala
recipes.description: Thin veal cutlets pan-fried and finished with a rich Marsala wine and mushroom sauce. An elegant Italian secondo piatto.
instructions: Pound veal escalopes thin, season with salt and pepper, and dust with flour.
Saute in half the butter and olive oil for 2 minutes per side until golden, then set aside.
Add sliced mushrooms to the pan and cook until golden brown.
Pour in Marsala wine and broth, scraping up the browned bits from the pan.
Simmer until the sauce reduces and thickens slightly.
Return the veal to the pan, add remaining butter, and swirl to create a glossy sauce.
Garnish with parsley and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Grissini Torinesi
recipes.description: Thin, crispy breadsticks from Turin, hand-stretched and baked until golden. Found on every Italian restaurant table.
instructions: Mix flour, yeast, salt, water, and olive oil to form a smooth dough.
Knead for 5 minutes, then rest the dough for 1 hour until doubled.
Roll the dough out into a rectangle on a semolina-dusted surface.
Cut into thin strips and gently stretch each one to about 30cm long.
Place on baking sheets and bake at 200C for 12-15 minutes until golden and crisp.
Cool on a rack and serve at room temperature.

recipes.name: Peperonata
recipes.description: A sweet and tangy stew of slow-cooked bell peppers, tomatoes, and onions. Served as a side dish, on bruschetta, or with grilled meats.
instructions: Slice peppers into thick strips and cut onion into half-moons.
Heat olive oil in a wide pan and saute onion and garlic until soft.
Add the peppers and cook for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add peeled, chopped tomatoes and a splash of vinegar.
Cover and cook gently for 20 minutes until peppers are silky soft.
Season with salt, scatter with basil, and serve warm or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Cacciucco alla Livornese
recipes.description: A rich and spicy Tuscan fish stew from Livorno with at least five types of seafood cooked in a garlicky tomato broth, served over toasted bread.
instructions: Cut octopus into pieces and simmer in water for 30 minutes until tender.
Saute sliced garlic and chili in olive oil, add crushed tomatoes and wine, and simmer for 15 minutes.
Add the octopus and tougher fish first, cooking for 5 minutes.
Add calamari rings, shrimp, and mussels, cover, and cook for 5-7 minutes until shellfish open.
Toast bread slices and rub with garlic.
Place toast in bowls, ladle the stew over, and finish with parsley and olive oil.

recipes.name: Biscotti di Prato
recipes.description: Twice-baked almond biscuits from Prato, crunchy and dry, traditionally dipped in Vin Santo dessert wine. The original cantucci.
instructions: Whisk eggs with sugar until light, then add lemon zest and vanilla.
Fold in flour, baking powder, salt, and whole almonds to form a sticky dough.
Shape the dough into two flat logs on a lined baking sheet.
Bake at 180C for 25 minutes until golden and firm.
Let cool slightly, then slice diagonally into 1cm thick biscotti.
Lay the slices cut-side down and bake again at 150C for 15 minutes until dry and crunchy.

recipes.name: Ciambella
recipes.description: A simple and rustic Italian ring cake, tender and lightly lemon-scented. The everyday cake found in Italian home kitchens.
instructions: Whisk eggs with sugar until pale and fluffy.
Add oil and milk, mixing until combined.
Fold in flour, baking powder, salt, lemon zest, and vanilla.
Pour batter into a greased and floured bundt pan.
Bake at 180C for 35-40 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean.
Cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then invert and dust with powdered sugar.

recipes.name: Farinata di Ceci
recipes.description: A thin, crispy Ligurian flatbread made from chickpea flour, water, and olive oil baked in a very hot oven. Naturally gluten-free.
instructions: Whisk chickpea flour into water gradually to avoid lumps, then add salt and half the olive oil.
Let the batter rest for at least 2 hours at room temperature, skimming any foam.
Pour the remaining olive oil into a large round baking pan and heat in a 250C oven.
Pour the batter into the hot oiled pan, it should be very thin.
Scatter rosemary leaves on top and bake for 20-25 minutes until golden and crispy at the edges.
Season with black pepper and cut into wedges to serve hot.

recipes.name: Trippa alla Romana
recipes.description: Roman-style tripe slow-simmered in a tomato and mint sauce, finished with Pecorino Romano. A traditional Saturday lunch dish in Rome.
instructions: Wash the tripe thoroughly and cut into thin strips.
Saute diced onion, carrot, and celery in olive oil until softened.
Add the tripe and white wine, cooking until the wine evaporates.
Add crushed tomatoes and enough water to cover, then simmer gently for 1 to 1.5 hours until tender.
Season with salt, pepper, and torn fresh mint leaves.
Serve hot with a generous grating of Pecorino Romano.

recipes.name: Cotoletta alla Milanese
recipes.description: A bone-in veal cutlet pounded thin, breaded in fine breadcrumbs, and fried in clarified butter until golden and crispy. Milan's most iconic dish.
instructions: Pound the veal chops between plastic wrap to an even 5mm thickness, keeping the bone attached.
Season with salt, dip in beaten egg, and coat thoroughly in fine breadcrumbs, pressing firmly.
Refrigerate the breaded cutlets for 15 minutes to set the coating.
Heat clarified butter in a large skillet until shimmering.
Fry the cutlets for 3-4 minutes per side until deep golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve with lemon wedges and arugula salad.

recipes.name: Semifreddo al Torroncino
recipes.description: A frozen Italian dessert halfway between gelato and mousse, studded with crushed nougat. No ice cream machine needed.
instructions: Whip the heavy cream to soft peaks and refrigerate.
Whisk egg yolks with half the sugar over a bain-marie until thick and pale, then cool.
Whip egg whites with remaining sugar to stiff peaks.
Chop the torrone nougat and toasted almonds into small pieces.
Fold the whipped cream into the egg yolk mixture, then fold in the egg whites.
Fold in the chopped torrone and pour into a lined loaf pan.
Freeze for at least 6 hours, then slice and serve drizzled with honey.

recipes.name: Pasta con le Sarde
recipes.description: A quintessential Sicilian pasta with fresh sardines, wild fennel, pine nuts, raisins, saffron, and toasted breadcrumbs. Sweet, savory, and complex.
instructions: Blanch fennel fronds in salted water, drain (reserve water), and chop finely.
Soak raisins in warm water and dissolve saffron in a tablespoon of warm water.
Saute diced onion in olive oil, add anchovies and stir until melted.
Add sardine fillets and cook gently for 5 minutes, breaking them up slightly.
Add fennel, pine nuts, drained raisins, and saffron water, cooking for 5 more minutes.
Cook bucatini in the fennel water until al dente, then toss with the sauce.
Toast breadcrumbs in a dry pan until golden and sprinkle over the finished pasta.

recipes.name: Panino con Porchetta
recipes.description: The quintessential Italian pork sandwich with sliced porchetta on a crusty rosetta roll. A beloved street food from Lazio and Umbria.
instructions: Slice the rosetta rolls in half.
Layer generous amounts of thinly sliced porchetta on the bottom half.
Add sliced provolone and a handful of arugula.
Season with a pinch of salt and close the sandwich.
Press gently and serve at room temperature.

recipes.name: Torta Caprese
recipes.description: A flourless chocolate and almond cake from the island of Capri. Dense, fudgy, and naturally gluten-free, with a crackly top.
instructions: Melt chocolate and butter together in a double boiler, then let cool slightly.
Separate eggs and whisk yolks with sugar until pale and thick.
Fold the melted chocolate mixture into the yolks, then fold in almond flour and salt.
Whip egg whites to stiff peaks and gently fold into the batter in two additions.
Pour into a greased and lined 23cm springform pan.
Bake at 170C for 30-35 minutes until the top is set but the center is still slightly soft.
Cool completely in the pan, then dust with powdered sugar before serving.

recipes.name: Salmon Nigiri Sushi
recipes.description: Hand-pressed sushi rice topped with fresh slices of salmon, brushed with a touch of soy sauce. A cornerstone of Edomae sushi tradition.
instructions: Rinse sushi rice until water runs clear, then cook with appropriate water ratio and let rest for 10 minutes.
Mix rice vinegar, sugar, and salt in a small saucepan over low heat until dissolved to make sushi-zu.
Transfer hot rice to a large wooden bowl (hangiri), drizzle sushi-zu over it, and fold gently with a rice paddle while fanning to cool.
Slice the salmon against the grain into pieces about 7cm long, 3cm wide, and 5mm thick.
Wet your hands with vinegared water, take about 20g of rice and form into an oval mound with gentle pressure.
Place a small dab of wasabi on the rice, lay the salmon slice on top, and press gently to shape.
Serve with soy sauce, pickled ginger, and additional wasabi on the side.

recipes.name: Spicy Tuna Maki Roll
recipes.description: Inside-out sushi roll filled with spicy tuna mixture and cucumber, coated in sesame seeds. A beloved maki variation combining heat and freshness.
instructions: Cook sushi rice and season with rice vinegar mixed with sugar and a pinch of salt, then cool.
Dice the tuna into small cubes and mix with sriracha and Japanese mayonnaise to make the spicy tuna filling.
Cut cucumber into long thin strips, removing the seedy center.
Place a nori sheet on a bamboo mat covered in plastic wrap, spread rice evenly, and sprinkle with sesame seeds.
Flip the nori so rice faces down, arrange spicy tuna and cucumber strips along the center.
Roll tightly using the bamboo mat, applying even pressure to form a compact cylinder.
Slice each roll into 8 pieces with a wet sharp knife and serve with soy sauce.

recipes.name: Chirashi Don
recipes.description: Scattered sushi bowl with assorted sashimi arranged over seasoned sushi rice, garnished with shiso and tamagoyaki. A festive and colorful one-bowl meal.
instructions: Cook sushi rice and season with rice vinegar, sugar, and salt mixture, then fan and cool to room temperature.
Slice salmon and tuna into thin sashimi pieces, and cut tamagoyaki into rectangular strips.
Slice cucumber thinly and prepare shiso leaves by washing and patting dry.
Divide the seasoned rice among four serving bowls.
Arrange the sashimi slices, shrimp, tamagoyaki, and cucumber decoratively on top of the rice.
Garnish with shiso leaves, nori strips, and pickled ginger.
Serve immediately with soy sauce and wasabi on the side.

recipes.name: Temaki (Hand Roll)
recipes.description: Cone-shaped nori hand rolls filled with sushi rice, fresh fish, and vegetables. An informal and fun way to enjoy sushi at home.
instructions: Cook and season sushi rice with rice vinegar, sugar, and salt, then cool to room temperature.
Slice tuna into long strips, avocado into thin wedges, and cucumber into matchstick-sized batons.
Cut each nori sheet in half to create half-sheets for rolling.
Hold a nori half-sheet in your palm, spread a thin layer of rice on the left third.
Place a shiso leaf, tuna strips, avocado, and cucumber diagonally across the rice.
Roll the nori into a cone shape, tucking the bottom corner in tightly.
Seal the edge with a grain of rice and serve immediately with soy sauce and wasabi.

recipes.name: Tonkotsu Ramen
recipes.description: Rich, creamy pork bone broth ramen simmered for hours until milky white, served with thin noodles, chashu pork, and soft-boiled egg. The iconic Hakata-style ramen.
instructions: Blanch pork bones in boiling water for 10 minutes, drain, rinse thoroughly, and scrub clean to remove impurities.
Place clean bones in a large stockpot, cover with fresh water, add crushed garlic and sliced ginger, and bring to a vigorous rolling boil.
Maintain a strong boil for 6-8 hours, adding water as needed to keep bones submerged, until broth is opaque and creamy.
Meanwhile, roll and tie pork belly, sear in a hot pan, then braise in soy sauce, sake, and mirin for 2 hours until tender.
Prepare soft-boiled eggs by cooking for 6.5 minutes, then marinate peeled eggs in the chashu braising liquid for at least 4 hours.
Strain the broth, season with salt and soy sauce to taste, and keep at a simmer.
Cook ramen noodles according to package directions, drain well, and place in bowls.
Ladle hot tonkotsu broth over noodles, top with sliced chashu, halved marinated egg, nori, and sliced green onions.

recipes.name: Shoyu Ramen
recipes.description: Clear soy sauce-based ramen with a refined chicken and dashi broth, topped with chashu, menma, and nori. A classic Tokyo-style ramen.
instructions: Simmer chicken carcass in water with ginger and leek trimmings for 3 hours, skimming impurities regularly.
Strain the broth through a fine mesh sieve and combine with dashi stock.
Prepare the tare by combining soy sauce, mirin, and sake in a saucepan, and bring to a brief boil.
Make soft-boiled eggs by cooking for 6.5 minutes and marinating in a soy-mirin mixture.
Cook ramen noodles until just al dente and drain well.
Place 2 tablespoons of tare in each bowl, ladle hot broth over it, and stir to combine.
Add noodles, then arrange chashu slices, halved egg, menma, nori, and sliced green onions on top.

recipes.name: Miso Ramen
recipes.description: Hearty ramen in a rich miso-based broth with ground pork, bean sprouts, corn, and butter. A warming specialty from Hokkaido.
instructions: Heat sesame oil in a large pot and stir-fry minced garlic and grated ginger until fragrant.
Add ground pork and cook until browned, breaking it into small crumbles.
Pour in chicken stock and bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Dissolve white and red miso paste into the broth using a ladle and strainer to avoid lumps.
Cook ramen noodles according to package directions and divide among four bowls.
Blanch bean sprouts briefly in boiling water and drain.
Ladle miso broth and pork over the noodles, top with bean sprouts, corn, a pat of butter, and sliced green onions.

recipes.name: Shio Ramen
recipes.description: Delicate salt-seasoned ramen with a light yet flavorful clear broth made from chicken and seafood. The oldest and most refined style of ramen.
instructions: Soak kombu and dried scallops in 1.5 liters of cold water for at least 1 hour.
Add chicken wings and bring to a gentle simmer over medium-low heat, skimming any scum that rises.
Simmer gently for 2 hours, keeping the broth clear by never allowing a full boil.
Strain the broth and season with salt and sake to create the shio tare.
Prepare soft-boiled eggs by boiling for 6.5 minutes, cooling, peeling, and halving.
Cook ramen noodles, drain, and place in bowls.
Ladle the clear shio broth over the noodles and top with chashu slices, bamboo shoots, halved egg, nori, and green onions.

recipes.name: Kitsune Udon
recipes.description: Thick udon noodles in a savory dashi broth topped with sweet simmered fried tofu (aburaage). A comforting Osaka classic named after the fox spirit.
instructions: Pour boiling water over aburaage to remove excess oil, then drain and gently squeeze dry.
Simmer aburaage in a mixture of dashi, soy sauce, mirin, and sugar for 15 minutes until sweet and well-seasoned.
Prepare the udon broth by combining remaining dashi with soy sauce and mirin, bringing to a gentle simmer.
Cook udon noodles according to package directions, drain, and rinse briefly under warm water.
Divide noodles among four bowls and ladle the hot broth over them.
Top each bowl with a piece of seasoned aburaage, sliced kamaboko, and chopped green onions.

recipes.name: Tempura Udon
recipes.description: Hearty udon noodles in a clear dashi broth crowned with crispy shrimp tempura. The contrast of hot broth and crispy tempura is irresistible.
instructions: Prepare udon broth by simmering dashi with soy sauce and mirin, keep warm.
Peel and devein shrimp, leaving the tail on, and make small cuts on the belly to prevent curling.
Make tempura batter by lightly mixing ice water, beaten egg, and flour, leaving lumps for crispiness.
Heat vegetable oil to 180C, dip shrimp in batter, and fry until golden and crispy, about 2 minutes.
Drain tempura on a wire rack to maintain crispiness.
Cook udon noodles, drain, and divide among bowls, then ladle hot broth over them.
Place crispy shrimp tempura on top of each bowl and garnish with sliced green onions.

recipes.name: Zaru Soba
recipes.description: Chilled buckwheat noodles served on a bamboo mat with a cold dipping sauce, wasabi, and green onions. A refreshing summer staple.
instructions: Prepare the mentsuyu dipping sauce by combining dashi, soy sauce, and mirin in a saucepan, bringing to a boil, then cooling completely and chilling.
Cook soba noodles in a large pot of boiling water according to package directions, stirring gently.
Drain and rinse noodles thoroughly under cold running water, rubbing gently to remove excess starch.
Arrange chilled noodles on bamboo mats or plates.
Serve with individual cups of cold mentsuyu, topped with finely sliced green onions and a small mound of wasabi.
Garnish noodles with thin strips of nori and instruct diners to dip noodles into the sauce before eating.

recipes.name: Kake Soba
recipes.description: Hot buckwheat noodles served in a simple, fragrant dashi broth. A warming and minimalist noodle dish enjoyed year-round.
instructions: Prepare the hot broth by bringing dashi stock to a simmer with soy sauce, mirin, and salt.
Cook soba noodles in a separate pot of boiling water until just tender.
Drain and rinse noodles briefly under warm water to remove excess starch while keeping them warm.
Divide noodles among four bowls.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles.
Garnish with sliced green onions and serve with shichimi togarashi on the side for sprinkling.

recipes.name: Yakisoba
recipes.description: Stir-fried noodles with pork, cabbage, and vegetables in a tangy Worcestershire-based sauce. A popular Japanese street food and festival favorite.
instructions: Slice pork belly into thin bite-sized pieces, shred cabbage, julienne carrot, and slice onion.
Heat vegetable oil in a large wok or frying pan over high heat.
Stir-fry pork until browned, then add onion, carrot, and cabbage, cooking until slightly softened.
Add yakisoba noodles to the pan, loosening them with a splash of water if needed.
Pour yakisoba sauce over the noodles and toss everything together until evenly coated.
Serve on plates topped with pickled red ginger, aonori flakes, and bonito flakes.

recipes.name: Onigiri (Rice Balls)
recipes.description: Triangular rice balls filled with umeboshi, salmon, or tuna mayo, wrapped in nori. Japan's ultimate portable comfort food.
instructions: Cook rice and let it cool until just warm enough to handle.
Mix drained tuna with Japanese mayonnaise for the tuna mayo filling.
Wet your hands with salted water to prevent sticking.
Take a handful of rice, make an indentation in the center, and place your chosen filling inside.
Shape the rice into a firm triangle by pressing gently with both hands, rotating to form three flat sides.
Wrap the base of each onigiri with a strip of nori and serve.

recipes.name: Oyakodon
recipes.description: Chicken and egg simmered in a sweet soy-dashi sauce and served over hot rice. The name means parent and child, referring to the chicken and egg.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm.
Cut chicken thigh into bite-sized pieces and slice onion into thin half-moons.
Combine dashi, soy sauce, mirin, and sugar in a small lidded skillet and bring to a simmer.
Add sliced onion and simmer for 3 minutes until softened.
Add chicken pieces and cook for 5-6 minutes until chicken is cooked through.
Beat eggs lightly, pour two-thirds over the chicken, cover, and cook for 30 seconds.
Add the remaining egg, cover again, and cook for another 30 seconds until eggs are just set but still custardy.
Slide the mixture over bowls of hot rice and garnish with mitsuba or sliced green onion.

recipes.name: Katsudon
recipes.description: Crispy breaded pork cutlet simmered with egg and onion in a savory dashi sauce over rice. The ultimate Japanese comfort bowl.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm. Season pork cutlets with salt and pepper.
Dredge pork in flour, dip in beaten egg, and coat thoroughly in panko breadcrumbs.
Deep fry at 170C for 6-7 minutes until golden brown and cooked through, then drain and slice into strips.
In a small skillet, combine dashi, soy sauce, mirin, and sugar with sliced onion and simmer for 3 minutes.
Place sliced tonkatsu on top of the simmering onion mixture.
Pour beaten egg over the tonkatsu, cover with a lid, and cook for 1 minute until egg is just set.
Slide the katsu-egg mixture over bowls of hot rice and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Gyudon
recipes.description: Thinly sliced beef and onion simmered in a sweet soy sauce and served over steamed rice. A popular fast-food staple across Japan.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm.
Slice onion into thin half-moons and grate the ginger.
Combine dashi, soy sauce, mirin, sake, and sugar in a saucepan and bring to a simmer.
Add sliced onion and grated ginger, cooking for 5 minutes until onion is soft.
Add thinly sliced beef and cook for 5-7 minutes, skimming any foam.
Serve the beef and onion with its sauce over bowls of hot steamed rice.
Garnish with pickled red ginger on the side.

recipes.name: Tendon (Tempura Rice Bowl)
recipes.description: Crispy assorted tempura served over rice and drizzled with a sweet tentsuyu sauce. A satisfying bowl that celebrates the art of tempura.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm. Prepare tentsuyu sauce by simmering dashi, soy sauce, and mirin together.
Slice sweet potato and eggplant thinly, peel and devein shrimp leaving tails on.
Make tempura batter by lightly combining ice water, egg, and flour without overmixing.
Heat oil to 180C, dip vegetables and shrimp in batter, and fry in batches until crispy and light golden.
Drain tempura briefly on a wire rack.
Place hot rice in bowls, arrange tempura on top, and drizzle generously with warm tentsuyu sauce.
Serve immediately while the tempura is still crispy.

recipes.name: Japanese Curry Rice (Kare Raisu)
recipes.description: Thick, savory Japanese curry with beef, potatoes, carrots, and onions served over steamed rice. A beloved home-cooking dish adapted from British curry.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm.
Cut beef into cubes, peel and cut potatoes and carrots into large chunks, and slice onions.
Heat oil in a large pot and brown the beef on all sides over high heat.
Add onions and cook until translucent, then add carrots and potatoes.
Pour in water, bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 30 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Turn off heat, break curry roux into the pot and stir until fully dissolved.
Simmer on low heat for another 10 minutes until sauce thickens, stirring occasionally.
Serve curry alongside steamed rice with fukujinzuke on the side.

recipes.name: Omurice
recipes.description: Ketchup-flavored chicken fried rice wrapped in a silky soft omelette, topped with more ketchup or demi-glace. A yoshoku favorite loved by all ages.
instructions: Dice chicken thigh and onion into small pieces.
Heat oil in a frying pan, cook chicken until done, then add onion and green peas.
Add cooked rice and stir-fry, then mix in ketchup until the rice is evenly coated and slightly caramelized.
Divide the ketchup rice into four portions and shape each into an oval mound on plates.
For each serving, beat 2 eggs with a pinch of salt, melt butter in a non-stick pan, and pour in the egg.
Swirl the pan to create a thin, creamy omelette, then drape it over the rice mound.
Drizzle extra ketchup on top in a decorative pattern and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Takikomi Gohan
recipes.description: Seasoned mixed rice cooked with vegetables, chicken, and mushrooms in a soy-dashi broth. A fragrant autumn rice dish bursting with umami.
instructions: Rinse rice and soak in water for 30 minutes, then drain.
Cut chicken into small pieces, slice shiitake caps, julienne carrot and gobo, and tear konnyaku into small pieces.
Place rice in a rice cooker and add dashi, soy sauce, sake, and mirin.
Arrange all the prepared ingredients on top of the rice without stirring.
Cook using the regular rice cooker setting.
Once done, gently fold all ingredients together with a rice paddle and let steam for 10 minutes.
Serve in bowls garnished with mitsuba or sliced green onion.

recipes.name: Yakitori
recipes.description: Skewered chicken pieces grilled over charcoal and glazed with sweet tare sauce or seasoned with shio salt. The quintessential Japanese bar snack.
instructions: Soak bamboo skewers in water for 30 minutes to prevent burning.
Cut chicken thigh into bite-sized cubes and cut leek into 3cm segments.
Thread chicken and leek alternately onto skewers.
Prepare tare sauce by combining soy sauce, mirin, sake, and sugar in a small pan, simmering until thickened and glossy.
Grill skewers over high heat, turning frequently, for 8-10 minutes.
Brush with tare sauce during the last few minutes of grilling, applying 2-3 coats.
Serve immediately, sprinkled with shichimi togarashi if desired.

recipes.name: Teriyaki Chicken
recipes.description: Juicy chicken thighs glazed in a glossy sweet soy teriyaki sauce until caramelized. A universally loved Japanese home-cooking classic.
instructions: Score the chicken thighs lightly on the flesh side for even cooking.
Heat oil in a skillet over medium-high heat and place chicken skin-side down.
Cook for 7-8 minutes until skin is golden and crispy, then flip and cook for 3 more minutes.
Drain excess fat from the pan, then add soy sauce, mirin, sake, and sugar.
Simmer while spooning the sauce over the chicken until it reduces to a thick, glossy glaze.
Slice the chicken and serve over steamed rice, drizzling remaining sauce on top.

recipes.name: Teriyaki Salmon
recipes.description: Salmon fillets pan-seared and glazed with a sweet and savory teriyaki sauce. A quick weeknight dish that highlights the richness of salmon.
instructions: Pat salmon fillets dry and season lightly with salt.
Mix soy sauce, mirin, sake, and sugar to make the teriyaki sauce.
Heat oil in a non-stick skillet over medium-high heat.
Sear salmon skin-side up for 3 minutes, then flip and cook for 2 more minutes.
Pour teriyaki sauce into the pan and simmer, spooning it over the salmon as it thickens.
Serve salmon with the glaze, garnished with sliced green onions and sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Yakiniku (Japanese BBQ)
recipes.description: Thinly sliced marinated beef grilled at the table over high heat, dipped in tare and lemon juice. A social and interactive dining experience.
instructions: Combine soy sauce, sesame oil, minced garlic, sugar, chopped green onions, and sesame seeds for the marinade.
Marinate the thinly sliced beef for at least 30 minutes in the refrigerator.
Prepare dipping sauces: tare (soy-based) and lemon juice in separate small dishes.
Heat a grill plate, tabletop grill, or cast iron skillet to very high heat.
Grill the marinated beef slices quickly, about 30-60 seconds per side.
Serve grilled meat with lettuce wraps, steamed rice, dipping sauces, and lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Unagi Kabayaki
recipes.description: Grilled freshwater eel basted with a rich sweet soy kabayaki sauce, served over rice. A prized summer delicacy believed to provide stamina.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm.
Prepare kabayaki sauce by simmering soy sauce, mirin, sake, and sugar until thickened to a syrupy consistency.
If using pre-cooked unagi, warm the fillets by steaming for 5 minutes to soften them.
Grill or broil the unagi fillets skin-side down, basting with kabayaki sauce every minute.
Turn once and continue basting until the eel is glazed with 3-4 coats and caramelized.
Serve the glazed unagi over bowls of hot rice, drizzle with extra sauce, and sprinkle with sansho pepper.

recipes.name: Shrimp and Vegetable Tempura
recipes.description: Light, crispy battered shrimp and seasonal vegetables deep-fried to perfection. The hallmark of Japanese frying technique with an ethereal, shatter-crisp coating.
instructions: Prepare tentsuyu dipping sauce by simmering dashi, soy sauce, and mirin, then grate daikon for garnish.
Peel and devein shrimp, slice sweet potato and lotus root thinly on a diagonal.
Make tempura batter by gently stirring ice water, egg, and sifted flour together, leaving lumps for extra crispiness.
Heat oil to 180C, lightly dust ingredients in flour, dip in batter, and fry vegetables first, then shrimp.
Fry in small batches for 2-3 minutes until pale golden and crispy, maintaining oil temperature.
Drain on a wire rack and serve immediately with tentsuyu dipping sauce and grated daikon.

recipes.name: Tonkatsu
recipes.description: Thick pork loin cutlet breaded in panko and deep-fried until the crust is shattering and golden. Served with shredded cabbage and tangy tonkatsu sauce.
instructions: Score the fat edge of each pork cutlet to prevent curling and season both sides with salt and pepper.
Set up a breading station: flour, beaten egg, and panko in separate shallow dishes.
Coat each cutlet in flour, dip in egg, then press firmly into panko to create a thick even coating.
Heat oil to 170C and carefully lower cutlets in, frying for 5-6 minutes until deep golden brown.
Remove and let rest on a wire rack for 2 minutes, then slice into strips.
Serve on a plate with finely shredded cabbage, lemon wedges, tonkatsu sauce, and karashi mustard.

recipes.name: Karaage (Japanese Fried Chicken)
recipes.description: Bite-sized chicken marinated in soy sauce, ginger, and garlic, coated in potato starch and fried twice for extra crunch. Japan's favorite fried chicken.
instructions: Cut chicken thigh into bite-sized pieces, about 3-4cm each.
Marinate in soy sauce, sake, grated ginger, and minced garlic for at least 30 minutes.
Drain excess marinade and coat each piece thoroughly in potato starch.
Heat oil to 160C and fry chicken in batches for 3-4 minutes, then remove and rest for 2 minutes.
Increase oil temperature to 190C and fry again for 1-2 minutes until extra crispy and dark golden.
Drain on a wire rack and serve with lemon wedges and Japanese mayonnaise on the side.

recipes.name: Korokke (Japanese Croquettes)
recipes.description: Creamy mashed potato and ground meat filling encased in a crispy panko shell. A beloved yoshoku dish found in every Japanese bakery and bento.
instructions: Boil potatoes until tender, drain, and mash while still hot.
Saute finely diced onion in butter until golden, add ground beef, and cook until browned.
Combine mashed potatoes with the meat mixture, season with salt and pepper, and mix well.
Shape the mixture into oval patties, then chill in the refrigerator for 15 minutes to firm up.
Coat each patty in flour, dip in beaten egg, then press into panko breadcrumbs.
Deep fry at 170C for 3-4 minutes until golden brown and crispy on all sides.
Serve hot with tonkatsu sauce and shredded cabbage.

recipes.name: Ebi Fry (Fried Shrimp)
recipes.description: Jumbo shrimp butterflied and coated in panko breadcrumbs, fried until golden and crunchy. A staple of Japanese set meals and bento boxes.
instructions: Peel and devein shrimp, leaving tails on, and make small cuts on the belly to straighten them.
Butterfly each shrimp by cutting along the back without cutting all the way through, then flatten gently.
Season shrimp with salt and pepper, then coat in flour, dip in beaten egg, and press into panko.
Heat oil to 175C and fry shrimp for 2-3 minutes until golden and cooked through.
Drain on a wire rack.
Serve on a plate with finely shredded cabbage, lemon wedges, tonkatsu sauce, and tartar sauce.

recipes.name: Miso Soup
recipes.description: Essential Japanese soup made with dashi stock and miso paste, with tofu and wakame seaweed. Served at nearly every Japanese meal.
instructions: Bring dashi stock to a gentle simmer in a saucepan.
Soak dried wakame in water for 5 minutes until rehydrated, then drain.
Cut tofu into small 1.5cm cubes.
Reduce heat to low, place miso paste in a ladle, and dissolve it into the dashi by stirring with chopsticks.
Add tofu and wakame to the soup, heat gently without boiling to preserve the miso flavor.
Serve in bowls garnished with finely sliced green onions.

recipes.name: Tonjiru (Pork Miso Soup)
recipes.description: Hearty miso soup loaded with pork and root vegetables. A warming, substantial soup that is a meal in itself during cold months.
instructions: Cut pork into bite-sized pieces, and chop daikon, carrot, potato, gobo, and konnyaku into small pieces.
Heat sesame oil in a pot and stir-fry pork until lightly browned.
Add all the vegetables and konnyaku, stir-frying briefly.
Pour in dashi stock, bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Remove from heat, dissolve miso paste into the soup using a ladle.
Serve hot, garnished with sliced green onions.

recipes.name: Oden
recipes.description: Assorted ingredients simmered in a light soy-dashi broth for hours until deeply flavored. A beloved winter hot pot found at convenience stores across Japan.
instructions: Peel daikon and cut into thick rounds, score a shallow cross on one face, and par-boil for 10 minutes.
Score konnyaku in a crosshatch pattern, cut into triangles, and blanch briefly.
Pour boiling water over atsuage to remove excess oil.
Combine dashi, soy sauce, and mirin in a large pot and bring to a gentle simmer.
Add daikon first and simmer for 30 minutes, then add remaining ingredients.
Continue simmering on very low heat for at least 1 hour, the longer the better for flavor.
Serve hot from the pot with karashi mustard on the side for dipping.

recipes.name: Chawanmushi
recipes.description: Silky savory egg custard steamed with shrimp, chicken, and ginkgo nuts in a delicate dashi base. An elegant and delicate appetizer course.
instructions: Gently beat eggs without creating foam, then mix with cooled dashi, soy sauce, mirin, and salt.
Strain the egg mixture through a fine sieve for a perfectly smooth custard.
Cut chicken into small pieces, devein shrimp, and slice shiitake caps.
Divide chicken, shrimp, mushroom, and ginkgo nuts among four chawanmushi cups.
Gently pour the egg mixture into each cup, removing any surface bubbles with a skewer.
Cover each cup with foil, steam over medium-low heat for 15-18 minutes until custard is just set.
Garnish with mitsuba and serve warm.

recipes.name: Sukiyaki
recipes.description: Thinly sliced beef and vegetables simmered in a sweet soy broth at the table, dipped in raw beaten egg. A festive communal hot pot.
instructions: Prepare the warishita sauce by combining soy sauce, sugar, sake, and mirin in a bowl.
Cut tofu into cubes, slice cabbage, cut green onions into lengths, and rinse shirataki noodles.
Heat a cast iron pot (or sukiyaki pan) at the table and melt beef suet to coat the surface.
Sear a few slices of beef, add some warishita sauce, then begin adding vegetables and tofu.
Simmer all ingredients together, adding more sauce as needed, keeping ingredients in separate groups.
Each diner beats a raw egg in a small bowl and dips the cooked ingredients before eating.
Continue adding ingredients and sauce throughout the meal as items are consumed.

recipes.name: Shabu Shabu
recipes.description: Paper-thin slices of beef swished briefly in kombu dashi broth, then dipped in ponzu or sesame sauce. An elegant and healthy hot pot.
instructions: Soak kombu in water in a hot pot for at least 30 minutes to make a gentle broth base.
Arrange sliced beef, cut vegetables, and tofu decoratively on platters.
Prepare dipping sauces in individual bowls: ponzu with grated daikon and sesame sauce.
Heat the kombu broth at the table until just simmering, removing the kombu before it boils.
Each diner picks up a slice of beef with chopsticks and swishes it in the broth for a few seconds.
Dip cooked beef and vegetables in your preferred sauce before eating.
At the end of the meal, cook udon noodles in the enriched broth as a finishing course.

recipes.name: Nikujaga (Meat and Potato Stew)
recipes.description: Tender beef, potatoes, and onions simmered in a sweet soy-dashi broth. Japan's quintessential home-cooked comfort food, a taste of mother's cooking.
instructions: Cut potatoes into large chunks, slice onion into wedges, and cut carrot into rolling chunks.
Heat oil in a pot and stir-fry beef until it changes color.
Add onion, carrot, and potato, stir-frying briefly to coat with oil.
Add dashi, sake, and sugar, bring to a boil, and skim any scum from the surface.
Add soy sauce and mirin, cover with a drop lid (otoshibuta), and simmer for 20-25 minutes.
Add rinsed shirataki noodles in the last 5 minutes of cooking.
Let rest for 10 minutes before serving to allow flavors to absorb into the potatoes.

recipes.name: Edamame
recipes.description: Young soybeans boiled in salted water and served in the pod as a snack. The classic accompaniment to cold beer in Japan.
instructions: Bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil.
Add a generous amount of salt to the boiling water.
Add frozen edamame and cook for 4-5 minutes until tender.
Drain and toss with additional salt to taste.
Serve warm or at room temperature, squeezing the beans from the pods to eat.

recipes.name: Gyoza (Japanese Dumplings)
recipes.description: Pan-fried pork and cabbage dumplings with crispy bottoms and juicy filling, dipped in soy-vinegar-chili oil. Addictively crispy and savory.
instructions: Finely mince cabbage, salt it, and squeeze out excess moisture in a clean towel.
Combine ground pork, cabbage, chopped nira, minced garlic, grated ginger, soy sauce, and sesame oil.
Mix the filling vigorously in one direction until it becomes sticky and cohesive.
Place a spoonful of filling in each wrapper, wet the edges, and fold into pleated crescent shapes.
Heat oil in a non-stick skillet, arrange gyoza in a single layer, and cook until bottoms are golden.
Add water to the skillet to come 1/3 up the gyoza, cover, and steam for 5 minutes until water evaporates.
Serve with a dipping sauce of soy sauce, rice vinegar, and chili oil.

recipes.name: Takoyaki (Octopus Balls)
recipes.description: Crispy-outside, creamy-inside ball-shaped snacks filled with diced octopus, battered and cooked in a special molded pan. The iconic Osaka street food.
instructions: Mix flour, eggs, and dashi stock to make a thin, runny batter and let it rest for 15 minutes.
Dice octopus into small cubes and chop green onions and pickled ginger finely.
Heat a takoyaki pan and oil each mold generously.
Fill each mold with batter, add a piece of octopus, green onion, ginger, and tenkasu to each.
Cook until the edges set, then use a pick to turn each ball 90 degrees, tucking in excess batter.
Continue turning until all sides are evenly golden and the shape is round.
Serve topped with takoyaki sauce, mayonnaise, bonito flakes, and aonori.

recipes.name: Okonomiyaki
recipes.description: Savory Japanese pancake loaded with cabbage, pork belly, and topped with a web of sauce and mayonnaise. Osaka's beloved griddle-cooked comfort food.
instructions: Mix flour and dashi stock to form a base batter, then fold in beaten eggs.
Shred cabbage finely and add to the batter along with tenkasu and chopped green onions.
Heat a griddle or large skillet with oil over medium heat.
Pour a quarter of the batter into a round shape and lay slices of pork belly on top.
Cook for 5-6 minutes until the bottom is golden, then carefully flip and cook for another 5 minutes.
Flip once more, brush generously with okonomiyaki sauce, and drizzle with mayonnaise.
Top with bonito flakes and aonori, then serve immediately while hot.

recipes.name: Tamagoyaki (Japanese Rolled Omelette)
recipes.description: Sweet and savory layered egg omelette rolled in a rectangular pan. A staple of Japanese breakfast and bento boxes with its signature spiral pattern.
instructions: Beat eggs gently and mix in dashi, sugar, soy sauce, and mirin without creating foam.
Strain the mixture through a sieve for a smooth texture.
Heat a rectangular tamagoyaki pan over medium-low heat and oil it lightly.
Pour a thin layer of egg mixture into the pan, let it set slightly, then roll it to one side.
Oil the empty portion of the pan, pour another thin layer, lifting the rolled egg to let it flow underneath.
Roll again incorporating the new layer, and repeat until all egg mixture is used, building up layers.
Shape with a bamboo mat if desired, let rest briefly, then slice into pieces and serve.

recipes.name: Sunomono (Cucumber Vinegar Salad)
recipes.description: Thinly sliced cucumber dressed in a tangy sweet rice vinegar sauce. A refreshing palate cleanser that accompanies many Japanese meals.
instructions: Slice cucumbers paper-thin using a mandoline, sprinkle with salt, and let sit for 10 minutes.
Soak dried wakame in water for 5 minutes until rehydrated, then drain.
Squeeze excess moisture from the salted cucumber slices.
Mix rice vinegar, sugar, and soy sauce until sugar dissolves to make the amazu dressing.
Toss cucumber and wakame with the amazu dressing.
Serve chilled in small dishes, garnished with sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Agedashi Tofu
recipes.description: Deep-fried tofu in a light starch coating served in a warm dashi-soy broth with grated daikon and ginger. Crispy outside, silky inside.
instructions: Drain tofu and press between paper towels for 15 minutes to remove excess moisture.
Cut tofu into large cubes and coat evenly in potato starch.
Prepare the tentsuyu sauce by heating dashi, soy sauce, and mirin together.
Grate daikon and ginger separately for toppings.
Heat oil to 180C and fry tofu until golden and crispy on all sides, about 3-4 minutes.
Place fried tofu in serving bowls, pour warm tentsuyu sauce around it.
Top with grated daikon, grated ginger, sliced green onions, and bonito flakes.

recipes.name: Hiyayakko (Cold Tofu)
recipes.description: Chilled silken tofu served with grated ginger, green onions, and bonito flakes drizzled with soy sauce. A simple, cooling summer dish.
instructions: Keep silken tofu chilled until ready to serve.
Cut the tofu block into four portions and place each on a small plate or in a dish.
Grate fresh ginger finely.
Thinly slice green onions.
Top each tofu portion with grated ginger, sliced green onions, bonito flakes, and sesame seeds.
Drizzle soy sauce over the top just before eating.

recipes.name: Kinpira Gobo
recipes.description: Burdock root and carrot stir-fried in a sweet soy glaze with a hint of chili. A classic Japanese side dish with a satisfying crunch.
instructions: Scrub gobo and shave into thin matchstick-sized strips, soaking in vinegared water to prevent browning.
Julienne the carrot into similar sized strips.
Heat sesame oil in a skillet over medium-high heat with sliced dried chili.
Drain gobo and stir-fry with carrot for 3-4 minutes until slightly tender.
Add soy sauce, mirin, and sugar, continue stir-frying until the liquid evaporates and vegetables are glazed.
Sprinkle with sesame seeds and serve warm or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Tsukemono (Quick Pickled Vegetables)
recipes.description: Lightly salted and pressed Japanese pickled vegetables served as an accompaniment to rice. A fundamental element of the traditional Japanese table.
instructions: Cut cucumber into irregular chunks, slice napa cabbage into strips, and thinly slice daikon.
Place all vegetables in a bowl and sprinkle with salt, tossing to coat evenly.
Cut kombu into thin strips and slice dried chili, adding both to the vegetables.
Place a plate on top and weigh it down with something heavy, pressing the vegetables.
Refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or overnight for deeper flavor.
Squeeze out excess liquid before serving as a side dish with rice.

recipes.name: Mochi (Rice Cakes)
recipes.description: Soft, chewy glutinous rice cakes made from pounded sweet rice flour. A traditional Japanese confection enjoyed on special occasions and as everyday sweets.
instructions: Mix mochiko flour, sugar, and water in a microwave-safe bowl until smooth.
Cover and microwave in 1-minute intervals, stirring between each, for about 3 minutes total until translucent and very sticky.
Dust a work surface generously with potato starch.
Turn out the hot mochi dough onto the starch and dust the top as well.
Pull off small portions and flatten into rounds, place a ball of anko in the center.
Pinch the edges closed, round into a smooth ball, and place seam-side down.
Serve at room temperature within the same day for the best texture.

recipes.name: Dorayaki
recipes.description: Sweet red bean paste sandwiched between two fluffy honey pancakes. A beloved Japanese confection famously associated with the character Doraemon.
instructions: Beat eggs with sugar and honey until light and fluffy.
Sift flour and baking powder together, fold into the egg mixture gently.
Add water and mirin to thin the batter to a thick but pourable consistency, then rest for 15 minutes.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium-low heat and pour small rounds of batter (about 8cm diameter).
Cook until bubbles appear on the surface and the edges are set, then flip and cook briefly.
Pair up pancakes by size, spread a generous layer of anko on one, and sandwich with the other.
Serve at room temperature, wrapped in plastic briefly to keep moist.

recipes.name: Matcha Ice Cream
recipes.description: Creamy green tea ice cream made with premium matcha powder. A popular Japanese dessert with an earthy, bittersweet flavor.
instructions: Sift matcha powder and dissolve in 2 tablespoons of hot water to form a smooth paste.
Heat milk and cream together in a saucepan until just steaming.
Whisk egg yolks with sugar until pale, then slowly pour in the hot cream while whisking constantly.
Return to the saucepan and cook over low heat, stirring constantly until the custard coats the back of a spoon.
Remove from heat, whisk in the matcha paste until fully incorporated, and strain through a sieve.
Cool the mixture completely, then churn in an ice cream maker according to manufacturer's instructions.
Transfer to a freezer container and freeze for at least 4 hours until firm.

recipes.name: Taiyaki
recipes.description: Fish-shaped cakes with a crispy shell filled with sweet red bean paste. A nostalgic Japanese street snack cooked in a special fish-shaped mold.
instructions: Sift together flour, baking powder, and sugar into a mixing bowl.
Add beaten egg and water, mixing until you have a smooth, thin batter.
Heat a taiyaki mold (fish-shaped waffle iron) and brush with oil.
Pour batter into each mold cavity, filling about halfway.
Add a generous spoonful of red bean paste in the center of each.
Add more batter on top to cover the filling, close the mold, and cook for 3-4 minutes per side.
Serve warm when the shell is crispiest.

recipes.name: Daifuku
recipes.description: Soft mochi wrapped around sweet red bean paste filling. A traditional wagashi confection with a pillowy, stretchy exterior.
instructions: Form the red bean paste into 8 equal balls and set aside.
Mix mochiko, sugar, and water in a microwave-safe bowl until smooth.
Microwave in 30-second intervals, stirring each time, until the mochi is translucent and stretchy.
Dust a work surface with potato starch and turn out the hot mochi.
Divide into 8 portions, flatten each into a disc, and place an anko ball in the center.
Stretch the mochi around the filling, pinching to seal, and roll into a smooth ball.
Dust each daifuku lightly with potato starch and serve within the same day.

recipes.name: Yokan (Sweet Bean Jelly)
recipes.description: Firm jellied dessert made from red bean paste and agar, sliced into elegant bars. A traditional wagashi served with green tea.
instructions: Dissolve agar powder in water in a saucepan and bring to a boil, stirring constantly.
Add sugar and stir until completely dissolved.
Add the smooth red bean paste and a pinch of salt, mixing until fully combined.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, for 5 minutes until the mixture thickens slightly.
Pour into a rectangular mold lined with plastic wrap and smooth the surface.
Cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 2 hours until firmly set.
Unmold and slice into elegant rectangular bars to serve with green tea.

recipes.name: Saba Shioyaki (Salt-Grilled Mackerel)
recipes.description: Whole mackerel fillets salted and grilled until the skin is blistered and crispy. A staple of traditional Japanese breakfast and teishoku set meals.
instructions: Sprinkle mackerel fillets generously with salt on both sides and let rest for 30 minutes to draw out moisture.
Pat the fillets dry with paper towels to remove released moisture.
Preheat the broiler or grill to high heat.
Grill skin-side up for 5-6 minutes until the skin is blistered and charred, then flip and cook for 3-4 minutes.
Grate daikon radish finely for oroshi (garnish).
Serve the grilled mackerel with a mound of grated daikon, lemon wedge, and a drizzle of soy sauce.

recipes.name: Natto Gohan
recipes.description: Fermented soybeans stirred until sticky and stringy, served over hot rice with mustard and soy sauce. A polarizing but nutritious everyday Japanese breakfast.
instructions: Cook rice and divide into two bowls while still hot.
Open the natto package and add the included mustard and soy sauce packets, or use your own.
Stir the natto vigorously with chopsticks for 30-50 strokes until very stringy and foamy.
Finely slice the green onion.
Place the stirred natto on top of the hot rice.
Garnish with sliced green onions and serve immediately, mixing into the rice as you eat.

recipes.name: Kakiage (Mixed Vegetable Tempura Fritter)
recipes.description: A crispy tempura fritter made from julienned vegetables and small shrimp fried together into a cohesive disc. A rustic tempura style served on rice or with soba.
instructions: Julienne onion, carrot, and gobo into thin strips and cut mitsuba into short lengths.
Toss the vegetables and shrimp with a tablespoon of flour to lightly coat.
Make a thin tempura batter by mixing egg, ice water, and remaining flour lightly, leaving lumps.
Combine the floured vegetables with just enough batter to bind them together.
Heat oil to 170C, and carefully slide spoonfuls of the mixture into the oil, pressing into flat discs.
Fry for 3-4 minutes until golden and crispy, flipping once.
Serve with a tentsuyu dipping sauce made from dashi, soy sauce, and mirin.

recipes.name: Japanese Hambagu (Hamburg Steak)
recipes.description: Juicy meat patties made with beef and pork mixture, served with a rich demi-glace sauce. A yoshoku classic that is Japan's answer to the hamburger steak.
instructions: Finely dice onion, saute in butter until golden and translucent, then cool completely.
Soak panko in milk until softened.
Combine ground beef, ground pork, cooled onion, soaked panko, egg, salt, pepper, and nutmeg.
Knead the mixture vigorously until sticky and cohesive, then shape into four oval patties, pressing out air.
Heat oil in a skillet, sear patties on high heat for 2 minutes per side, then add a splash of water, cover, and steam-cook on low for 8-10 minutes.
Remove patties, then make the sauce in the same pan by combining ketchup and Worcestershire sauce, simmering briefly.
Serve patties with the sauce drizzled over, alongside steamed rice and a simple salad.

recipes.name: Hayashi Rice
recipes.description: Thinly sliced beef and mushrooms in a rich demi-glace tomato sauce served over rice. A comforting yoshoku stew often compared to beef stroganoff.
instructions: Cook rice and keep warm.
Slice onions thinly and slice mushrooms.
Melt butter in a pot over medium heat, add onions, and cook slowly until deeply caramelized, about 15 minutes.
Add sliced beef and cook until just browned, then add mushrooms and stir briefly.
Pour in red wine and let it reduce by half.
Add water, demi-glace sauce, ketchup, and Worcestershire sauce, stirring to combine.
Simmer for 15-20 minutes until the sauce is rich and thickened.
Serve the hayashi sauce alongside steamed rice on a plate.

recipes.name: Matcha Warabi Mochi
recipes.description: Soft, jiggly bracken starch confection dusted with matcha and kinako soybean powder. A delicate and unique wagashi with a melt-in-your-mouth texture.
instructions: Mix warabi mochiko, sugar, and water in a saucepan until no lumps remain.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon, until the mixture becomes translucent and very thick.
Continue stirring vigorously for 2-3 more minutes until the dough pulls away from the pan cleanly.
Combine kinako and matcha powder in a shallow dish.
Transfer the hot mochi to the kinako-matcha mixture and cut or tear into bite-sized pieces using wet spoons.
Roll each piece in the powder to coat thoroughly.
Serve with kuromitsu drizzled on top for extra sweetness.

recipes.name: Bulgogi
recipes.description: Thinly sliced marinated beef grilled or stir-fried with a sweet and savory soy sauce marinade. One of Korea's most iconic dishes.
instructions: Combine soy sauce, sesame oil, sugar, minced garlic, grated Asian pear, rice wine, and black pepper in a large bowl to make the marinade.
Add the thinly sliced beef to the marinade and mix well. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Add sliced onion and green onions to the marinated beef and toss together.
Heat a large skillet or grill pan over high heat until very hot.
Cook the beef in batches without overcrowding, about 2-3 minutes per side until caramelized.
Garnish with sesame seeds and serve with steamed rice and lettuce wraps.

recipes.name: Galbi (Beef Short Ribs)
recipes.description: Grilled marinated beef short ribs with a rich, sweet soy glaze. A beloved Korean BBQ centerpiece for gatherings.
instructions: Score the meat between the bones on each short rib piece to help the marinade penetrate.
Soak the ribs in cold water for 30 minutes to draw out blood, then drain and pat dry.
Mix soy sauce, brown sugar, sesame oil, garlic, grated pear, rice wine, ginger, and black pepper for the marinade.
Coat the ribs thoroughly in the marinade and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat. Remove ribs from marinade, letting excess drip off.
Grill ribs for 3-4 minutes per side until charred and cooked through.
Garnish with green onions and sesame seeds. Serve immediately with ssamjang and lettuce.

recipes.name: Samgyeopsal (Grilled Pork Belly)
recipes.description: Thick slices of unseasoned pork belly grilled at the table and wrapped in lettuce with garlic, ssamjang, and kimchi.
instructions: Slice pork belly into 1cm thick pieces. Keep unseason for authentic preparation.
Prepare lettuce leaves, perilla leaves, sliced garlic, green chili peppers, ssamjang, and kimchi as accompaniments.
Mix sesame oil with a pinch of coarse salt in a small dipping dish.
Heat a grill pan or tabletop grill over high heat until very hot.
Grill pork belly slices for 3-4 minutes per side until golden and crispy, cutting with scissors as they cook.
Grill garlic slices and kimchi alongside the pork for extra flavor.
Wrap grilled pork in lettuce and perilla leaves with garlic, ssamjang, and kimchi. Eat in one bite.

recipes.name: Dakgalbi (Spicy Stir-Fried Chicken)
recipes.description: Chicken pieces stir-fried with vegetables in a spicy gochugaru and gochujang sauce, often cooked on a large flat grill.
instructions: Combine gochugaru, gochujang, soy sauce, sugar, minced garlic, and sesame oil to make the sauce.
Marinate the cubed chicken thighs in half the sauce for at least 30 minutes.
Heat a large flat pan or skillet over medium-high heat with a drizzle of oil.
Arrange sweet potato slices on the pan first, then add the marinated chicken on top.
Add cabbage, rice cakes, and the remaining sauce. Stir-fry everything together for 15-20 minutes.
Add green onions and perilla leaves in the last 2 minutes of cooking.
Serve directly from the pan with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Bossam (Boiled Pork Wraps)
recipes.description: Tender boiled pork belly sliced and served with salted napa cabbage wraps, radish salad, and raw oysters.
instructions: Place pork belly in a large pot with doenjang, garlic, ginger, green onions, black peppercorns, and enough water to cover.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 1.5 hours until the pork is fork-tender.
While pork cooks, salt napa cabbage leaves and let them wilt for 30 minutes, then rinse and squeeze dry.
Make radish salad by tossing julienned radish with gochugaru, fish sauce, sugar, and a splash of rice wine.
Remove cooked pork from the broth and let rest for 10 minutes before slicing into 5mm thick pieces.
Arrange sliced pork on a platter with salted cabbage, radish salad, and saeujeot on the side.
To eat, place pork on a cabbage leaf, add radish salad and saeujeot, wrap, and enjoy.

recipes.name: Jokbal (Braised Pig's Feet)
recipes.description: Pig's feet braised in a fragrant soy sauce broth until tender and gelatinous, sliced and served with salted shrimp dip.
instructions: Soak pig's feet in cold water for 2 hours to draw out blood. Scrub and clean thoroughly.
Blanch the pig's feet in boiling water for 10 minutes. Drain and rinse off any scum.
Place pig's feet in a large pot with soy sauce, rice wine, brown sugar, garlic, ginger, cinnamon, star anise, peppercorns, and green onions.
Add enough water to cover the pig's feet and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to low and simmer for 2 hours until the meat is very tender and pulls away from the bone.
Remove pig's feet from the broth and let cool slightly before slicing the meat.
Arrange sliced jokbal on a platter and serve with saeujeot dipping sauce and pickled vegetables.

recipes.name: LA Galbi (Korean-Style Short Ribs)
recipes.description: Flanken-cut beef short ribs marinated in a sweet soy and fruit sauce, grilled to smoky perfection. Named after LA's Korean community.

ingredients.name: LA-style beef short ribs, flanken cut thin

instructions: Soak the short ribs in cold water for 1 hour to remove excess blood. Pat dry.
Blend kiwi and grated onion together to create a natural meat tenderizer.
Combine soy sauce, sugar, sesame oil, garlic, kiwi-onion puree, rice wine, and black pepper for the marinade.
Coat ribs in the marinade and refrigerate for 4-6 hours. Do not over-marinate as kiwi can over-tenderize.
Preheat grill to high heat. Grill the ribs for 2-3 minutes per side until nicely charred.
Sprinkle with sesame seeds and serve immediately with steamed rice and banchan.

recipes.name: Kimchi Jjigae (Kimchi Stew)
recipes.description: A hearty, spicy stew made with well-fermented kimchi, pork, and tofu. The ultimate Korean comfort food.
instructions: Heat sesame oil in a pot over medium-high heat. Stir-fry the sliced pork belly until lightly browned.
Add the chopped aged kimchi and stir-fry together for 3-4 minutes until fragrant.
Pour in the water or anchovy broth and kimchi brine. Add gochugaru, garlic, and sugar.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes to develop the flavors.
Add the cubed tofu and cook for another 5 minutes without stirring too much.
Garnish with chopped green onions and serve bubbling hot with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Doenjang Jjigae (Soybean Paste Stew)
recipes.description: A savory, umami-rich stew made with fermented soybean paste, vegetables, and tofu. Everyday Korean home cooking at its best.
instructions: Bring the anchovy and kelp broth to a boil in a stone pot or heavy-bottomed saucepan.
Dissolve the doenjang paste into the boiling broth, breaking up any lumps.
Add the diced Korean radish and onion first and cook for 5 minutes.
Add the zucchini, mushrooms, and garlic. Simmer for another 5 minutes.
Add the cubed tofu and sliced green chili pepper. Cook for 5 more minutes.
Sprinkle with gochugaru and green onions. Serve immediately while still bubbling with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Sundubu Jjigae (Soft Tofu Stew)
recipes.description: A fiery, comforting stew with silky uncurdled soft tofu in a spicy broth, often topped with a raw egg cracked in at the table.
instructions: Heat sesame oil in a stone pot (ttukbaegi) over medium heat. Saute garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add gochugaru and stir for 30 seconds to bloom the pepper flakes in the oil.
Add sliced pork belly and cook until lightly browned, about 2 minutes.
Pour in the anchovy broth and bring to a boil. Add soy sauce and salt to taste.
Gently add the soft tofu by scooping it in with a spoon, breaking it into large chunks.
Simmer for 10 minutes until the stew is bubbling vigorously.
Crack a raw egg on top and serve immediately. The residual heat will cook the egg.

recipes.name: Budae Jjigae (Army Stew)
recipes.description: A fusion stew born from post-war Korea combining kimchi and gochujang with spam, hot dogs, and American cheese. Rich, spicy, and deeply satisfying.
instructions: Arrange spam, hot dogs, kimchi, tofu, and baked beans in sections in a large shallow pot.
Mix gochugaru, gochujang, and garlic with a ladleful of broth to make the seasoning paste. Pour over the ingredients.
Add the water or anchovy broth to the pot and bring to a boil over medium-high heat.
Once boiling, add the instant ramyeon noodles and cook for 3 minutes.
Place American cheese slices on top and let them melt over the stew.
Garnish with green onions and serve communally straight from the pot with rice on the side.

recipes.name: Gamjatang (Pork Bone Soup)
recipes.description: A rich, spicy soup made with pork neck bones and potatoes simmered until the meat falls off the bone. A popular late-night comfort food.
instructions: Soak pork neck bones in cold water for 2 hours to draw out blood. Drain and rinse.
Blanch the bones in boiling water for 10 minutes, then drain and rinse off any impurities.
Place the bones in a large pot, cover with fresh water, add ginger slices, and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 1.5 hours until the meat is very tender.
Add potatoes, napa cabbage, gochugaru, doenjang, ground perilla seeds, and garlic. Cook 20 more minutes.
Season with salt to taste. Garnish with green onions and perilla leaves before serving.

recipes.name: Seolleongtang (Ox Bone Soup)
recipes.description: A milky-white ox bone broth soup simmered for hours, served with thin rice noodles and sliced brisket. Mild and deeply nourishing.
instructions: Soak ox bones in cold water for 3-4 hours, changing the water several times to remove blood.
Blanch the bones and brisket in boiling water for 15 minutes. Drain and rinse thoroughly.
Place bones and brisket in a very large stockpot, cover with fresh water, and bring to a rolling boil.
Reduce to a steady simmer and cook for 6-8 hours, adding water as needed to keep bones submerged. The broth should turn milky white.
Remove the brisket after 2 hours when tender, let cool, and slice thinly. Return bones to continue simmering.
Cook somyeon noodles separately according to package directions. Drain and set aside.
Ladle the milky broth into bowls over noodles and rice. Top with sliced brisket and green onions. Season at the table with salt and pepper.

recipes.name: Samgyetang (Ginseng Chicken Soup)
recipes.description: A whole young chicken stuffed with glutinous rice, ginseng, jujubes, and garlic, simmered into a nourishing, restorative soup.
instructions: Rinse the chicken inside and out and pat dry. Trim excess fat.
Stuff the chicken cavity with soaked glutinous rice, ginseng root, garlic cloves, jujubes, and chestnuts.
Cross the chicken legs and tie them with kitchen twine to seal the cavity.
Place the stuffed chicken in a pot and add enough water to just cover the chicken.
Bring to a boil, skimming any foam. Reduce heat and simmer for 1 to 1.5 hours until the chicken is very tender.
Serve the whole chicken in a bowl with the broth. Season at the table with salt and pepper. Garnish with green onions.

recipes.name: Yukgaejang (Spicy Beef Soup)
recipes.description: A fiery, deeply flavored soup with shredded beef brisket, fernbrake, bean sprouts, and scallions in a spicy red broth.
instructions: Boil beef brisket in a large pot of water for 1 hour until tender. Remove, cool, and shred by hand along the grain.
Reserve the beef broth. Skim off excess fat from the surface.
Toss the shredded beef with gochugaru, sesame oil, garlic, and soy sauce in a bowl.
Return the seasoned beef to the broth along with soaked gosari, bean sprouts, and green onions.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 20-30 minutes until all vegetables are tender.
Drizzle beaten egg into the soup in a thin stream while stirring gently.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve piping hot with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Tteokguk (Rice Cake Soup)
recipes.description: A clear beef broth soup with sliced rice cakes, traditionally eaten on Lunar New Year to symbolize gaining a year of age.
instructions: Soak the sliced rice cakes in cold water for 20 minutes if using dried ones.
Bring the anchovy and kelp broth to a boil. Add thinly sliced beef and garlic, cooking for 10 minutes.
Season the broth with soy sauce, salt, and sesame oil.
Add the soaked rice cakes and cook for 5-7 minutes until soft and chewy but not mushy.
Beat eggs and cook as a thin omelet in a pan. Slice into thin strips (jidan).
Ladle the soup into bowls and top with egg strips, sliced green onions, and crumbled roasted seaweed.

recipes.name: Bibimbap
recipes.description: A vibrant bowl of rice topped with an array of seasoned vegetables, meat, gochujang, and a fried egg, mixed together before eating.
