Continue cooking and stirring until the mixture thickens to a pudding consistency, about 15 more minutes.
Add vanilla extract, pour into serving glasses, and let cool.
Make the meringue by whisking egg whites until soft peaks form, then gradually add sugar and port wine.
Continue whisking until stiff, glossy peaks form.
Pipe or spoon the meringue on top of the custard and dust with cinnamon.

recipes.name: Pierogi
recipes.description: Polish dumplings with a tender dough filled with potato and farmer's cheese, served with caramelized onions and sour cream.
instructions: Mix flour, eggs, sour cream, a pinch of salt, and warm water to form a smooth, elastic dough; rest for 30 minutes.
Boil and mash potatoes, then mix with crumbled farmer's cheese, salt, and pepper.
Roll dough thin on a floured surface and cut circles with a glass or round cutter.
Place a spoonful of filling on each circle, fold in half, and pinch the edges tightly to seal.
Boil pierogi in salted water until they float, then cook 2 more minutes.
Caramelize sliced onions slowly in butter until deep golden brown.
Serve pierogi topped with caramelized onions, a pat of butter, and sour cream.

recipes.name: Bigos
recipes.description: Poland's hunter's stew of sauerkraut and fresh cabbage slow-simmered with mixed meats, dried mushrooms, and prunes.
instructions: Soak dried porcini mushrooms in warm water for 30 minutes, then chop, reserving the soaking liquid.
Dice bacon and render the fat in a large Dutch oven, then brown cubed pork shoulder on all sides.
Add diced onion and cook until translucent.
Add drained and rinsed sauerkraut, shredded fresh cabbage, sliced kielbasa, chopped mushrooms, and their liquid.
Stir in tomato paste, prunes, bay leaves, juniper berries, and allspice.
Add water to just cover everything, bring to a boil, then simmer covered on low heat for 2 hours.
The stew improves over days; reheat and serve the next day for deeper flavor.

recipes.name: Zurek
recipes.description: Traditional Polish sour rye soup with white sausage and hard-boiled eggs, served in a bread bowl.
instructions: Simmer white sausage in water with bay leaves for 20 minutes, then slice into rounds.
In a separate pot, sauté diced bacon and onion until golden, then add minced garlic.
Add diced potatoes and enough water to cover, simmer until potatoes are tender.
Stir in the sour rye starter and bring to a gentle simmer, avoiding a full boil.
Add sliced sausage, marjoram, and horseradish, then stir in heavy cream.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve in hollowed-out bread bowls with halved hard-boiled eggs on top.

recipes.name: Placki Ziemniaczane
recipes.description: Crispy Polish potato pancakes grated and fried golden, served with sour cream or applesauce.
instructions: Peel and finely grate potatoes and onion, then squeeze out as much moisture as possible using a clean towel.
Mix the grated potato and onion with eggs, flour, salt, and pepper.
Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Drop spoonfuls of the mixture into the hot oil and flatten into thin pancakes.
Fry for 3-4 minutes per side until golden brown and crispy on the edges.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot with sour cream on the side.

recipes.name: Golabki
recipes.description: Polish stuffed cabbage rolls filled with pork, rice, and onions, baked in a tomato sauce.
instructions: Core the cabbage and blanch in boiling salted water until the leaves are pliable enough to peel off.
Mix ground pork with cooked rice, minced onion, garlic, egg, salt, pepper, and paprika.
Place a portion of the filling on each cabbage leaf, tuck in the sides, and roll tightly.
Arrange the rolls seam-side down in a baking dish.
Mix crushed tomatoes with tomato paste and a little water, then pour over the cabbage rolls.
Cover with foil and bake at 180C for 60 minutes until the meat is cooked through.
Let rest for 10 minutes and serve with the tomato sauce spooned over the rolls.

recipes.name: Kotlet Schabowy
recipes.description: Polish breaded pork cutlet pounded thin, coated in flour, egg, and breadcrumbs, and pan-fried until golden.
instructions: Pound each pork cutlet between plastic wrap until about 5mm thick.
Season both sides with salt and pepper.
Dredge each cutlet in flour, shaking off excess.
Dip in beaten egg, then coat thoroughly in breadcrumbs, pressing gently to adhere.
Heat lard or oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Fry each cutlet for 3-4 minutes per side until the breadcrumb coating is deeply golden and the pork is cooked through.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges, mashed potatoes, and a beet salad.

recipes.name: Barszcz Czerwony
recipes.description: Clear Polish beetroot soup with a deep ruby color, traditionally served with uszka (small mushroom dumplings) on Christmas Eve.
instructions: Peel and roughly chop beets, carrots, celery root, and onion.
Place the vegetables in a pot with 2 liters of water, bay leaves, allspice, and garlic.
Simmer for 45 minutes until the vegetables are very tender and the broth is deeply colored.
Strain through a fine sieve, pressing on the vegetables to extract flavor, and return the clear broth to the pot.
Season with vinegar, sugar, and salt, balancing the sweet-sour flavor.
Cook uszka dumplings in salted water according to package directions.
Ladle the hot ruby broth into bowls and add a few uszka to each serving.

recipes.name: Makowiec
recipes.description: Traditional Polish poppy seed roll with a sweet yeast dough wrapped around a rich filling of ground poppy seeds, honey, and nuts.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm milk with a pinch of sugar; let bloom for 10 minutes.
Mix flour, sugar, eggs, softened butter, and yeast mixture into a soft dough; knead for 10 minutes and let rise for 1 hour.
Grind poppy seeds twice through a fine grinder or blend until pasty.
Cook ground poppy seeds with honey, sugar, chopped walnuts, raisins, and lemon zest over low heat for 10 minutes.
Roll the risen dough into a large rectangle, spread the poppy seed filling evenly, and roll up tightly.
Place seam-side down on a lined baking sheet and let rise for 30 minutes.
Brush with beaten egg and bake at 180C for 45-50 minutes until deep golden brown.
Cool completely before slicing to reveal the spiral of poppy seed filling.

recipes.name: Borscht
recipes.description: Classic Russian beet soup with beef, potatoes, and cabbage, served hot with a generous dollop of smetana (sour cream).
instructions: Simmer beef chuck in 2.5 liters of water with bay leaves for 60 minutes, skimming any foam.
Remove beef, shred into pieces, and strain the broth.
Sauté grated beets with vinegar in a pan for 10 minutes to preserve the color.
Sauté diced onion and grated carrots with tomato paste in another pan until softened.
Add diced potatoes to the broth and cook for 10 minutes.
Add the sauteed beets, onion-carrot mixture, shredded cabbage, and beef back to the pot.
Simmer for 15 minutes, add minced garlic and salt, then let rest covered for 15 minutes.
Serve hot, topped with sour cream and chopped fresh dill.

recipes.name: Beef Stroganoff
recipes.description: Tender strips of beef sauteed with mushrooms and onions in a rich sour cream sauce, a Russian classic from the 19th century.
instructions: Cut beef tenderloin into thin strips and season with salt and pepper.
Sear beef strips in batches in hot butter over high heat for 1 minute per side, then set aside.
In the same pan, sauté sliced mushrooms until golden, then add diced onion and cook until soft.
Sprinkle flour over the vegetables and stir for 1 minute.
Pour in beef broth and bring to a simmer, scraping up the browned bits.
Reduce heat, stir in sour cream and Dijon mustard, and return the beef to the pan.
Simmer gently for 3 minutes (do not boil or the sour cream will curdle).
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve over egg noodles or mashed potatoes.

recipes.name: Pelmeni
recipes.description: Siberian meat dumplings filled with a mixture of beef and pork, boiled and served with sour cream and vinegar.
instructions: Make the dough from flour, eggs, salt, and water; knead until smooth and elastic, then rest for 30 minutes.
Mix ground beef and pork with finely minced onion, garlic, salt, and pepper for the filling.
Roll dough thin and cut small circles with a round cutter.
Place a teaspoon of filling on each circle, fold in half, and pinch to seal, then join the two corners together.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Drop pelmeni in batches, cook until they float plus 3 more minutes.
Drain and toss with butter, then serve with sour cream and a splash of vinegar.

recipes.name: Blini
recipes.description: Light, fluffy Russian yeasted buckwheat pancakes, traditionally served with sour cream, smoked salmon, or caviar.
instructions: Warm milk to lukewarm, dissolve yeast and sugar in it, and let bloom for 10 minutes.
Mix both flours with salt, then whisk in the yeast mixture and egg yolks to form a smooth batter.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled and bubbly.
Beat egg whites to stiff peaks and fold gently into the risen batter.
Melt a little butter in a nonstick pan and ladle small portions of batter to make 10cm pancakes.
Cook for 2 minutes per side until golden with small holes on the surface.
Serve warm, topped with sour cream and smoked salmon.

recipes.name: Shchi
recipes.description: Traditional Russian cabbage soup simmered with pork, root vegetables, and fresh herbs, a staple of Russian cuisine for centuries.
instructions: Place pork ribs in a pot with 2 liters of cold water, bring to a boil, and skim the foam.
Simmer for 40 minutes until the pork is tender, then remove the meat from the bones.
Add diced potatoes to the broth and cook for 10 minutes.
Sauté diced onion and grated carrots with tomato paste until softened.
Add the sauteed vegetables and shredded cabbage to the pot.
Return the pork meat, add bay leaves, and simmer for 15 minutes until cabbage is tender.
Add minced garlic, salt, and pepper, and let rest covered for 10 minutes.
Serve with a dollop of sour cream and fresh dill.

recipes.name: Pirozhki
recipes.description: Golden Russian baked buns stuffed with a savory filling of seasoned beef, onions, and hard-boiled eggs.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm milk with sugar and let bloom for 10 minutes.
Mix flour with salt, then add the yeast mixture, 2 beaten eggs, and softened butter to form a soft dough.
Knead for 10 minutes until smooth, cover, and let rise for 1 hour.
Brown ground beef with diced onions, then mix with chopped hard-boiled eggs, dill, salt, and pepper.
Divide dough into 16 pieces, roll each into a small oval, place filling in the center, and pinch edges to seal into a boat shape.
Place seam-side down on a baking sheet, let rise 20 minutes, and brush with beaten egg.
Bake at 190C for 20-25 minutes until deeply golden brown.

recipes.name: Olivier Salad
recipes.description: Russia's iconic festive potato salad with diced vegetables, pickles, eggs, and bologna in a generous mayonnaise dressing.
instructions: Boil potatoes and carrots until tender, then cool completely and peel.
Dice potatoes, carrots, hard-boiled eggs, bologna, and pickles into small uniform cubes.
Combine all diced ingredients in a large bowl with drained green peas.
Add mayonnaise, salt, and pepper, and fold gently until everything is evenly coated.
Taste and adjust seasoning.
Chill for at least 1 hour to let the flavors meld.
Garnish with chopped dill and sliced green onions before serving.

recipes.name: Medovik
recipes.description: Russian honey cake with multiple thin layers of honey-infused sponge sandwiched with tangy sour cream frosting.
instructions: Melt butter, honey, and sugar in a double boiler, then add baking soda and stir as it foams.
Beat in eggs one at a time, then gradually mix in flour to form a soft, sticky dough.
Divide the dough into 8 equal portions and chill for 30 minutes.
Roll each portion into a thin circle on parchment paper and bake at 180C for 5-6 minutes until golden.
Whip sour cream with powdered sugar and vanilla until thick.
Stack the layers, spreading a generous amount of sour cream frosting between each one.
Crush the trimmings from the layers and press onto the sides and top of the cake.
Refrigerate for at least 8 hours so the layers soften and meld together before serving.

recipes.name: Patatas Bravas
recipes.description: Crispy fried potato cubes served with a spicy smoky tomato sauce and garlic aioli, one of Spain's most beloved tapas.
instructions: Peel the potatoes and cut into rough 3cm cubes.
Heat olive oil in a deep pan to 180C and fry potatoes in batches until golden and crispy, about 8-10 minutes per batch.
For the bravas sauce, saute minced garlic in 2 tablespoons olive oil until fragrant.
Add smoked paprika, hot paprika, and cayenne, stir for 30 seconds, then add tomato passata and sherry vinegar.
Simmer the sauce for 15 minutes until thickened, then season with salt.
Drain the fried potatoes on paper towels and season with salt.
Pile the potatoes on a plate and drizzle generously with the bravas sauce.
Serve immediately while hot and crispy.

recipes.name: Gambas al Ajillo
recipes.description: Sizzling garlic shrimp cooked in abundant olive oil with dried chili, a classic tapa served bubbling hot in a cazuela.
instructions: Peel and devein the prawns, leaving the tails intact, and pat dry with paper towels.
Thinly slice the garlic cloves and finely chop the parsley.
Heat the olive oil in a cazuela or small heavy skillet over medium-high heat.
Add the sliced garlic and broken dried chili pieces, cooking for 1 minute until garlic just begins to turn golden.
Add the prawns in a single layer and cook for 2 minutes per side until pink and curled.
Remove from heat, season with sea salt, and scatter with chopped parsley.
Serve immediately in the cazuela with plenty of crusty bread for dipping in the garlicky oil.

recipes.name: Croquetas de Jamon
recipes.description: Creamy bechamel croquettes studded with Serrano ham, coated in breadcrumbs and fried until golden, a beloved Spanish bar snack.
instructions: Finely dice the onion and Serrano ham into very small pieces.
Melt butter in a saucepan, saute the onion until soft, then add the diced ham and cook for 2 minutes.
Add the flour and stir constantly for 2 minutes to cook the roux.
Gradually add the milk, stirring continuously to avoid lumps, and cook until the bechamel is very thick and pulls away from the sides of the pan.
Season with nutmeg, salt, and white pepper, then spread onto a tray, cover with cling film touching the surface, and refrigerate for at least 3 hours.
Shape the chilled mixture into small oval croquettes, dip in beaten egg, then coat in breadcrumbs.
Deep-fry in olive oil at 180C for 2-3 minutes until deep golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.

recipes.name: Tortilla Espanola
recipes.description: The iconic Spanish potato omelette made with thinly sliced potatoes and onion slowly cooked in olive oil, a staple served at room temperature.
instructions: Peel and thinly slice the potatoes into 3mm rounds, then thinly slice the onion.
Heat the olive oil in a deep skillet over medium heat and gently cook the potatoes and onion for 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until very tender but not browned.
Beat the eggs in a large bowl with salt.
Drain the potatoes and onion, reserving the oil, and fold them into the beaten eggs, letting the mixture rest for 5 minutes.
Heat 2 tablespoons of the reserved oil in a non-stick skillet over medium-high heat and pour in the egg and potato mixture.
Cook for 4-5 minutes until the edges are set, then place a plate over the pan and flip the tortilla onto it.
Slide the tortilla back into the pan and cook for another 3-4 minutes until just set but still slightly juicy inside.
Let it rest for 5 minutes before slicing into wedges and serving at room temperature.

recipes.name: Pimientos de Padron
recipes.description: Small green Padron peppers blistered in olive oil and finished with coarse sea salt, where most are mild but some are fiery hot.
instructions: Wash the Padron peppers and pat them completely dry with paper towels.
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over high heat until shimmering and almost smoking.
Add the peppers in a single layer and cook without moving for 1-2 minutes until blistered and charred on one side.
Toss the peppers and continue cooking for another 1-2 minutes until blistered all over and softened.
Transfer to a serving plate and generously sprinkle with flaky sea salt.
Serve immediately while hot.

recipes.name: Boquerones en Vinagre
recipes.description: Fresh anchovies marinated in white wine vinegar, garlic, and parsley, a refreshing cold tapa found in bars across Spain.
instructions: Clean the anchovies by removing the heads, guts, and backbone, separating them into two fillets each.
Rinse the fillets under cold water and pat dry.
Lay the fillets skin-side down in a shallow dish and cover completely with white wine vinegar.
Refrigerate and marinate for at least 6 hours or overnight until the flesh turns white and opaque.
Drain the vinegar, finely mince the garlic, and chop the parsley.
Arrange the marinated anchovies on a plate, drizzle generously with olive oil, and scatter with garlic, parsley, and sea salt.
Serve cold as a tapa with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Albondigas en Salsa
recipes.description: Tender Spanish meatballs simmered in a rich tomato and saffron sauce, a comforting tapa or main dish served throughout Spain.
instructions: Combine the ground pork, ground beef, breadcrumbs, egg, half the minced garlic, chopped parsley, salt, and smoked paprika in a bowl and mix well.
Shape the mixture into walnut-sized meatballs and dust lightly with flour.
Heat olive oil in a large cazuela or deep skillet and brown the meatballs in batches, then set aside.
In the same pan, saute the finely diced onion and remaining garlic until softened.
Add the white wine and saffron threads, simmer for 2 minutes, then add the crushed tomatoes.
Return the meatballs to the sauce, cover, and simmer gently for 25 minutes until cooked through and the sauce has thickened.
Adjust seasoning with salt and garnish with fresh parsley.
Serve hot with crusty bread to mop up the sauce.

recipes.name: Pan con Tomate
recipes.description: Toasted bread rubbed with ripe tomato, garlic, and drizzled with olive oil, the simplest and most iconic Catalan tapa.
instructions: Toast or grill the bread slices until golden and crispy on both sides.
Cut the garlic cloves in half and rub the cut side vigorously over the warm toast.
Cut the tomatoes in half crosswise and grate the flesh on a box grater, discarding the skin.
Spoon the fresh tomato pulp generously over each toast and spread evenly.
Drizzle with good extra virgin olive oil and sprinkle with flaky sea salt.
Serve immediately as a tapa or alongside cured meats and cheese.

recipes.name: Pulpo a la Gallega
recipes.description: Galician-style octopus sliced and served on a wooden board with boiled potatoes, smoked paprika, coarse salt, and olive oil.
instructions: If using fresh octopus, freeze it for at least 48 hours then thaw to tenderize the flesh.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil with the bay leaves and dip the octopus in and out three times to curl the tentacles before fully submerging.
Simmer the octopus for 40-50 minutes until tender when pierced with a knife.
In the last 20 minutes of cooking, add peeled and sliced potatoes to the pot.
Remove the octopus and let it rest for 5 minutes, then cut the tentacles into 1cm thick slices with scissors.
Arrange the potato slices on a wooden board and layer the octopus slices on top.
Drizzle generously with olive oil, sprinkle with smoked paprika and coarse sea salt.
Serve warm on the wooden board as is traditional in Galicia.

recipes.name: Paella Valenciana
recipes.description: The original Valencian paella made with chicken, rabbit, green beans, and lima beans cooked with saffron rice over an open flame.
instructions: Heat olive oil in a wide paella pan over high heat and brown the chicken and rabbit pieces on all sides, then set aside.
In the same oil, saute the green beans for 3-4 minutes, then add minced garlic and grated tomato, cooking until the liquid evaporates.
Add smoked paprika, stir for 30 seconds, then return the meat to the pan.
Pour in the hot stock infused with saffron threads and rosemary, bring to a boil, and simmer for 20 minutes.
Add the lima beans and scatter the bomba rice evenly across the pan without stirring.
Cook over high heat for 10 minutes, then reduce to medium for another 8-10 minutes until the rice is cooked and the liquid is absorbed.
Increase heat for the last 2 minutes to create the socarrat, the prized crispy rice layer on the bottom.
Remove from heat, cover with a clean cloth, rest for 5 minutes, then serve with lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Paella de Marisco
recipes.description: Luxurious seafood paella loaded with prawns, mussels, clams, and squid in a fragrant saffron rice cooked in fish stock.
instructions: Heat olive oil in a paella pan and saute the diced onion and red pepper until softened.
Add sliced squid rings and cook for 2 minutes, then add minced garlic and cook for another minute.
Stir in the grated tomato and cook until the mixture darkens and the liquid evaporates.
Add the bomba rice and stir to coat in the sofrito, then pour in the hot fish stock infused with saffron.
Distribute the rice evenly, bring to a boil, then cook over medium-high heat for 10 minutes without stirring.
Nestle the prawns, mussels, and clams into the rice and cook for another 8-10 minutes until the shellfish open and the rice is tender.
Increase heat for the final 2 minutes to develop the socarrat.
Remove from heat, discard any unopened shellfish, garnish with parsley, and serve with lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Paella Mixta
recipes.description: A generous mixed paella combining chicken, chorizo, prawns, and mussels with saffron rice, popular in restaurants across Spain.
instructions: Heat olive oil in a paella pan over high heat and brown the chicken pieces on all sides, then remove and set aside.
Add sliced chorizo and cook until it releases its oils, then add diced onion, pepper, and garlic, sauteing until soft.
Stir in the grated tomato and smoked paprika, cooking until the sofrito is thick and dark.
Return the chicken to the pan, add the rice, and stir to coat everything in the sofrito.
Pour in the hot saffron-infused stock, distribute everything evenly, and bring to a boil.
Cook over medium-high heat for 10 minutes, then add the prawns and mussels, pressing them into the rice, along with the frozen peas.
Continue cooking for 8-10 minutes until the rice is tender, the seafood is cooked, and the liquid is absorbed.
Let the paella rest off the heat for 5 minutes before serving directly from the pan.

recipes.name: Arroz Negro
recipes.description: Dramatic black rice cooked with squid ink, squid, and seafood stock, a specialty of the Spanish Mediterranean coast.
instructions: Clean the squid, separating the tentacles from the bodies, and cut the bodies into rings.
Heat olive oil in a paella pan and saute the diced onion until translucent, then add minced garlic.
Add the squid rings and tentacles, cooking over high heat for 3 minutes.
Pour in the white wine and let it reduce by half, then add the grated tomato and cook for 5 minutes.
Dissolve the squid ink in the hot fish stock, add the rice to the pan, and pour in the inky stock.
Stir once to distribute evenly, then cook over medium-high heat for 18-20 minutes without stirring until the rice is tender and liquid absorbed.
Rest for 5 minutes off the heat.
Serve the dramatic black rice with a generous dollop of alioli on top.

recipes.name: Cochinillo Asado
recipes.description: Roast suckling pig from Segovia, slow-roasted until the skin is impossibly crispy and the meat falls off the bone.
instructions: Score the skin of the suckling pig with a sharp knife in a crosshatch pattern.
Rub the pig all over with olive oil, crushed garlic, salt, and pepper, and tuck bay leaves and thyme underneath.
Place the pig skin-side down in a large roasting pan with the water and white wine.
Roast at 180C for 1.5 hours, basting occasionally with the pan juices.
Carefully flip the pig skin-side up, rub the skin with lard, and increase the oven to 220C.
Roast for another 45-60 minutes until the skin is deeply golden and crackles when tapped.
Rest the pig for 15 minutes before carving, traditionally done with the edge of a plate to show how tender the meat is.
Serve with the crispy skin and pan juices spooned over.

recipes.name: Fabada Asturiana
recipes.description: A hearty bean stew from Asturias made with large white fabes beans, chorizo, morcilla, and smoked pork, perfect for cold weather.
instructions: Soak the fabes beans overnight in cold water, then drain and rinse.
Place the beans in a large pot with the smoked pork shoulder, halved onion, whole garlic cloves, and bay leaves.
Cover with cold water and bring slowly to a boil, skimming any foam from the surface.
Reduce to a gentle simmer and cook for 1 hour, adding cold water as needed to keep the beans submerged.
Add the whole chorizo and morcilla, along with saffron and smoked paprika, and continue simmering for another hour until beans are very tender and creamy.
Remove the meats, slice them thickly, and return to the pot.
Season with salt, let the fabada rest for 10 minutes off the heat so the flavors meld.
Serve in deep bowls with the sliced meats on top of the beans and plenty of the rich broth.

recipes.name: Pisto Manchego
recipes.description: A vegetable stew from La Mancha made with tomatoes, peppers, zucchini, and onion, similar to ratatouille but distinctly Spanish.
instructions: Dice the onion, peppers, and zucchini into roughly 1cm cubes and keep them separate.
Score and blanch the tomatoes, then peel and roughly chop them.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet and cook the onion over low heat until very soft, about 10 minutes.
Add the peppers and continue cooking gently for another 10 minutes.
Add the diced zucchini and minced garlic, cooking for 5 more minutes.
Add the chopped tomatoes, sugar, and salt, and simmer uncovered for 15-20 minutes until everything is soft and the sauce has thickened.
Adjust seasoning and serve warm, at room temperature, or topped with a fried egg for a more substantial dish.

recipes.name: Pollo al Ajillo
recipes.description: Chicken pieces braised with an abundance of garlic cloves in olive oil and white wine, a rustic dish found in every Spanish home kitchen.
instructions: Season the chicken pieces generously with salt and pepper.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet or cazuela over medium-high heat and brown the chicken on all sides until golden, about 8 minutes total.
Remove the chicken and reduce the heat to medium, then add the whole peeled garlic cloves and fry gently until golden and fragrant.
Pour in the white wine, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom, and add the bay leaves and thyme.
Return the chicken to the pan, cover, and simmer gently for 25 minutes until the chicken is cooked through and the garlic is meltingly soft.
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve with plenty of crusty bread to soak up the garlicky juices.

recipes.name: Cordero al Chilindron
recipes.description: Aragonese braised lamb with a rich sauce of roasted red peppers, tomatoes, and chorizo, a festive dish from northeastern Spain.
instructions: Cut the lamb shoulder into large chunks and season with salt and pepper.
Heat olive oil in a heavy casserole and brown the lamb in batches over high heat, then set aside.
Add diced chorizo and Serrano ham to the pot and cook for 2 minutes until the fat renders.
Add sliced onions and garlic, cooking until softened, then stir in smoked paprika.
Pour in the white wine and let it reduce by half, then add crushed tomatoes and sliced roasted peppers.
Return the lamb to the pot, cover tightly, and braise in a 160C oven for 1.5 hours until the meat is fork-tender.
Adjust seasoning and let rest for 10 minutes before serving.
Serve in the casserole with the rich red pepper sauce spooned generously over the lamb.

recipes.name: Bacalao al Pil Pil
recipes.description: Salt cod gently cooked in olive oil with garlic, creating a silky emulsified sauce through the fish's natural gelatin, a Basque masterpiece.
instructions: Desalt the cod by soaking in cold water for 48 hours, changing the water 3-4 times, then pat dry.
Place the cod skin-side down in a cold cazuela, pour the olive oil over, and place on the lowest possible heat.
Cook very gently for 15-18 minutes, swirling the pan occasionally, until the fish is cooked through and begins to release its gelatin into the oil.
Carefully remove the cod to a plate and set aside, keeping it warm.
Add sliced garlic and broken chili to the oil and cook until the garlic is just golden, then remove them.
Off the heat, begin swirling the cazuela in a circular motion, tilting it to create the pil pil emulsion as the fish gelatin and oil combine into a creamy white sauce.
Return the cod and garlic to the cazuela, spoon the pil pil sauce over the fish.
Garnish with parsley and serve immediately in the cazuela.

recipes.name: Merluza a la Vasca
recipes.description: Basque-style hake in a vibrant green sauce of garlic, parsley, white wine, and peas, a refined and elegant fish dish.
instructions: Season the hake fillets with salt and lightly dust with flour.
Heat olive oil in a wide cazuela over medium heat and cook the hake skin-side down for 3 minutes, then carefully remove.
In the same oil, gently fry sliced garlic until golden, then add finely chopped parsley stems and cook for 1 minute.
Pour in the white wine and fish stock, bring to a simmer, and shake the pan gently to begin emulsifying the sauce.
Add the peas and clams, then nestle the hake fillets back in skin-side up.
Cover and cook for 8-10 minutes, gently shaking the pan periodically to thicken the green sauce, until the clams open and fish is cooked.
Scatter with chopped parsley leaves and serve immediately in the cazuela.

recipes.name: Cocido Madrileno
recipes.description: Madrid's iconic chickpea stew served in three courses: first the broth with noodles, then the chickpeas and vegetables, and finally the meats.
instructions: Soak the chickpeas overnight in cold water with a pinch of salt, then drain.
Place the beef shank, chicken, ham bone, chickpeas, peppercorns, and whole garlic in a very large pot and cover with cold water.
Bring slowly to a boil, skimming the foam constantly, then reduce to a gentle simmer.
After 1 hour, add the carrots, leek, and potatoes, and continue simmering.
After another 30 minutes, add the chorizo and morcilla, cooking for 30 minutes more.
Add the quartered cabbage and cook for a final 30 minutes until everything is tender.
Strain the broth into a separate pot, cook the fideos noodles in it, and serve as the first course.
Arrange the chickpeas and vegetables on one platter and the sliced meats on another, serving as the second and third courses.

recipes.name: Migas
recipes.description: Rustic fried breadcrumbs from shepherds' cuisine, crisped with olive oil, garlic, chorizo, and smoked paprika, topped with grapes and fried eggs.
instructions: Tear the stale bread into small rough crumbs, sprinkle with salted water, and let it sit for 30 minutes to soften slightly.
Heat half the olive oil in a large skillet and fry sliced chorizo until crispy, then remove and set aside.
In the same oil, fry whole peeled garlic cloves until golden, then remove.
Add the remaining olive oil, sprinkle in the smoked paprika, and add the moistened breadcrumbs.
Fry the breadcrumbs over medium heat, stirring and turning constantly for 15-20 minutes until golden and crispy throughout.
In a separate pan, fry the eggs in olive oil until the edges are crispy.
Serve the migas on a plate topped with the crispy chorizo, fried garlic, fried egg, and fresh grapes.

recipes.name: Callos a la Madrilena
recipes.description: Madrid-style slow-cooked tripe stew with chorizo, morcilla, and chickpeas in a spicy smoky paprika sauce.
instructions: Clean the tripe thoroughly, cut into 3cm pieces, and boil in salted water for 10 minutes, then drain and rinse.
In a large pot, cover the tripe with fresh water, add bay leaves, and simmer for 2 hours until tender.
In a separate pan, heat olive oil and saute the diced onion and garlic until soft.
Add smoked paprika, hot paprika, and tomato paste, stirring for 1 minute.
Add this sofrito to the tripe pot along with sliced chorizo, morcilla, and chickpeas.
Simmer everything together for another 45 minutes until the sauce is thick and the flavors have melded.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve very hot in deep bowls, ideally the next day when the flavors are even better.

recipes.name: Gazpacho
recipes.description: Chilled Andalusian tomato soup blended with peppers, cucumber, garlic, bread, and sherry vinegar, the quintessential summer refreshment.
instructions: Roughly chop the tomatoes, cucumber, green pepper, and garlic.
Soak the stale bread in water for a few minutes until softened.
Place all the vegetables and soaked bread in a blender with the olive oil, sherry vinegar, salt, and water.
Blend on high until very smooth and creamy.
Pass through a fine sieve for an extra smooth texture if desired.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours.
Serve ice-cold in bowls, drizzled with olive oil and garnished with finely diced cucumber, pepper, and croutons.

recipes.name: Salmorejo
recipes.description: A thick creamy cold tomato soup from Cordoba, richer than gazpacho, traditionally topped with diced Serrano ham and hard-boiled egg.
instructions: Score the tomatoes, blanch briefly in boiling water, peel, and roughly chop.
Remove the crusts from the bread and soak in water until softened.
Blend the tomatoes, squeezed bread, garlic, salt, and sherry vinegar until very smooth.
With the blender running, slowly drizzle in the olive oil to create a thick, creamy emulsion.
Chill thoroughly in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours.
Hard-boil the eggs, peel, and finely dice them.
Serve the salmorejo in bowls topped with diced Serrano ham, chopped hard-boiled egg, and a drizzle of olive oil.

recipes.name: Caldo Gallego
recipes.description: A warming Galician broth with white beans, turnip greens, potatoes, and pork, the ultimate comfort food from rainy northwest Spain.
instructions: Soak the white beans overnight in cold water, then drain.
Place the beans, ham bone, smoked pork ribs, halved onion, and garlic in a large pot, cover with cold water, and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer gently for 1 hour, skimming any foam from the surface.
Add the peeled and cubed potatoes and whole chorizo, continuing to simmer for 30 minutes.
Wash the turnip greens, remove tough stems, roughly chop, and add to the pot.
Cook for a final 20-30 minutes until the greens are tender and the beans are creamy.
Remove the meats, slice the chorizo and shred the pork from the ribs, and return to the pot.
Season with salt, drizzle with olive oil, and serve steaming hot in deep bowls.

recipes.name: Sopa de Ajo
recipes.description: Castilian garlic soup made with stale bread, plenty of garlic, smoked paprika, and topped with a poached egg, a humble but deeply satisfying dish.
instructions: Slice the bread into thin rounds or tear into rough pieces.
Heat olive oil in a cazuela over medium heat and fry the thinly sliced garlic until pale golden.
Add the smoked paprika and stir for 10 seconds, being careful not to burn it.
Immediately add the bread pieces and toss to coat in the garlicky paprika oil.
Pour in the stock, bring to a simmer, and cook for 15 minutes until the bread has softened and the soup has thickened.
Season with salt, then crack the eggs directly into the simmering soup.
Cover and cook gently for 4-5 minutes until the eggs are poached but still runny.
Sprinkle with chopped parsley and serve immediately in the cazuela.

recipes.name: Gambas a la Plancha
recipes.description: Whole prawns simply grilled on a flat griddle with just sea salt and olive oil, showcasing the pure flavor of the seafood.
instructions: Pat the prawns dry and toss lightly with olive oil and coarse sea salt.
Heat a plancha or large flat griddle to very high heat until smoking.
Place the prawns in a single layer and cook for 2 minutes without moving until the shells are charred and pink.
Flip and cook for another 1-2 minutes until just cooked through.
Transfer to a plate, drizzle with more olive oil, and sprinkle with chopped parsley.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges for squeezing.

recipes.name: Calamares a la Romana
recipes.description: Classic fried squid rings in a light crispy batter, served with lemon wedges, found in tapas bars and bocadillo shops across Spain.
instructions: Clean the squid tubes and cut into 1cm thick rings, then pat very dry.
Make the batter by whisking the flour, egg, sparkling water, and a pinch of salt until smooth but still slightly lumpy.
Heat the olive oil in a deep pan to 180C.
Dip the squid rings into the batter, letting excess drip off.
Fry in batches for 2-3 minutes until golden and crispy, turning once.
Drain on paper towels and season with salt immediately.
Serve hot with lemon wedges, either as a tapa or stuffed into a crusty roll for a bocadillo de calamares.

recipes.name: Zarzuela de Mariscos
recipes.description: A spectacular Catalan seafood stew of mixed fish and shellfish in a rich tomato, saffron, and brandy sauce.
instructions: Cut the monkfish into large chunks and the squid into rings, season with salt, and dust lightly with flour.
Heat olive oil in a large wide cazuela and briefly sear the monkfish and squid, then set aside.
In the same pan, saute the finely diced onion and garlic until soft.
Pour in the brandy and carefully flambe, then add the crushed tomatoes, fish stock, and saffron.
Simmer the sauce for 15 minutes until reduced and flavorful.
Return the monkfish and squid to the pan, add the prawns, mussels, and clams.
Cover and cook for 8-10 minutes until all the shellfish have opened and the fish is cooked through.
Discard any unopened shellfish, scatter with chopped parsley, and serve the zarzuela directly from the cazuela with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Churros con Chocolate
recipes.description: Golden fried dough sticks with a crispy exterior and soft interior, served with thick Spanish hot chocolate for dipping.
instructions: Bring the water, 2 tablespoons olive oil, and salt to a boil in a saucepan.
Remove from heat and add the flour all at once, stirring vigorously with a wooden spoon until a smooth dough forms and pulls away from the sides.
Transfer the dough to a churrera or piping bag fitted with a large star nozzle.
Heat the frying oil to 190C and pipe 15cm lengths of dough directly into the hot oil, cutting with scissors.
Fry in batches for 3-4 minutes, turning once, until deep golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and roll in the sugar and cinnamon mixture while still hot.
For the chocolate, heat the milk, whisk in chopped chocolate and cornstarch, and stir over low heat until thick and glossy.
Serve the warm churros immediately with the thick hot chocolate for dunking.

recipes.name: Crema Catalana
recipes.description: Catalonia's answer to creme brulee, a silky custard infused with lemon zest and cinnamon, topped with a crackly caramelized sugar crust.
instructions: Heat the milk with the lemon zest strips and cinnamon stick until just simmering, then remove from heat and steep for 15 minutes.
Whisk the egg yolks with 100g of sugar and the cornstarch until pale and thick.
Strain the infused milk and gradually whisk it into the egg mixture.
Return to the saucepan and cook over medium-low heat, stirring constantly, until the custard thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon.
Add vanilla extract, then pour into individual shallow clay dishes.
Refrigerate for at least 4 hours until completely set.
Just before serving, sprinkle the remaining sugar evenly over each custard and caramelize with a kitchen torch or under a very hot grill until golden and crackly.

recipes.name: Tarta de Santiago
recipes.description: A moist almond cake from Galicia marked with the Cross of Saint James, made without flour and with a wonderful dense texture.
instructions: Preheat the oven to 180C and grease a 24cm round cake tin with butter.
Beat the eggs and sugar together until very light, pale, and fluffy, about 5 minutes.
Gently fold in the ground almonds, lemon zest, and cinnamon until just combined.
Pour the batter into the prepared tin and smooth the top.
Bake for 35-40 minutes until golden and a skewer comes out clean.
Let the cake cool completely in the tin.
Place a cross of Saint James stencil on top and dust generously with powdered sugar, then carefully remove the stencil to reveal the pattern.

recipes.name: Flan
recipes.description: Classic Spanish caramel custard with a golden caramel base, silky smooth egg custard, and a rich vanilla flavor.
instructions: Make the caramel by heating 100g sugar with the water in a saucepan over medium heat without stirring until deep amber, then pour into a 1-liter mold, swirling to coat the bottom.
Heat the milk with the lemon zest until just simmering, then let it cool slightly and remove the zest.
Whisk the whole eggs, egg yolks, remaining 100g sugar, and vanilla until combined but not frothy.
Gradually pour the warm milk into the egg mixture, whisking gently, then strain through a fine sieve.
Pour the custard over the caramel in the mold and place in a bain-marie with hot water reaching halfway up the sides.
Bake at 160C for 45-50 minutes until the custard is just set with a slight wobble in the center.
Cool completely, then refrigerate for at least 6 hours or overnight.
To unmold, run a knife around the edge and invert onto a plate, letting the caramel sauce flow over the flan.

recipes.name: Arroz con Leche
recipes.description: Spanish rice pudding slowly cooked with milk, sugar, lemon zest, and cinnamon, served with a caramelized sugar top.
instructions: Bring the water to a boil, add the rice, and cook for 5 minutes, then drain.
In a large saucepan, heat the milk with the lemon zest and cinnamon stick until simmering.
Add the par-cooked rice and stir well.
Cook over low heat for 40-45 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent sticking, until the rice is very tender and the mixture is creamy.
Remove the lemon zest and cinnamon stick, stir in the sugar and butter until dissolved.
Pour into individual dishes and let cool to room temperature.
Dust the top with ground cinnamon and optionally caramelize a sprinkle of sugar on top with a torch.
Serve at room temperature or chilled.

recipes.name: Torrijas
recipes.description: Spanish-style French toast soaked in sweet milk and wine, fried until golden, and dusted with cinnamon sugar, a traditional Easter treat.
instructions: Slice the stale bread into 2cm thick slices.
Heat the milk with 50g sugar, cinnamon stick, and lemon zest until simmering, then let it cool slightly.
Soak the bread slices in the warm sweetened milk until saturated but not falling apart, about 2 minutes per side.
Beat the eggs in a shallow dish.
Dip each soaked bread slice in beaten egg to coat completely.
Fry in olive oil over medium heat until golden brown on both sides, about 2 minutes per side.
Mix the remaining sugar with ground cinnamon and roll the hot torrijas in the mixture.
Drizzle with honey and serve warm or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Leche Frita
recipes.description: Fried milk squares, a custard set firm, cut into pieces, breaded and fried until crispy outside and creamy inside, dusted with cinnamon sugar.
instructions: Heat the milk with lemon zest and cinnamon stick until simmering, then strain and discard the aromatics.
Whisk the egg yolks with 80g sugar and cornstarch until smooth.
Gradually whisk the hot milk into the egg yolk mixture, then return to the saucepan.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the custard is very thick and pulls away from the sides of the pan.
Pour into a lined tray about 2cm deep, smooth the surface, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours until completely firm.
Cut the set custard into rectangles, dust with flour, then dip in beaten egg.
Fry in olive oil at 180C until golden on all sides, about 2 minutes.
Drain on paper towels and roll in the remaining sugar mixed with ground cinnamon while still warm.

recipes.name: Natillas
recipes.description: A velvety smooth Spanish vanilla custard flavored with lemon and cinnamon, served chilled in individual cups with a cookie on top.
instructions: Heat the milk with the lemon zest and cinnamon stick until it just begins to simmer, then remove from heat and steep for 10 minutes.
Whisk the egg yolks with sugar and cornstarch until pale and smooth.
Strain the infused milk and gradually whisk it into the egg mixture.
Return to the saucepan and cook over low heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon, until the custard thickens and coats the back of the spoon.
Stir in the vanilla extract and immediately pour into individual cups or glasses.
Press a sheet of cling film onto the surface of each custard to prevent a skin from forming.
Refrigerate for at least 4 hours until well chilled.
Serve each cup topped with a Maria cookie and a light dusting of ground cinnamon.

recipes.name: Ensalada Mixta
recipes.description: A classic Spanish mixed salad of lettuce, tomato, onion, tuna, olives, and hard-boiled egg dressed simply with olive oil and vinegar.
instructions: Hard-boil the eggs, cool, peel, and cut into quarters.
Tear the lettuce into bite-sized pieces and arrange on a large plate.
Cut the tomatoes into wedges and the onion into thin rings.
Arrange the tomato wedges, onion rings, drained tuna chunks, olives, and egg quarters over the lettuce.
Whisk together the olive oil, red wine vinegar, and salt.
Drizzle the dressing over the salad just before serving.

recipes.name: Piquillos Rellenos
recipes.description: Sweet roasted piquillo peppers stuffed with a creamy salt cod and potato filling, baked in a light tomato sauce.
instructions: Desalt the cod by soaking for 24-36 hours, changing the water several times, then poach in milk until it flakes easily.
Boil the potatoes until tender, drain, and mash smoothly.
Flake the cod and mix with the mashed potato, a drizzle of olive oil, and minced garlic to make a creamy filling.
Carefully stuff each piquillo pepper with the cod mixture, being gentle not to tear them.
For the sauce, saute diced onion in olive oil until soft, add flour, stir, then add crushed tomatoes and simmer for 10 minutes.
Place the stuffed peppers in an ovenproof dish and pour the tomato sauce around them.
Bake at 180C for 15 minutes until heated through and bubbling.
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve warm.

recipes.name: Green Curry (Gaeng Khiao Wan)
recipes.description: Aromatic Thai green curry with tender chicken, Thai eggplant, and bamboo shoots simmered in a fragrant coconut milk broth. One of the most beloved curries in Thai cuisine.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok over medium-high heat. Add green curry paste and fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Pour in half the coconut milk and stir until the oil separates from the paste.
Add chicken pieces and cook for 5 minutes until sealed on all sides.
Add remaining coconut milk, bamboo shoots, Thai eggplant, and kaffir lime leaves. Bring to a simmer.
Cook for 15 minutes until chicken is cooked through and vegetables are tender.
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar, adjusting to taste.
Stir in Thai basil leaves and sliced bird's eye chili just before serving.
Serve hot over steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Red Curry (Gaeng Daeng)
recipes.description: Rich and creamy Thai red curry with sliced pork, green beans, and red bell pepper in a coconut-based sauce. A staple comfort dish across Thailand.
instructions: Heat oil in a large pot and fry red curry paste for 2 minutes until aromatic.
Add half the coconut milk and cook, stirring constantly, until oils begin to separate.
Add sliced pork and stir-fry for 3-4 minutes until browned.
Pour in the remaining coconut milk, add green beans, sliced bell pepper, and kaffir lime leaves.
Simmer for 15-18 minutes until pork is tender and vegetables are cooked.
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar to achieve a balanced flavor.
Garnish with fresh Thai basil leaves and serve over jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Yellow Curry (Gaeng Karee)
recipes.description: Mild and aromatic Thai yellow curry with chicken, potatoes, and onions in a turmeric-tinted coconut sauce. A gentler curry influenced by Indian flavors.
instructions: Heat oil in a pot over medium heat. Saute diced onion until softened, about 3 minutes.
Add yellow curry paste and turmeric powder, frying until fragrant.
Pour in coconut milk and bring to a gentle boil.
Add cubed chicken and diced potatoes, then reduce heat to a simmer.
Cook for 25 minutes until potatoes are tender and chicken is cooked through.
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar to balance the flavors.
Serve with steamed jasmine rice or roti bread.

recipes.name: Massaman Curry (Gaeng Massaman)
recipes.description: Hearty Southern Thai curry with braised beef, potatoes, and roasted peanuts in a rich, warmly spiced coconut sauce. A unique fusion of Thai and Malay-Indian flavors.
instructions: Heat oil in a heavy pot and fry massaman curry paste with cinnamon, cardamom, and bay leaves for 2 minutes.
Add half the coconut milk and stir until oils separate from the paste.
Add beef chunks and sear on all sides for 5 minutes.
Pour in remaining coconut milk, cover, and simmer on low heat for 40 minutes.
Add quartered potatoes and halved onions. Continue cooking for 20 minutes until beef and potatoes are tender.
Stir in tamarind paste, palm sugar, fish sauce, and roasted peanuts.
Adjust seasoning and serve with steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Panang Curry (Gaeng Panang)
recipes.description: Thick and creamy Thai panang curry with sliced beef, ground peanuts, and kaffir lime in a concentrated coconut curry sauce. Richer and less soupy than other Thai curries.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok and fry panang curry paste for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Add half the coconut milk and cook until the oil separates.
Add thinly sliced beef and stir-fry for 3 minutes.
Pour in remaining coconut milk and add sliced bell pepper. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir in ground peanuts, fish sauce, and palm sugar.
Tear kaffir lime leaves and stir into the curry just before serving.
Serve over steamed jasmine rice with extra coconut cream drizzled on top.

recipes.name: Jungle Curry (Gaeng Pa)
recipes.description: Fiery and brothy Thai jungle curry made without coconut milk, packed with mixed vegetables, herbs, and wild flavors. Originating from the forests of central Thailand.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add curry paste and stir-fry for 1 minute.
Add sliced chicken and stir-fry for 3 minutes until sealed.
Pour in chicken stock and bring to a boil.
Add bamboo shoots, green beans, baby corn, Thai eggplant, and sliced grachai.
Add torn kaffir lime leaves and sliced bird's eye chilies.
Simmer for 12 minutes until chicken is cooked through and vegetables are tender.
Season with fish sauce and stir in Thai basil just before serving.
Serve immediately with steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Khao Soi (Northern Thai Curry Noodles)
recipes.description: Rich and creamy Northern Thai coconut curry noodle soup with egg noodles, topped with crispy fried noodles and pickled mustard greens. A signature dish of Chiang Mai.
instructions: Reserve a quarter of the egg noodles. Deep-fry them in oil until golden and crispy. Set aside on paper towels.
In a pot, heat 2 tbsp oil and fry red curry paste with curry powder for 2 minutes.
Add half the coconut milk and stir until oil separates.
Add chicken drumsticks and cook for 5 minutes, turning to coat.
Pour in remaining coconut milk and chicken stock. Simmer for 25 minutes until chicken is tender.
Season with fish sauce and palm sugar. Cook remaining egg noodles according to package directions.
Divide boiled noodles into bowls, ladle curry and chicken over top.
Garnish with crispy noodles, sliced shallots, pickled mustard greens, and lime wedges.

recipes.name: Pad Thai
recipes.description: Thailand's most famous stir-fried rice noodle dish with shrimp, tofu, bean sprouts, and crushed peanuts in a sweet-sour tamarind sauce. A beloved street food icon.
instructions: Soak rice noodles in warm water for 30 minutes until pliable. Drain well.
Mix tamarind paste, fish sauce, and palm sugar in a small bowl to make the sauce.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Fry minced garlic for 30 seconds.
Add shrimp and cubed tofu, stir-fry for 2 minutes until shrimp turns pink.
Push ingredients to one side, crack eggs into the wok, and scramble.
Add drained noodles and pour the sauce over. Toss everything together for 2 minutes.
Add bean sprouts, garlic chives, and dried shrimp. Toss for another minute.
Serve topped with crushed peanuts, extra bean sprouts, and lime wedges.

recipes.name: Pad See Ew
recipes.description: Smoky stir-fried wide rice noodles with Chinese broccoli, egg, and chicken in a dark soy sauce glaze. A beloved Thai street food showcasing the prized wok hei flavor.
instructions: If using dried noodles, soak in warm water for 30 minutes. Fresh noodles can be used directly.
Mix dark soy sauce, light soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar in a small bowl.
Heat oil in a wok over very high heat until smoking. Add minced garlic and fry for 15 seconds.
Add sliced chicken and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until nearly cooked.
Push chicken aside, crack eggs into the wok, and let set slightly before breaking up.
Add noodles and sauce mixture. Toss vigorously for 2 minutes to coat evenly and develop wok hei.
Add Chinese broccoli stems first, then leaves. Toss for 1 more minute.
Season with white pepper and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Pad Kra Pao (Thai Basil Stir-Fry)
recipes.description: Thailand's ultimate street food of minced pork stir-fried with holy basil, garlic, and chilies, served over rice with a fried egg. Considered the nation's everyday lunch.
instructions: Pound garlic and bird's eye chilies together in a mortar until roughly crushed.
Heat oil in a wok over very high heat. Add the garlic-chili mixture and fry for 30 seconds.
Add minced pork and stir-fry, breaking it apart, for 3-4 minutes until cooked through.
Add fish sauce, oyster sauce, dark soy sauce, and sugar. Stir-fry for 1 minute.
Turn off heat and fold in holy basil leaves, letting them wilt from residual heat.
In a separate pan, fry eggs in oil until edges are crispy but yolk is still runny.
Serve the stir-fry over steamed jasmine rice, topped with the fried egg.

recipes.name: Pad Pak Ruam (Stir-Fried Mixed Vegetables)
recipes.description: Colorful Thai stir-fried mixed vegetables with garlic and oyster sauce, a healthy and quick everyday dish. A versatile side that accompanies almost any Thai meal.
instructions: Wash and cut all vegetables into bite-sized pieces. Slice carrots on the diagonal.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add minced garlic and fry for 30 seconds.
Add carrots and baby corn first as they take longest to cook. Stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Add mushrooms, Chinese broccoli stems, and snow peas. Stir-fry for 2 more minutes.
Add Chinese broccoli leaves, oyster sauce, soy sauce, and sugar.
Toss everything together for 1-2 minutes until vegetables are tender-crisp.
Serve immediately as a side dish with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Cashew Chicken (Gai Pad Med Mamuang)
recipes.description: Thai stir-fried chicken with roasted cashew nuts, dried chilies, and onions in a savory-sweet sauce. A popular dish that balances crunch with tender chicken.
instructions: Cut chicken into bite-sized cubes. Dice onion and bell pepper. Slice spring onions.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Fry dried chilies for 30 seconds until darkened.
Add minced garlic and stir-fry for 15 seconds until fragrant.
Add chicken pieces and stir-fry for 4 minutes until golden and cooked through.
Add onion and bell pepper, cooking for 2 minutes until slightly softened.
Add oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar. Toss to combine.
Stir in cashew nuts and spring onions. Toss for 30 seconds.
Serve immediately over steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Ginger Chicken (Gai Pad King)
recipes.description: Simple yet flavorful Thai stir-fried chicken with generous amounts of julienned ginger, cloud ear mushrooms, and a light soy-based sauce.
instructions: Soak cloud ear mushrooms in warm water for 15 minutes. Drain and slice.
Julienne the ginger into thin matchstick strips. Slice chicken into thin strips.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add minced garlic and stir-fry for 30 seconds.
Add chicken strips and stir-fry for 3 minutes until nearly cooked.
Add ginger, mushrooms, and sliced onion. Stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Season with soy sauce, oyster sauce, soybean paste, and sugar. Toss well.
Garnish with sliced spring onions and serve with steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Tom Yum Goong (Spicy Shrimp Soup)
recipes.description: Thailand's iconic hot and sour shrimp soup perfumed with lemongrass, galangal, and kaffir lime leaves. A masterful balance of spicy, sour, salty, and sweet flavors.
instructions: Peel and devein shrimp, reserving heads and shells. Bruise lemongrass stalks and cut into 2-inch pieces.
Boil water with shrimp heads and shells for 5 minutes to make stock. Strain and discard shells.
Add lemongrass, sliced galangal, torn kaffir lime leaves, and crushed bird's eye chilies to the stock.
Simmer for 5 minutes until the broth is highly aromatic.
Add halved straw mushrooms and cook for 2 minutes.
Add shrimp and cook for 2-3 minutes until they turn pink and curl.
Remove from heat. Stir in fish sauce, lime juice, and nam prik pao.
Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Tom Kha Gai (Coconut Chicken Soup)
recipes.description: Silky Thai coconut soup with chicken, galangal, and mushrooms in a creamy, aromatic broth. A gentler cousin of tom yum with the richness of coconut milk.
instructions: Slice galangal thinly. Bruise lemongrass and cut into 2-inch pieces. Tear kaffir lime leaves.
Bring chicken stock and coconut milk to a gentle boil in a pot.
Add galangal, lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, and crushed chilies. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Add sliced chicken breast and cook for 8 minutes until cooked through.
Add torn oyster mushrooms and simmer for 3 more minutes.
Remove from heat. Season with fish sauce, lime juice, and palm sugar.
Garnish with cilantro leaves and serve with steamed jasmine rice on the side.

recipes.name: Gaeng Jued (Thai Clear Soup)
recipes.description: Light and nourishing Thai clear soup with minced pork, tofu, and glass noodles in a delicate pork broth. A comforting everyday soup served at family meals.
instructions: Soak glass noodles in warm water for 10 minutes. Drain and cut into short lengths.
Pound garlic and cilantro root together in a mortar. Mix into the minced pork with a pinch of pepper.
Bring pork stock to a boil. Roll small balls of the seasoned minced pork and drop into the stock.
Simmer for 5 minutes until pork balls are cooked through.
Add cubed tofu, chopped napa cabbage, and glass noodles.
Cook for 3-4 minutes until cabbage is tender and noodles are translucent.
Season with soy sauce and white pepper. Garnish with cilantro and serve hot.

recipes.name: Khao Tom (Thai Rice Soup)
recipes.description: Gentle Thai rice soup with pork, ginger, and soft-cooked rice in a clear broth, commonly eaten for breakfast. A soothing dish beloved across all regions of Thailand.
instructions: Bring pork stock to a boil with sliced ginger and cilantro root.
Season minced pork with a splash of soy sauce and pepper. Form into small balls.
Drop pork balls into the simmering stock and cook for 5 minutes.
Add the cooked jasmine rice and stir to combine.
Simmer for 10 minutes until the rice softens and the soup thickens slightly.
Season with fish sauce and white pepper to taste.
Serve in bowls topped with cilantro leaves and crispy fried garlic.

recipes.name: Som Tum (Green Papaya Salad)
recipes.description: Vibrant Thai green papaya salad pounded in a mortar with chilies, lime, fish sauce, and tomatoes. The quintessential Isaan dish with an electrifying balance of flavors.
instructions: Peel green papaya and shred into thin strips using a knife or special shredder.
Pound garlic and bird's eye chilies together in a large clay mortar until crushed.
Add green beans cut into 1-inch pieces and lightly bruise them.
Add dried shrimp and peanuts, pounding lightly to crush.
Add shredded papaya and bruise it gently with the pestle, turning with a spoon.
Add halved cherry tomatoes and squeeze gently.
Season with fish sauce, lime juice, and palm sugar. Toss and pound lightly to combine.
Taste and adjust the balance of sour, salty, sweet, and spicy. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Larb Moo (Spicy Minced Pork Salad)
recipes.description: Zesty Isaan minced pork salad with toasted rice powder, mint, shallots, and a fiery lime-chili dressing. The national dish of Laos also beloved in Northeastern Thailand.
instructions: Heat a pan over medium heat. Cook minced pork with a splash of chicken stock, breaking it up.
Cook for 5-7 minutes until pork is cooked through. Remove from heat and let cool slightly.
Transfer pork to a mixing bowl. Add fish sauce, lime juice, and chili flakes.
Add thinly sliced shallots, chopped spring onions, and toasted rice powder.
Toss everything together until well combined.
Fold in fresh mint leaves and cilantro just before serving.
Serve at room temperature with fresh cabbage leaves and sticky rice.

recipes.name: Yum Woon Sen (Glass Noodle Salad)
recipes.description: Tangy Thai glass noodle salad with shrimp, minced pork, celery, and onions in a spicy lime dressing. A refreshing dish served at room temperature.
instructions: Soak glass noodles in hot water for 5 minutes until soft. Drain and cut into shorter lengths.
Blanch shrimp in boiling water for 2 minutes until pink. Remove and set aside.
Cook minced pork in the same boiling water for 3 minutes. Drain.
Make the dressing by mixing fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, and sliced bird's eye chilies.
Combine glass noodles, shrimp, pork, sliced celery, thinly sliced onion, and halved tomatoes in a bowl.
Pour the dressing over and toss thoroughly to combine.
Garnish with cilantro and serve at room temperature.

recipes.name: Nam Tok Moo (Waterfall Pork Salad)
recipes.description: Smoky Isaan grilled pork salad with toasted rice powder, herbs, and a spicy-sour dressing. Named for the way meat juices drip like a waterfall onto the charcoal.
instructions: Grill pork neck over high charcoal heat for 5-7 minutes per side until cooked with a slight char.
Let the pork rest for 5 minutes, then slice thinly against the grain.
In a large bowl, mix fish sauce, lime juice, and chili flakes to make the dressing.
Add the sliced pork while still warm, allowing it to absorb the dressing.
Add thinly sliced shallots, chopped spring onions, and toasted rice powder.
Toss well, then fold in mint leaves and cilantro.
Serve immediately with sticky rice and fresh cabbage leaves.

recipes.name: Yum Pla Duk Foo (Crispy Catfish Salad)
recipes.description: Fluffy deep-fried catfish flakes served with a spicy green mango salad on the side. A popular Thai bar snack with a wonderful contrast of textures.
instructions: Steam or grill catfish until cooked through. Let cool, then flake the meat finely with a fork.
Spread flaked catfish on a tray and let it dry slightly for 10 minutes.
Heat oil to 180C. Deep-fry the catfish flakes in batches until golden and crispy. Drain on paper towels.
For the salad, shred green mango into thin strips.
Mix fish sauce, lime juice, palm sugar, and sliced bird's eye chilies for the dressing.
Toss green mango with dressing, sliced shallots, and crushed peanuts.
Arrange crispy catfish on a plate and top with the green mango salad. Garnish with cilantro.

recipes.name: Khao Pad (Thai Fried Rice)
recipes.description: Classic Thai fried rice with egg, onion, and spring onion, seasoned simply with fish sauce and white pepper. A staple comfort food found at every street stall in Thailand.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add minced garlic and fry for 15 seconds.
Add diced chicken and stir-fry for 3 minutes until cooked through.
Push chicken aside, crack eggs into the wok, and scramble quickly.
Add diced onion and stir-fry for 1 minute.
Add the day-old rice, breaking up any clumps. Stir-fry for 3 minutes.
Season with fish sauce, soy sauce, and white pepper. Toss well.
Add sliced spring onions and give a final toss.
Serve with cucumber slices, lime wedge, and sliced bird's eye chili in fish sauce.

recipes.name: Khao Man Gai (Thai Chicken Rice)
recipes.description: Silky poached chicken served over fragrant chicken-fat rice with a pungent ginger-chili dipping sauce. Thailand's version of Hainanese chicken rice.
instructions: Stuff the chicken cavity with ginger slices and cilantro roots. Poach in simmering water for 35 minutes.
Remove chicken and plunge into ice water to tighten the skin. Reserve the poaching broth.
Cook jasmine rice using chicken broth instead of water, adding chicken fat and minced garlic.
Make the dipping sauce by blending ginger, garlic, bird's eye chilies, fermented soybean sauce, vinegar, and dark soy sauce.
Chop the chicken into pieces through the bone, Thai-style.
Arrange chicken over the chicken-fat rice with sliced cucumber.
Serve with the ginger-chili sauce, a bowl of the poaching broth, and cilantro.

recipes.name: Pineapple Fried Rice (Khao Pad Sapparot)
recipes.description: Sweet and savory Thai fried rice with pineapple chunks, shrimp, cashews, and curry powder, served in a hollowed pineapple shell. A festive dish popular with visitors.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add diced onion and stir-fry for 1 minute.
Add shrimp and stir-fry for 2 minutes until pink.
Push ingredients aside, crack egg into the wok, and scramble.
Add rice and curry powder. Stir-fry for 3 minutes, tossing to coat evenly.
Add pineapple chunks, cashew nuts, and raisins. Toss for 1 minute.
Season with fish sauce, soy sauce, and sugar. Mix well.
Serve in a hollowed-out pineapple shell for presentation.

recipes.name: Basil Fried Rice (Khao Pad Kra Pao)
recipes.description: Spicy Thai fried rice with holy basil, minced chicken, and chili, inspired by the classic pad kra pao. A satisfying one-plate meal with big, bold flavors.
instructions: Pound garlic and bird's eye chilies in a mortar until roughly crushed.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Fry the garlic-chili mixture for 30 seconds.
Add minced chicken and stir-fry for 3 minutes until cooked.
Add rice and toss vigorously over high heat for 2 minutes.
Season with fish sauce, oyster sauce, and dark soy sauce.
Fold in holy basil leaves and toss until wilted.
Fry eggs separately until crispy-edged and serve on top of the fried rice.

recipes.name: Boat Noodles (Kuay Teow Reua)
recipes.description: Intensely flavored Thai boat noodle soup with pork in a dark, aromatic broth enriched with five-spice. Originally served from canal boats in Bangkok.
instructions: Simmer pork ribs in pork stock with cinnamon, star anise, and five-spice powder for 30 minutes.
Remove ribs and shred the meat. Strain the broth and return to pot.
Add dark soy sauce, fish sauce, and palm sugar to the broth. Adjust seasoning.
Blanch rice noodles in boiling water for 30 seconds. Drain into serving bowls.
Quickly blanch bean sprouts and morning glory. Add to bowls.
Briefly cook thin pork slices in the simmering broth. Ladle broth and pork over noodles.
Top with shredded rib meat, fried garlic, and a sprinkle of white pepper.
Serve with crushed peanuts, chili flakes, sugar, and fish sauce on the side for self-seasoning.

recipes.name: Kuay Teow (Thai Noodle Soup)
recipes.description: Classic Thai clear noodle soup with chicken, bean sprouts, and fresh herbs. The everyday noodle bowl found on every street corner in Thailand.
instructions: Bring chicken stock to a boil with crushed garlic cloves.
Add sliced chicken breast and poach for 8 minutes until cooked. Remove and slice.
Season the broth with soy sauce, fish sauce, and white pepper.
Blanch rice noodles in boiling water until tender. Drain into bowls.
Add bean sprouts and chopped Chinese celery to the bowls.
Arrange sliced chicken on top and ladle hot broth over everything.
Garnish with cilantro, fried garlic, and white pepper. Serve with condiment tray.

recipes.name: Rad Na (Noodles in Gravy)
recipes.description: Wide rice noodles smothered in a thick, savory gravy with Chinese broccoli and pork. A comforting Thai-Chinese noodle dish with a silky sauce.
instructions: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a wok over very high heat. Add noodles and dark soy sauce, charring slightly. Set aside on plates.
In the same wok, heat remaining oil. Add minced garlic and fry for 30 seconds.
Add sliced pork and stir-fry for 3 minutes until nearly cooked.
Add Chinese broccoli and stir-fry for 1 minute.
Pour in chicken stock, oyster sauce, soy sauce, and fermented soybean sauce. Bring to a boil.
Mix tapioca starch with 3 tbsp water and stir into the sauce to thicken.
Pour the thick gravy over the charred noodles and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Satay (Chicken Satay with Peanut Sauce)
recipes.description: Tender marinated chicken skewers grilled over charcoal and served with a rich peanut dipping sauce and cucumber relish. A beloved Thai street food appetizer.
instructions: Slice chicken into thin strips and marinate with coconut milk, turmeric, curry powder, and finely minced lemongrass for at least 1 hour.
Thread marinated chicken onto soaked bamboo skewers.
For the peanut sauce, heat red curry paste in a pan, add coconut milk, crushed peanuts, palm sugar, tamarind paste, and fish sauce. Simmer until thickened.
Make cucumber relish by mixing diced cucumber with vinegar, sugar, and sliced shallots.
Grill satay skewers over charcoal or high heat for 3-4 minutes per side, basting with coconut milk.
Serve the golden skewers with peanut sauce and cucumber relish on the side.

recipes.name: Moo Ping (Grilled Pork Skewers)
recipes.description: Sweet and savory Thai grilled pork skewers marinated in garlic, coconut milk, and palm sugar, charred over hot coals. An irresistible morning street food staple.
instructions: Slice pork neck into thin, flat pieces against the grain.
Pound garlic and cilantro root in a mortar until a paste forms.
Mix the paste with coconut milk, oyster sauce, fish sauce, palm sugar, and white pepper.
Marinate the pork in this mixture for at least 2 hours, preferably overnight.
Thread pork onto soaked bamboo skewers and grill over medium-high charcoal heat.
Grill for 3-4 minutes per side, basting with reserved marinade, until caramelized.
Serve with sticky rice and nam jim jaew dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Tod Mun Pla (Thai Fish Cakes)
recipes.description: Bouncy and aromatic Thai fish cakes made with red curry paste, green beans, and kaffir lime leaves. A beloved appetizer with a springy, satisfying texture.
instructions: Blend fish fillet in a food processor until it forms a smooth, sticky paste.
Add red curry paste, egg, fish sauce, and palm sugar. Blend until combined.
Transfer to a bowl. Stir in very thinly sliced green beans and finely shredded kaffir lime leaves.
Wet your hands and shape the mixture into small flat patties.
Heat oil to 170C and deep-fry fish cakes in batches for 3-4 minutes until golden brown.
Make a cucumber relish with diced cucumber, vinegar, sugar, crushed peanuts, and sliced chili.
Serve the hot fish cakes with the cucumber relish.

recipes.name: Gai Yang (Thai Grilled Chicken)
recipes.description: Juicy Thai grilled chicken marinated in garlic, lemongrass, cilantro root, and fish sauce, charred over coals. The definitive Isaan street chicken of Northeast Thailand.
instructions: Spatchcock the chicken by removing the backbone and pressing flat.
Pound garlic, cilantro root, white peppercorns, and finely sliced lemongrass into a paste.
Mix the paste with fish sauce, oyster sauce, palm sugar, and coconut milk.
Rub the marinade all over the chicken, getting under the skin. Marinate for at least 4 hours.
Grill over medium-low charcoal heat for 15-18 minutes per side until golden and cooked through.
Rest for 5 minutes, then chop into pieces.
Serve with sticky rice, nam jim jaew dipping sauce, and fresh herbs.

recipes.name: Mango Sticky Rice (Khao Niao Mamuang)
recipes.description: Thailand's most famous dessert of sweet sticky rice soaked in coconut cream served with slices of ripe mango. A perfect harmony of tropical flavors and textures.
instructions: Soak sticky rice in cold water for at least 4 hours or overnight. Drain well.
Steam the rice in a bamboo steamer lined with cheesecloth for 20-25 minutes until tender.
Heat 300ml coconut milk with sugar and salt until dissolved. Do not boil.
Pour the warm sweet coconut milk over the hot steamed rice. Stir and cover for 15 minutes to absorb.
Peel and slice the ripe mangoes into elegant pieces.
Serve sticky rice on a plate with mango slices alongside.
Drizzle with remaining coconut cream and sprinkle with toasted mung beans.

recipes.name: Roti with Condensed Milk
recipes.description: Crispy, flaky Thai street-style roti drizzled with sweetened condensed milk and sugar. A popular dessert snack adapted from Muslim Thai communities in the south.
instructions: Mix flour with salt and a tablespoon of sugar. Add water gradually and knead into a smooth, elastic dough.
Divide dough into balls and coat with oil. Rest for at least 30 minutes.
Flatten each ball by stretching and spinning it paper-thin on an oiled surface.
Fold the stretched dough into a square parcel.
Fry on a hot, well-oiled flat griddle with butter until golden and crispy on both sides.
Chop the cooked roti into pieces on the griddle.
Drizzle generously with sweetened condensed milk and sprinkle with sugar. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Pla Rad Prik (Fried Fish with Chili Sauce)
recipes.description: Crispy deep-fried whole fish topped with a tangy, sweet, and spicy three-flavored sauce. A showstopping Thai dish that balances all taste elements beautifully.
instructions: Score the fish with deep diagonal cuts on both sides. Pat dry and dust with rice flour.
Heat oil to 180C and deep-fry the fish for 7-8 minutes per side until golden and crispy. Drain and place on a platter.
In a separate pan, fry sliced garlic, shallots, and crushed chilies in 2 tbsp oil until fragrant.
Add tamarind paste, palm sugar, and fish sauce. Simmer until the sauce thickens and becomes glossy.
Taste the sauce and adjust to balance sweet, sour, salty, and spicy.
Pour the hot sauce over the crispy fried fish.
Garnish with cilantro leaves and serve immediately with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Goong Ob Woon Sen (Shrimp Baked with Glass Noodles)
recipes.description: Succulent shrimp baked in a clay pot with glass noodles, ginger, garlic, and a savory soy-sesame sauce. A fragrant one-pot dish with incredible depth of flavor.
instructions: Soak glass noodles in warm water for 10 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Pound garlic, cilantro root, and white peppercorns into a paste.
Line a clay pot with the soaked glass noodles. Arrange shrimp on top.
Spread the garlic-pepper paste over the shrimp. Layer sliced ginger on top.
Mix oyster sauce, soy sauce, sesame oil, and chicken stock. Pour over the shrimp.
Dot with butter, cover the pot, and bake at 200C for 15-18 minutes until shrimp are pink and noodles have absorbed the sauce.
Garnish with chopped Chinese celery and serve straight from the clay pot.

recipes.name: Steamed Fish with Lime (Pla Neung Manao)
recipes.description: Delicately steamed whole fish bathed in a fiery lime, garlic, and chili sauce. A healthy and intensely flavored dish showcasing the Thai love of sour and spicy.
instructions: Score the fish with shallow cuts on both sides. Place on a steaming plate.
Lay bruised lemongrass and cilantro root on and around the fish.
Steam over high heat for 12-15 minutes until the fish is just cooked through.
Pound garlic and bird's eye chilies roughly in a mortar.
Mix with lime juice, fish sauce, and palm sugar to create the dressing.
Pour the spicy lime dressing over the steamed fish.
Garnish with cilantro and serve immediately with steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Hor Mok (Thai Steamed Fish Curry)
recipes.description: Silky Thai steamed fish curry custard with red curry paste, coconut cream, and Thai basil, traditionally steamed in banana leaf cups. An elegant and aromatic dish.
instructions: Slice fish into thin pieces. Mix red curry paste with half the coconut cream, egg, fish sauce, and palm sugar.
Fold the fish into the curry mixture until well coated.
Line banana leaf cups or ramekins with napa cabbage leaves.
Place Thai basil leaves on the cabbage, then spoon the fish curry mixture on top.
Top each cup with a spoonful of reserved coconut cream, shredded kaffir lime leaves, and sliced red chili.
Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutes until the custard is set and fish is cooked.
Serve warm directly in the banana leaf cups.

recipes.name: Tub Tim Krob (Red Rubies Dessert)
recipes.description: Jewel-like Thai dessert of crunchy water chestnut rubies in sweet coconut milk over crushed ice. A refreshing treat with a delightful chewy-crunchy texture.
instructions: Dice water chestnuts into small cubes and toss with red food coloring until evenly coated.
Toss the colored chestnuts in tapioca starch until completely coated.
Boil a pot of water and cook the coated chestnuts for 2-3 minutes until they float and become translucent.
Transfer immediately to ice water to stop cooking and firm up.
Heat coconut milk with sugar, salt, and jasmine water until sugar dissolves. Chill.
To serve, place drained red rubies in a bowl with crushed ice.
Pour the sweet coconut milk over and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Kluay Buat Chi (Bananas in Coconut Milk)
recipes.description: Warm Thai dessert of ripe bananas gently simmered in sweetened coconut milk with a hint of salt. A simple, comforting sweet enjoyed across Thailand.
instructions: Peel bananas and cut each in half lengthwise, then crosswise.
Bring coconut milk to a gentle simmer with the knotted pandan leaf.
Add sugar and salt, stirring until dissolved.
Add banana pieces and cook gently for 5-7 minutes until just tender but not mushy.
Remove the pandan leaf.
Serve warm in small bowls, ladling the sweet coconut milk over the bananas.

recipes.name: Sangkaya (Coconut Custard)
recipes.description: Rich and silky Thai coconut custard steamed in a pumpkin or individual cups, perfumed with pandan. A classic Thai dessert with a luscious, smooth texture.
instructions: Melt palm sugar with a splash of water over low heat until dissolved. Strain and cool slightly.
Whisk eggs gently, avoiding creating bubbles.
Stir coconut cream, melted palm sugar, and salt into the eggs until smooth.
Strain the mixture through a fine sieve for silkiness.
Pour into small heatproof cups or a hollowed-out pumpkin.
Steam over medium heat for 25-30 minutes until custard is set but still jiggly in the center.
Let cool to room temperature before serving. Can be chilled for a firmer texture.

recipes.name: Coconut Ice Cream (I-Tim Kati)
