recipes.description: Creamy Thai coconut ice cream served in a coconut shell with peanuts, corn, and sticky rice. A beloved street dessert churned fresh at market stalls.
instructions: Heat coconut milk and coconut cream with sugar and salt until sugar dissolves. Cool completely.
Pour the mixture into an ice cream maker and churn according to manufacturer instructions.
If no machine, pour into a container and freeze, stirring vigorously every 30 minutes for 3-4 hours.
Scoop the ice cream into coconut shell halves or bowls.
Top with crushed roasted peanuts, sweet corn, sliced palm seeds, and a spoonful of sticky rice.
Serve immediately before it melts.

recipes.name: Foi Thong (Golden Threads)
recipes.description: Delicate golden threads of egg yolk drizzled into sugar syrup, a Thai royal dessert of Portuguese origin. An auspicious sweet served at celebrations and ceremonies.
instructions: Strain egg yolks through a fine sieve to remove any chalazae. Gently stir without creating bubbles.
Make a sugar syrup by boiling sugar and water together until it reaches a light syrup consistency.
Add jasmine water to the syrup for fragrance.
Transfer egg yolks to a piping cone or squeeze bottle with a very fine tip.
Drizzle thin streams of egg yolk in a circular motion into the simmering syrup.
Cook the threads for about 1 minute, then carefully lift out and fold into neat bundles.
Repeat until all yolk is used. Arrange the golden bundles on a serving plate.

recipes.name: Nam Jim Jaew (Isaan Dipping Sauce)
recipes.description: Smoky and tangy Isaan dipping sauce made with roasted chili flakes, toasted rice powder, and tamarind. The essential condiment for grilled meats and sticky rice.
instructions: Mix fish sauce, lime juice, and tamarind paste in a bowl until the palm sugar dissolves.
Add dried chili flakes and toasted rice powder. Stir to combine.
Finely slice shallots and spring onion. Add to the sauce.
Chop cilantro and stir in.
Taste and adjust the balance of sour, salty, sweet, and spicy.
Serve as a dipping sauce alongside grilled meats, sticky rice, and fresh vegetables.

recipes.name: Sticky Rice (Khao Niao)
recipes.description: Perfectly steamed Thai glutinous rice, the staple carbohydrate of Isaan and Northern Thailand. Eaten by hand in small rolled balls alongside curries and grilled dishes.
instructions: Rinse sticky rice until the water runs clear.
Soak the rice in cold water for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
Drain the rice thoroughly.
Line a bamboo steamer basket with cheesecloth and spread the rice evenly.
Steam over boiling water for 15-20 minutes, flipping the rice halfway through.
Transfer to a traditional Thai sticky rice basket or a covered container.
Serve warm, pinching off small portions by hand to eat with dishes.

recipes.name: Jasmine Rice (Khao Hom Mali)
recipes.description: Fragrant Thai jasmine rice, perfectly fluffy and aromatic, the essential accompaniment to Thai curries and stir-fries. A foundation of Central and Southern Thai cuisine.
instructions: Rinse jasmine rice in cold water 2-3 times until the water is mostly clear.
Combine rice and water in a pot with a tight-fitting lid.
Bring to a boil over high heat, then immediately reduce to the lowest setting.
Cover and cook for 12 minutes without lifting the lid.
Remove from heat and let stand, covered, for 10 minutes to finish steaming.
Fluff gently with a fork or rice paddle and serve.

recipes.name: Thai Iced Tea (Cha Yen)
recipes.description: Vibrant orange Thai iced tea made from strongly brewed Thai tea mix, sweetened with sugar and poured over ice with evaporated milk. A refreshing street drink icon.
instructions: Bring water to a boil and add Thai tea mix. Steep for 5 minutes.
Strain the tea through a cloth filter or fine strainer.
Add sugar while the tea is still hot, stirring until dissolved.
Let the tea cool to room temperature, then chill in the refrigerator.
Fill tall glasses with ice cubes and pour the chilled tea to three-quarters full.
Slowly pour evaporated milk over the back of a spoon to create a layered effect.
Stir before drinking and serve with a straw.

recipes.name: Pad Woon Sen (Stir-Fried Glass Noodles)
recipes.description: Savory stir-fried glass noodles with egg, vegetables, and a light soy sauce seasoning. A quick Thai-Chinese home-cooking favorite with a springy noodle texture.
instructions: Soak glass noodles in warm water for 10 minutes. Drain and cut into shorter lengths.
Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add minced garlic and fry for 30 seconds.
Add shrimp and stir-fry for 2 minutes until pink.
Push to one side, crack eggs and scramble in the wok.
Add sliced carrot and napa cabbage. Stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Add glass noodles, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and white pepper. Toss for 2 minutes until noodles are heated through.
Add sliced spring onions, toss once more, and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Gaeng Som (Sour Curry)
recipes.description: Tangy Southern Thai sour curry with shrimp and vegetables in a turmeric-tinted tamarind broth without coconut milk. A brightly flavored, everyday comfort curry.
instructions: Pound dried chilies, shallots, shrimp paste, and sliced turmeric into a smooth curry paste.
Bring water to a boil and dissolve the curry paste into it, stirring well.
Add tamarind paste, palm sugar, and fish sauce. Adjust the sour-sweet-salty balance.
Add chopped Chinese cabbage and green beans cut into 2-inch pieces.
Cook for 5 minutes until vegetables are nearly tender.
Add shrimp and cook for 3 minutes until pink and curled.
Serve hot over steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Khao Kluk Kapi (Shrimp Paste Fried Rice)
recipes.description: Fragrant Thai shrimp paste fried rice served with an array of sweet, sour, and crunchy toppings. A complex one-plate meal with multiple contrasting elements.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok. Fry shrimp paste for 1 minute until fragrant and darkened.
Add day-old rice and stir-fry vigorously for 3-4 minutes until rice is well coated and heated through.
Season with a pinch of palm sugar. Set the rice aside on plates.
In separate batches, fry thin omelet strips, sliced Chinese sausage, and crispy fried shallots.
Shred the green mango into thin strips.
Arrange all toppings around the shrimp paste rice: omelet strips, sausage, fried shallots, dried shrimp, sliced chili, green mango, and lime wedge.
Mix all elements together before eating for the full flavor experience.

recipes.name: Gaeng Liang (Vegetable Curry with Shrimp Paste)
recipes.description: Peppery Thai vegetable soup with shrimp paste, lemon basil, and an abundance of fresh vegetables. A nutritious, herbaceous dish praised for its health benefits.
instructions: Pound shallots, white peppercorns, and shrimp paste together into a rough paste.
Bring water to a boil and stir in the shrimp paste mixture.
Add diced pumpkin and cook for 5 minutes until partially tender.
Add sliced luffa gourd and baby corn. Cook for 3 minutes.
Add shrimp and cook for 2-3 minutes until pink.
Season with fish sauce and stir in lemon basil leaves.
Serve hot over steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Kai Jeow (Thai Omelet)
recipes.description: Puffy, crispy-edged Thai omelet fried in a generous amount of oil and served over jasmine rice with chili fish sauce. The ultimate Thai comfort food made in minutes.
instructions: Beat eggs vigorously with fish sauce, lime juice, and white pepper until very frothy.
Add finely sliced spring onion to the egg mixture.
Heat oil in a wok over very high heat until smoking hot.
Pour in the egg mixture all at once. It should puff up dramatically.
Let cook undisturbed for 1 minute until the bottom is golden and crispy.
Flip and cook for another 30 seconds.
Slide onto a plate of steamed jasmine rice. Serve with sriracha or chili-fish sauce.

recipes.name: Pla Muek Tod Kratiam (Fried Squid with Garlic and Pepper)
recipes.description: Crispy deep-fried squid coated with golden garlic and cracked white pepper. A beloved Thai bar snack and seafood restaurant staple with an addictive crunch.
instructions: Score squid tubes in a crosshatch pattern and cut into pieces. Pat completely dry.
Pound garlic, cilantro root, and white peppercorns into a coarse paste.
Mix rice flour and tapioca starch together. Toss squid pieces in the flour mixture.
Heat oil to 180C. Deep-fry squid in batches for 2-3 minutes until golden and crispy.
In a separate pan, fry the garlic-pepper paste in 2 tbsp oil until golden and fragrant.
Toss the crispy squid with the fried garlic mixture, fish sauce, and sugar.
Serve immediately with lime wedges and sweet chili sauce.

recipes.name: Phanaeng Neua (Dry Red Curry with Beef)
recipes.description: Thick and concentrated Southern Thai dry curry with slow-braised beef in a rich coconut and peanut sauce. An intensely flavored curry served with just a thin layer of sauce.
instructions: Slice beef brisket into thin pieces across the grain.
In a heavy pot, heat coconut cream over medium heat until oil separates. Fry red curry paste for 3 minutes.
Add beef slices and stir to coat with the curry paste. Cook for 5 minutes.
Add coconut milk and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook for 35 minutes until beef is very tender.
Stir in ground peanuts, palm sugar, fish sauce, and tamarind paste.
Cook uncovered for 5 more minutes until the sauce thickens and concentrates.
Garnish with thinly sliced kaffir lime leaves, Thai basil, and sliced red chili.
Serve with steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Iskender Kebab
recipes.description: Thinly sliced lamb doner served over cubed pide bread, drenched in rich tomato sauce and topped with melted butter and yogurt. A beloved specialty from Bursa.
instructions: Season the lamb leg with salt, black pepper, and olive oil, then roast at 200C for 35 minutes until cooked through.
Dice the tomatoes, cook with tomato paste and garlic over medium heat for 15 minutes to make a thick sauce, and season with salt.
Slice the roasted lamb thinly against the grain.
Cut the pide bread into bite-sized cubes and arrange on a serving platter.
Layer the sliced lamb over the pide bread and spoon the hot tomato sauce generously on top.
Melt the butter in a small pan until it begins to foam and turn slightly golden.
Add a dollop of yogurt on the side, drizzle the foaming butter over everything, and garnish with Aleppo pepper and charred green peppers.

recipes.name: Adana Kebab
recipes.description: Spicy hand-minced lamb kebab from Adana, seasoned with Aleppo pepper and tail fat, grilled on wide flat skewers over charcoal. Served with lavash, grilled vegetables, and sumac onions.
instructions: Hand-mince the lamb and tail fat together using a zirh (mezzaluna knife) until the mixture is very finely chopped and pasty.
Knead the meat with Aleppo pepper, minced garlic, and salt for at least 10 minutes until the mixture becomes sticky and cohesive.
Refrigerate the meat mixture for 30 minutes, then mould onto wide flat metal skewers in long, flat sausage shapes.
Grill over hot charcoal, turning frequently, for about 12-15 minutes until charred on the outside and cooked through.
Slice onions into thin rings, toss with sumac and a pinch of salt, and set aside.
Grill the tomatoes and green peppers alongside the kebabs until charred.
Serve the kebabs on lavash bread with grilled vegetables, sumac onions, and fresh parsley.

recipes.name: Doner Kebab
recipes.description: Marinated layers of seasoned lamb and beef stacked on a vertical rotisserie, slowly roasted and shaved into thin slices. The iconic Turkish street food served in bread with fresh vegetables.
instructions: Slice the lamb and beef very thinly against the grain and place in a large bowl.
Grate the onions, mix with yogurt, olive oil, minced garlic, cumin, paprika, Aleppo pepper, salt, and black pepper to create a marinade.
Coat all the meat slices thoroughly in the marinade, cover, and refrigerate for at least 6 hours or overnight.
Layer the marinated meat slices onto a vertical spit, alternating lamb and beef, pressing firmly.
Roast on the vertical rotisserie (or in the oven at 200C), basting occasionally, for about 2 hours.
Shave thin slices from the outer layer as it cooks and crisps.
Warm the pide bread, slice tomatoes, and serve the shaved doner meat in the bread with fresh vegetables.

recipes.name: Lahmacun
recipes.description: Paper-thin crispy flatbread topped with a spiced mixture of minced lamb, tomatoes, peppers, and herbs. Often called Turkish pizza, it is rolled up with fresh parsley, lemon juice, and sumac onions.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water, mix with flour, salt, and olive oil, and knead into a smooth dough; rest for 30 minutes.
Finely chop the onion, tomatoes, and peppers (or pulse in a food processor) and mix with the lamb mince.
Season the meat mixture with tomato paste, Aleppo pepper, salt, and chopped parsley, mixing until well combined.
Divide the dough into 8 small balls and roll each one out paper-thin on a floured surface.
Spread a thin, even layer of the meat mixture over each round of dough, reaching the edges.
Bake in a preheated oven at 250C for 8-10 minutes until the edges are crispy and the meat is cooked.
Serve immediately with fresh parsley, lemon wedges, and a sprinkle of sumac; roll up to eat.

recipes.name: Pide
recipes.description: Boat-shaped Turkish flatbread with a soft, chewy crust, filled with a savory mixture of ground lamb, cheese, and egg. Often called Turkish pizza, each region has its own signature filling.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water, combine with flour, olive oil, and salt, and knead into a soft elastic dough; let rise for 1 hour.
Sauté diced onion and green pepper, then mix with lamb mince, diced tomato, Aleppo pepper, salt, and black pepper.
Divide the risen dough into 4 portions and roll each into an oval shape about 30cm long.
Place the meat filling down the center of each oval, then fold and pinch the two long edges up to form a boat shape, pinching the ends to points.
Top with grated kashar cheese and bake at 230C for 12-15 minutes until golden and puffed.
Crack an egg into the center of each pide during the last 3 minutes of baking if desired.
Brush the edges with melted butter as soon as they come out of the oven and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Manti
recipes.description: Tiny handmade dumplings filled with spiced lamb, boiled and served with garlicky yogurt sauce and a drizzle of Aleppo pepper butter. A labor of love from Kayseri that rewards patience.
instructions: Mix flour, eggs, salt, and water to form a firm dough; knead for 10 minutes until smooth, then rest covered for 30 minutes.
Combine lamb mince with finely grated onion, salt, and black pepper for the filling.
Roll the dough out very thinly and cut into 2cm squares.
Place a tiny amount of filling in the center of each square and pinch the four corners together to seal into small parcels.
Boil the manti in salted water for about 15-20 minutes until the dough is tender and the filling is cooked.
Mix yogurt with minced garlic and a pinch of salt to make the yogurt sauce.
Melt butter in a small pan, stir in Aleppo pepper and dried mint to make the spiced butter.
Serve the drained manti topped with garlic yogurt, drizzled with the red pepper butter, and finished with a sprinkle of sumac.

recipes.name: Imam Bayildi
recipes.description: Whole eggplants stuffed with a fragrant filling of slow-cooked onions, garlic, and tomatoes in generous olive oil. This classic Ottoman dish is served at room temperature and tastes even better the next day.
instructions: Peel the eggplants in alternating stripes, cut a deep lengthwise slit in each without cutting through, and soak in salted water for 20 minutes.
Heat half the olive oil in a pan and fry the drained eggplants on all sides until softened; place in a baking dish.
In the same pan, sauté thinly sliced onions in the remaining olive oil until soft and translucent, about 10 minutes.
Add sliced garlic, chopped tomatoes, sugar, salt, and pepper, and cook for another 10 minutes until the tomatoes break down.
Stuff the slit in each eggplant generously with the onion-tomato mixture, placing any extra around the eggplants.
Add a splash of water to the dish, cover with foil, and bake at 180C for 45-60 minutes until the eggplants are completely tender.
Let cool to room temperature, garnish with fresh parsley, and serve with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Karniyarik
recipes.description: Fried eggplants split open and filled with a savory mixture of ground lamb, tomatoes, and peppers. Unlike imam bayildi, this warm dish features a hearty meat filling and is a staple of Turkish home cooking.
instructions: Peel the eggplants in stripes, soak in salted water for 15 minutes, pat dry, and fry in sunflower oil until golden on all sides; drain on paper towels.
Sauté diced onion in a little oil until translucent, then add the lamb mince and cook until browned.
Add minced garlic, diced green peppers, tomato paste, Aleppo pepper, salt, and black pepper, and cook for 5 minutes.
Add half the diced tomatoes to the meat mixture and cook until softened.
Cut a slit in each fried eggplant and open them up, then spoon the meat filling generously into each one.
Place the stuffed eggplants in a baking dish, top with remaining tomato slices, add a splash of water, and bake at 180C for 30 minutes.
Garnish with fresh parsley and serve hot with rice pilav.

recipes.name: Hunkar Begendi
recipes.description: Tender braised lamb stew served over a smoky, creamy eggplant puree enriched with bechamel and kashar cheese. This Ottoman palace dish translates to 'the sultan liked it' and lives up to its name.
instructions: Cut lamb shoulder into cubes, sear in olive oil until browned on all sides, then set aside.
In the same pot, sauté diced onions until golden, add tomato paste and garlic, cook for 2 minutes, then add diced tomatoes.
Return the lamb to the pot, add enough water to cover, season with salt and pepper, and simmer covered for 75-90 minutes until the lamb is fork-tender.
Char the eggplants directly over a gas flame or under the broiler until the skin is blackened and the flesh is completely soft.
Peel the charred eggplants immediately, chop the flesh, and toss with lemon juice to prevent browning.
Make a roux with butter and flour, gradually add milk while whisking, then fold in the mashed eggplant and grated kashar cheese; season with salt.
Spread the creamy eggplant puree on a serving platter and spoon the lamb stew on top; serve immediately.

recipes.name: Cig Kofte
recipes.description: Spiced raw bulgur balls kneaded with tomato paste, Aleppo pepper, and fresh herbs until smooth and fiery. The modern vegetarian version is a beloved Turkish street food wrapped in lettuce with a squeeze of lemon.
instructions: Soak the fine bulgur in hot water for 15 minutes until it absorbs the water and softens.
Grate the onions finely and add to the bulgur along with tomato paste, pepper paste, Aleppo pepper, cumin, salt, and olive oil.
Knead the mixture vigorously by hand for at least 15 minutes until it becomes smooth, cohesive, and darkens in color.
Add the pomegranate molasses and continue kneading for another 5 minutes.
Mix in finely chopped green onions and parsley.
Shape into small oval patties or finger-length torpedoes by squeezing in your palm.
Serve on lettuce leaves with lemon wedges and extra pomegranate molasses for drizzling.

recipes.name: Mercimek Koftesi
recipes.description: Red lentil and bulgur patties seasoned with cumin and green onions, served cold as a meze. These vegan lentil kofte are a staple appetizer throughout Turkey and are perfect wrapped in lettuce.
instructions: Boil the red lentils in 500ml water until they are very soft and mushy, about 15 minutes.
While the lentils are still hot, stir in the fine bulgur, cover, and let sit for 10 minutes until the bulgur absorbs the liquid.
Sauté the finely diced onion in olive oil until soft, add tomato paste, cumin, and Aleppo pepper, and cook for 2 minutes.
Add the onion mixture to the lentil-bulgur base and knead until well combined and smooth.
Mix in finely sliced green onions and chopped parsley, then season with salt and lemon juice.
Shape into small oval patties by squeezing a walnut-sized portion in your palm.
Arrange on a platter and serve at room temperature with lettuce leaves and lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Mercimek Corbasi
recipes.description: Velvety smooth red lentil soup seasoned with cumin and finished with a squeeze of lemon. Served at nearly every Turkish restaurant as a starter, this comforting soup is the heart of Turkish home cooking.
instructions: Rinse the red lentils, then combine with diced onion, carrot, and potato in a large pot with 1.5 liters of water.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 25 minutes until the lentils and vegetables are very tender.
Blend the soup with an immersion blender until completely smooth.
Stir in the tomato paste and season with cumin and salt; simmer for another 5 minutes.
In a small pan, melt butter with olive oil and Aleppo pepper to make a garnish drizzle.
Serve the soup in bowls, drizzled with the spiced butter and accompanied by lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Ezogelin Corbasi
recipes.description: A hearty Turkish soup made from red lentils, bulgur, and rice in a tomato and pepper paste broth, seasoned with dried mint and Aleppo pepper. Named after a legendary bride named Ezo.
instructions: Rinse the red lentils, bulgur, and rice, then combine in a large pot with 1.5 liters of water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes until the lentils begin to break down.
In a separate pan, sauté diced onion in olive oil until softened, then stir in tomato paste and pepper paste and cook for 2 minutes.
Add the onion-paste mixture to the soup and stir well.
Season with cumin, dried mint, and salt, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes until thick and hearty.
Melt butter with Aleppo pepper in a small pan for the garnish.
Serve hot with the spiced butter drizzled on top and crusty bread on the side.

recipes.name: Gozleme
recipes.description: Hand-rolled thin flatbread filled with spinach and feta, cooked on a convex griddle called a sac until crispy and golden. A beloved Turkish street food traditionally made by village women at local markets.
instructions: Mix flour with egg, yogurt, olive oil, salt, and enough warm water to form a soft dough; knead for 5 minutes and rest for 20 minutes.
Wash the spinach, chop finely, sauté with diced onion until wilted, and season with salt and pepper; let cool.
Mix the cooled spinach with crumbled feta cheese and Aleppo pepper.
Divide the dough into 4 balls and roll each one out very thinly into a large rectangle on a floured surface.
Spread a quarter of the filling over one half of each rectangle, then fold the other half over to enclose the filling.
Cook on a hot griddle or large pan, brushing with butter, for 3-4 minutes per side until golden and crispy.
Cut into pieces and serve hot.

recipes.name: Su Boregi
recipes.description: Layered savory pastry made from sheets of dough boiled briefly then layered with a feta and parsley filling, baked until golden. This unique technique gives su boregi its distinctively soft, silky texture.
instructions: Make a dough from flour, 2 eggs, salt, and water; knead until smooth, divide into 8 balls, and rest for 30 minutes.
Crumble the feta cheese, mix with chopped parsley, 1 beaten egg, and black pepper for the filling.
Roll each dough ball out into thin sheets the size of your baking tray.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and prepare a bowl of ice water; boil each sheet for 1-2 minutes, then plunge into ice water and drain.
Grease a baking tray with melted butter and oil, layer 4 sheets on the bottom (brushing each with butter and oil), spread the cheese filling, then layer the remaining 4 sheets on top.
Beat the remaining egg with milk and pour evenly over the top; brush with the remaining melted butter.
Bake at 180C for 35-40 minutes until the top is deep golden and crispy.
Let rest for 10 minutes before cutting into squares and serving.

recipes.name: Sigara Boregi
recipes.description: Crispy cigar-shaped pastry rolls filled with feta cheese and fresh herbs, fried until golden. These crunchy borek are a classic Turkish breakfast staple and meze item.
instructions: Crumble the feta cheese and mix with finely chopped parsley, dill, egg, and black pepper.
Cut each yufka sheet into triangles (or use pre-cut triangle phyllo sheets).
Place a spoonful of the cheese filling along the wide edge of each triangle.
Roll up tightly from the wide edge toward the point, tucking in the sides to form a cigar shape; seal the tip with a dab of water.
Heat the sunflower oil in a deep pan to 170C and fry the rolls in batches until golden brown and crispy, about 3-4 minutes.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot as part of a Turkish breakfast or meze spread.

recipes.name: Menemen
recipes.description: A vibrant Turkish scrambled egg dish cooked with tomatoes, green peppers, and spices in a single pan. This beloved breakfast dish is scooped up with crusty bread and best enjoyed communal-style from the pan.
instructions: Dice the onion, deseed and chop the green peppers, and roughly chop the tomatoes.
Heat butter and olive oil in a wide pan over medium heat and sauté the onion and peppers until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add the tomatoes and cook until they break down into a sauce, about 5-7 minutes.
Season with Aleppo pepper, salt, and black pepper.
Crack the eggs directly into the pan and gently stir, keeping the eggs in large soft curds that are just set but still creamy.
Remove from heat while still slightly runny (it will continue cooking from residual heat) and serve immediately in the pan with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Saksuka
recipes.description: A warm Turkish meze of fried eggplant and zucchini pieces in a garlicky tomato and pepper sauce. Not to be confused with shakshuka, this is served at room temperature as a side dish or dipped with bread.
instructions: Cube the eggplant and zucchini, salt them, and let sit for 15 minutes to draw out moisture; pat dry.
Fry the eggplant and zucchini pieces in olive oil in batches until golden; drain on paper towels.
In the same pan, sauté diced onion and green pepper until soft.
Add minced garlic, tomato paste, and diced tomatoes; cook for 10 minutes until the tomatoes break down.
Return the fried vegetables to the sauce, season with Aleppo pepper and salt, and gently fold together.
Simmer for 5 minutes to allow flavors to meld, then serve warm or at room temperature with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Turkish Pilav
recipes.description: Perfectly fluffy buttered rice pilaf with toasted vermicelli noodles, a foundational side dish of Turkish cuisine. The secret is the butter-toasting technique and proper steaming under a towel-covered lid.
instructions: Rinse the rice in several changes of cold water until the water runs clear, then soak in warm salted water for 20 minutes and drain.
Melt the butter in a heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat and toast the vermicelli noodles, stirring constantly, until golden brown.
Add the drained rice and stir for 2 minutes to coat each grain with butter.
Pour in the hot chicken stock and salt, bring to a boil, then reduce to the lowest heat, cover tightly, and cook for 15 minutes.
Remove from heat, place a clean kitchen towel under the lid, and let the rice steam for 10 minutes without opening.
Fluff gently with a fork and serve as a side dish alongside kebabs, stews, or grilled meats.

recipes.name: Dolma
recipes.description: Tender grape leaves rolled around a fragrant filling of rice, pine nuts, currants, and fresh herbs, braised in olive oil and lemon juice. These zeytinyagli (olive oil) dolma are served cold as a classic Turkish meze.
instructions: If using brined grape leaves, soak them in hot water for 15 minutes and rinse well; if fresh, blanch briefly in boiling water.
Sauté finely diced onions in half the olive oil until translucent, then add pine nuts and toast until golden.
Stir in the rice, currants, allspice, cinnamon, salt, and chopped herbs, and cook for 2 minutes.
Add 100ml hot water, cover, and cook for 5 minutes until the water is absorbed; let the filling cool.
Place a grape leaf vein-side up, put a teaspoon of filling near the stem end, fold in the sides, and roll up tightly into a small cigar shape.
Arrange the dolma seam-side down in a pot, packing them snugly in layers, and drizzle with remaining olive oil, lemon juice, and sugar dissolved in 200ml water.
Place a plate on top to weigh them down, cover, and simmer on low heat for 45-50 minutes until the rice is tender.
Let cool completely in the pot before serving at room temperature with lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Sarma
recipes.description: Cabbage leaves rolled around a spiced filling of rice and ground lamb, slowly braised until meltingly tender. These hearty rolls are a winter comfort food served hot with a dollop of yogurt.
instructions: Core the cabbage and blanch in boiling salted water until the leaves are pliable enough to peel off; trim the thick central ribs.
Mix the lamb mince with rinsed rice, grated onion, tomato paste, pepper paste, chopped herbs, Aleppo pepper, salt, and black pepper.
Place a portion of filling on each cabbage leaf, fold in the sides, and roll up tightly.
Arrange the rolls seam-side down in a wide pot, packing them snugly in a single layer if possible.
Dot with butter, add lemon juice and enough hot water to barely cover the rolls.
Place a plate on top to keep them submerged, cover the pot, and simmer on low heat for 70-75 minutes until the rice is cooked and the cabbage is tender.
Serve hot with a generous dollop of plain yogurt on the side.

recipes.name: Icli Kofte
recipes.description: Torpedo-shaped bulgur shells stuffed with a spiced lamb and walnut filling, then deep-fried until crispy. These labor-intensive kibbeh-like kofte from southeastern Turkey are a special occasion treat.
instructions: Pour boiling water over the fine bulgur (just enough to cover), add semolina, cover, and let stand for 20 minutes until soft.
Knead the bulgur mixture vigorously with wet hands for 10 minutes until it forms a smooth, pliable dough; add a splash of water if too dry.

For the filling, sauté diced onion until golden, add lamb mince and cook until browned, then stir in crushed walnuts, tomato paste, Aleppo pepper, cumin, allspice, salt, black pepper, and chopped parsley.
Take a walnut-sized piece of bulgur dough, form it into a hollow torpedo shape with thin walls by working it with your thumb.
Fill the cavity with a teaspoon of the lamb mixture, then pinch the opening shut and smooth the surface.
Heat the sunflower oil to 170C and fry the kofte in batches for 5-6 minutes until deep golden brown and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot with lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Tas Kebab
recipes.description: A classic Turkish lamb stew slowly braised with tomatoes, peppers, and potatoes until the meat is fall-apart tender. The name means 'stone kebab' from the traditional stone pot it was cooked in.
instructions: Cut the lamb shoulder into large cubes and pat dry; season with salt and pepper.
Heat butter and olive oil in a heavy pot and sear the lamb cubes in batches until deeply browned on all sides.
Add quartered onions and garlic, cook until softened, then stir in tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes.
Add diced tomatoes, chopped green peppers, and enough hot water to cover the meat; bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 60 minutes.
Add peeled and quartered potatoes, cover again, and cook for another 30 minutes until both the lamb and potatoes are tender.
Adjust seasoning and serve hot with Turkish pilav or crusty bread.

recipes.name: Kuzu Tandir
recipes.description: Whole leg of lamb slow-roasted for hours in a tandoor-style oven until it falls off the bone. This celebratory dish from Central Anatolia yields impossibly tender, deeply flavored meat.
instructions: Score the lamb leg deeply in several places and rub all over with olive oil, salt, black pepper, and cumin.
Cut the onions into thick wedges, halve the tomatoes, and separate the garlic cloves (unpeeled).
Place the vegetables and bay leaves in the bottom of a large, deep roasting pan and set the lamb on top.
Add 500ml of water to the pan, cover tightly with a double layer of foil and a lid.
Roast at 150C for 4 hours without opening, until the meat is falling off the bone.
Remove the foil for the last 30 minutes and increase heat to 200C to brown the surface.
Let rest for 15 minutes, then pull the meat apart with forks and serve with the pan juices, roasted vegetables, and warm bread.

recipes.name: Ali Nazik Kebab
recipes.description: Charcoal-grilled lamb cubes served over a bed of smoky eggplant puree blended with thick yogurt and garlic. This elegant dish from Gaziantep showcases the Turkish mastery of combining smoky, tangy, and meaty flavors.
instructions: Char the eggplants directly over a gas flame or on a grill until the skin is blackened and the flesh is completely soft and smoky.
Scoop out the eggplant flesh, drain excess liquid, and mash or blend until smooth.
Mix the eggplant puree with yogurt and minced garlic, season with salt, and set aside.
Season the lamb cubes with salt, black pepper, and olive oil, then grill over high heat (or in a very hot pan) until charred and cooked to your liking.
Grill the tomato and green peppers alongside the lamb.
Spread the eggplant-yogurt puree on a serving platter and arrange the grilled lamb on top.
Melt butter with Aleppo pepper in a small pan and drizzle over the dish; garnish with grilled vegetables.

recipes.name: Turkish Kofte
recipes.description: Classic Turkish grilled meatballs made from a kneaded mixture of lamb and beef with onion, breadcrumbs, and cumin. Shaped by hand into flat oval patties and grilled until charred on the outside and juicy within.
instructions: Grate the onion and squeeze out excess liquid; combine with both minces, breadcrumbs, egg, minced garlic, cumin, Aleppo pepper, parsley, salt, and black pepper.
Knead the mixture vigorously for 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and slightly sticky.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes to firm up.
Shape into flat oval patties about 8cm long and 2cm thick.
Grill over charcoal or cook in a very hot ridged grill pan for about 5-6 minutes per side until charred and cooked through.
Slice red onion into rings and toss with sumac and a pinch of salt.
Serve the kofte with sumac onions, grilled tomatoes and peppers, fresh bread, and a selection of meze.

recipes.name: Cacik
recipes.description: A refreshing chilled yogurt soup with grated cucumber, garlic, fresh mint, and a drizzle of olive oil. Thinner than Greek tzatziki, Turkish cacik is served as a cold soup or a cooling side to spicy kebabs.
instructions: Grate the cucumber on the coarse side of a box grater, squeeze out the excess water, and set aside.
Crush the garlic with salt to form a paste using a mortar and pestle.
Whisk the yogurt until smooth, then thin it out with cold water to a soupy consistency.
Stir in the grated cucumber, garlic paste, and chopped fresh mint.
Drizzle with olive oil, sprinkle with dried mint, and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes before serving cold.

recipes.name: Kunefe
recipes.description: A decadent warm dessert of shredded kadayif pastry layered with melting cheese, baked until crispy and golden, then soaked in sweet syrup. Topped with crushed pistachios, it is a specialty of Hatay.
instructions: Make the syrup by boiling sugar with water and lemon juice for 10 minutes until slightly thickened; let cool completely.
Roughly chop the shredded kadayif pastry and toss with melted butter until every strand is coated.
Press half the buttered kadayif into the bottom of a round baking pan in an even layer.
Slice or shred the cheese and spread evenly over the kadayif layer.
Cover with the remaining kadayif and press down firmly.
Bake at 180C for 20-25 minutes until deeply golden and crispy, or cook on the stovetop in a special kunefe pan.
Immediately flip onto a serving plate, pour the cold syrup over the hot kunefe, and top with crushed pistachios; serve immediately while the cheese is still stretchy.

recipes.name: Sutlac
recipes.description: Creamy baked Turkish rice pudding with a caramelized golden top, made with short-grain rice simmered slowly in milk. Unlike stovetop versions, this is finished under the broiler for its signature burnished surface.
instructions: Boil the rice in water until very soft and the water is absorbed, about 15 minutes.
Add the milk gradually while stirring, bring to a gentle simmer, and cook for 15 minutes, stirring frequently.
Dissolve the rice flour in a little cold milk and stir into the pudding to thicken.
Add the sugar and vanilla, stir until dissolved, and cook for another 5 minutes.
Temper the egg yolk with a spoonful of the hot mixture, then stir it back into the pot and cook for 2 minutes (do not boil).
Divide into individual oven-safe clay dishes, let cool slightly, then broil on high for 3-5 minutes until the tops are deeply caramelized and spotted.
Refrigerate until completely cold and serve chilled.

recipes.name: Lokma
recipes.description: Bite-sized balls of yeasted dough deep-fried until golden and immediately dunked in cold sugar syrup, emerging crispy outside and airy within. Traditionally given out to neighbors to celebrate special occasions.
instructions: Make the syrup first: boil 250g sugar with 200ml water and lemon juice for 10 minutes, then refrigerate until completely cold.
Dissolve yeast and remaining sugar in 200ml warm water and let it foam for 5 minutes.
Mix flour and salt, add the yeast mixture, and stir to form a thick, sticky batter (it should be too wet to knead).
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled and bubbly.
Heat the sunflower oil to 170C in a deep pot; using a wet spoon or your hand, drop small walnut-sized balls of batter into the hot oil.
Fry in batches, turning occasionally, for 3-4 minutes until puffed, golden, and cooked through.
Remove with a slotted spoon and immediately plunge into the cold syrup for 30 seconds, then drain.
Sprinkle with ground cinnamon and serve warm.

recipes.name: Pho Bo (Beef Pho)
recipes.description: Vietnam's iconic beef noodle soup with a rich, aromatic broth simmered for hours with star anise, cinnamon, and charred ginger, served over rice noodles with thinly sliced beef and fresh herbs.
instructions: Parboil beef bones in a large stockpot for 10 minutes, then drain and rinse to remove impurities.
Char the onion and ginger directly over an open flame or under a broiler until blackened on all sides, then peel the onion.
Return bones to the pot with 5 liters of water, add brisket, charred onion, and ginger. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer.
Toast star anise, cinnamon stick, and cloves in a dry pan until fragrant, then add to the broth in a spice bag. Simmer for 5-6 hours, skimming regularly.
Remove brisket when tender (about 2 hours), slice thinly, and set aside. Season broth with fish sauce and rock sugar.
Cook rice noodles according to package directions, drain, and divide among serving bowls.
Slice beef eye round paper-thin. Arrange brisket slices and raw beef over noodles, then ladle boiling hot broth over the top to cook the raw beef.
Serve with a plate of bean sprouts, Thai basil, lime wedges, bird's eye chilies, and hoisin sauce on the side.

recipes.name: Pho Ga (Chicken Pho)
recipes.description: A lighter, fragrant chicken noodle soup with a clear golden broth infused with ginger and coriander seeds, topped with poached chicken, fresh herbs, and a squeeze of lime.
instructions: Char the onion and ginger over an open flame or under a broiler until blackened on all sides.
Place the whole chicken in a large pot, cover with 4 liters of cold water, and bring to a boil. Skim off any foam that rises to the surface.
Add charred onion, ginger, coriander seeds, and star anise. Reduce heat to a gentle simmer and cook for 45 minutes until chicken is cooked through.
Remove the chicken, let cool slightly, then shred the meat and discard the bones. Return bones to the pot and simmer for another 30 minutes.
Strain the broth and season with fish sauce and sugar to taste.
Cook rice noodles according to package directions and divide among bowls.
Top noodles with shredded chicken, sliced green onion, and cilantro, then ladle hot broth over the top.
Serve with bean sprouts, lime wedges, and fresh herbs on the side.

recipes.name: Bun Bo Hue (Spicy Beef Noodle Soup)
recipes.description: A fiery, complex noodle soup from the imperial city of Hue featuring thick round rice noodles in a lemongrass-spiked broth with beef shank, pork knuckle, and fermented shrimp paste.

ingredients.name: bun bo hue noodles (thick round rice noodles)

instructions: Parboil beef shank and pork knuckle for 10 minutes, drain and rinse clean.
Return meats to a large pot with 5 liters of water. Bruise 4 stalks of lemongrass and add to the pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer for 3-4 hours.
Make the chili-lemongrass oil by mincing the remaining 2 stalks of lemongrass and frying in annatto oil with chili flakes until fragrant.
Dissolve fermented shrimp paste in a ladleful of broth, strain, and add back to the pot along with the chili-lemongrass oil.
Season broth with fish sauce and sugar. Remove meats when tender, slice into bite-sized pieces.
Cook bun bo hue noodles according to package directions and divide among bowls.
Arrange sliced meats over the noodles and ladle the spicy broth over the top.
Serve with shredded cabbage, thinly sliced banana blossom, Vietnamese mint, bean sprouts, and lime wedges.

recipes.name: Bun Rieu (Crab Tomato Noodle Soup)
recipes.description: A tangy, savory noodle soup with a tomato-based broth enriched with freshwater crab paste and topped with fluffy crab-egg fritters, tofu puffs, and fresh herbs.
instructions: Mix crab paste with beaten eggs in a bowl and set aside. This mixture will form the crab fritters in the soup.
Saute minced shallots in annatto oil until fragrant, then add diced tomatoes and cook until they break down into a sauce.
Add 3 liters of water to the pot, bring to a boil, then season with fish sauce and shrimp paste.
Gently pour the crab-egg mixture into the simmering broth without stirring. Let it float to the surface and set into a fluffy raft, about 5 minutes.
Add halved tofu puffs to the broth and simmer for another 10 minutes.
Cook rice vermicelli according to package directions, drain, and divide among bowls.
Ladle broth over the noodles, breaking off pieces of the crab fritter to distribute among bowls.
Serve with water spinach, perilla leaves, bean sprouts, and lime wedges.

recipes.name: Hu Tieu Nam Vang (Phnom Penh Noodle Soup)
recipes.description: A southern Vietnamese clear pork broth noodle soup influenced by Cambodian-Chinese cuisine, loaded with shrimp, ground pork, sliced pork, and served with chewy tapioca noodles.
instructions: Parboil pork bones, drain, and rinse. Return to pot with 4 liters of water, dried shrimp, and rock sugar. Simmer for 2 hours.
Add pork loin to the broth and simmer for 30 minutes until cooked through. Remove, slice thinly, and set aside.
Season the ground pork with a tablespoon of fish sauce and minced garlic, then form into small meatballs.
Season the broth with fish sauce. Add meatballs and peeled shrimp to the simmering broth and cook for 5 minutes.
Cook hu tieu noodles according to package directions and divide among bowls.
Arrange sliced pork, meatballs, and shrimp over the noodles, then ladle hot broth over the top.
Garnish with Chinese celery, sliced green onion, and fried shallots.
Serve with bean sprouts, lime wedges, and chili sauce on the side.

recipes.name: Mi Quang (Turmeric Noodles from Quang Nam)
recipes.description: A signature dish from central Vietnam featuring wide turmeric-tinted rice noodles in a small amount of rich, concentrated broth with shrimp, pork, herbs, and toasted rice crackers.
instructions: Marinate sliced pork shoulder with turmeric powder, minced garlic, and 1 tablespoon fish sauce for 15 minutes.
Saute onion in oil until soft, add the marinated pork, and cook until browned on all sides.
Add diced tomatoes and cook until softened, then add 1 liter of water and simmer for 30 minutes. Add the shrimp in the last 5 minutes.
Season the concentrated broth with remaining fish sauce. The broth should be rich and just enough to partially cover the noodles.
Cook the wide rice noodles according to package directions and divide among bowls.
Ladle a small amount of the rich broth over the noodles, then top with pork slices and shrimp.
Garnish with crushed roasted peanuts and serve with sesame rice crackers on the side.
Accompany with a plate of shredded banana blossom, lettuce, Vietnamese mint, and other fresh herbs.

recipes.name: Cao Lau (Hoi An Noodles)
recipes.description: A legendary noodle dish unique to Hoi An, featuring thick, chewy noodles tossed with slices of barbecued pork, fresh greens, and crispy croutons in a small amount of savory broth.
instructions: Marinate pork belly with five-spice powder, soy sauce, sugar, and minced garlic for at least 1 hour.
Roast the pork belly in the oven at 180C for about 90 minutes, basting occasionally, until deeply caramelized and tender.
Slice the roasted pork thinly. Deglaze the roasting pan with a cup of water to make a concentrated sauce.
Cook cao lau noodles according to package directions. They should be slightly chewy.
Toss the drained noodles with a few tablespoons of the pork braising sauce and a splash of soy sauce.
Divide noodles among bowls, top with sliced pork, bean sprouts, and torn lettuce.
Garnish with crispy pork croutons, fresh herbs, and a drizzle of the remaining sauce.
Serve with a small side of broth and chili sauce for dipping.

recipes.name: Banh Canh Cua (Crab Tapioca Noodle Soup)
recipes.description: A thick, luscious soup from southern Vietnam with slippery tapioca-rice noodles in a crab-infused broth, topped with crab meat, quail eggs, and fried shallots.
instructions: Simmer pork leg bone in 3 liters of water for 1 hour to create a rich broth. Strain and discard the bones.
Boil quail eggs for 3 minutes, peel, and set aside.
Saute minced shallots and garlic in oil until golden. Add crab meat and stir-fry briefly.
Add the crab mixture to the broth. Mix tapioca starch with a little water and stir into the broth to give it body.
Season with fish sauce and black pepper. Add peeled shrimp and cook for 3 minutes.
Cook banh canh noodles according to package directions and divide among bowls.
Ladle the thick crab broth over the noodles, top with quail eggs and extra crab meat.
Garnish with fried shallots, fresh cilantro, and a generous crack of black pepper.

recipes.name: Com Tam Suon Nuong (Broken Rice with Grilled Pork Chop)
recipes.description: Saigon's beloved broken rice plate topped with a caramelized grilled pork chop marinated in lemongrass and garlic, served with pickled vegetables, a fried egg, and sweet fish sauce.
instructions: Blend lemongrass, garlic, and shallots into a paste. Mix with fish sauce, sugar, and honey to make the marinade.
Score pork chops and marinate in the lemongrass mixture for at least 2 hours, preferably overnight.
Make pickled vegetables by julienning daikon and carrots, tossing with rice vinegar, sugar, and a pinch of salt. Let sit for 30 minutes.
Prepare the dipping fish sauce (nuoc cham) by dissolving sugar in warm water, then mixing with fish sauce, lime juice, garlic, and chili.
Cook broken rice in a rice cooker with slightly less water than regular rice.
Grill pork chops over medium-high charcoal or on a grill pan, about 5 minutes per side, until charred and cooked through.
Fry eggs sunny-side up. Plate each serving with a mound of broken rice, a grilled pork chop, a fried egg, pickled vegetables, and sliced cucumber and tomato.
Drizzle generously with nuoc cham dipping sauce and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Com Ga Hoi An (Hoi An Chicken Rice)
recipes.description: Fragrant chicken-fat rice from Hoi An, tinted yellow with turmeric, served with poached and shredded chicken, a tangy onion-herb salad, and a bowl of clear chicken broth.
instructions: Poach the whole chicken in a pot of salted water with ginger slices for 40-50 minutes until fully cooked. Reserve the broth.
Remove chicken and immediately plunge into ice water to tighten the skin. Shred the meat and set aside.
Render chicken fat in a pan, then toast the rice with turmeric powder in the chicken fat until fragrant.
Cook the turmeric rice using chicken broth instead of water for maximum flavor.
Thinly slice onion and toss with Vietnamese coriander, lime juice, and a splash of fish sauce to make the herb salad.
Season the remaining chicken broth with fish sauce and salt for a simple dipping broth.
Plate each serving with turmeric rice, shredded chicken, and the onion-herb salad.
Serve with the bowl of chicken broth, sliced chilies, and lime wedges on the side.

recipes.name: Xoi Xeo (Steamed Sticky Rice with Mung Bean)
recipes.description: A beloved Hanoi breakfast of turmeric-tinted sticky rice topped with crumbled mung bean paste, crispy fried shallots, and a drizzle of scallion oil.
instructions: Soak glutinous rice overnight or for at least 6 hours. Drain and toss with turmeric powder and a pinch of salt.
Soak mung beans for 2 hours, then steam until very soft, about 20 minutes. Mash with a fork and mix with a little sugar and oil.
Steam the turmeric-coated sticky rice in a steamer lined with cheesecloth for 25-30 minutes until tender and sticky.
Thinly slice shallots and fry in oil until golden and crispy. Reserve the shallot oil separately.
Finely chop green onions and heat in a few tablespoons of oil to make scallion oil.
Mound the sticky rice onto plates or bowls, crumble the mung bean paste on top.
Drizzle with scallion oil and shallot oil, then top with crispy fried shallots.

recipes.name: Goi Cuon (Fresh Spring Rolls)
recipes.description: Translucent rice paper rolls filled with shrimp, rice vermicelli, pork, and a bouquet of fresh herbs, served with a rich peanut dipping sauce.
instructions: Boil pork belly in water for 25 minutes until cooked through. Slice thinly when cool enough to handle.
Poach shrimp in salted water for 2-3 minutes until pink. Peel, devein, and halve lengthwise.
Cook rice vermicelli according to package directions, rinse in cold water, and drain well.
Make peanut dipping sauce by warming hoisin sauce with peanut butter, minced garlic, and a splash of water. Top with crushed peanuts and chili sauce.
Dip a rice paper wrapper briefly in warm water until just pliable. Lay flat on a work surface.
Place lettuce, vermicelli, herbs, pork slices, and shrimp halves (cut side up) on the lower third. Fold the bottom edge up, fold in the sides, and roll tightly.
Repeat with remaining wrappers and filling ingredients.
Serve immediately with the peanut dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Cha Gio (Vietnamese Fried Spring Rolls)
recipes.description: Crispy, golden fried spring rolls filled with a savory mixture of ground pork, crab meat, glass noodles, wood ear mushrooms, and shredded vegetables, wrapped in rice paper.
instructions: Soak glass noodles and wood ear mushrooms in warm water for 15 minutes. Drain, chop the noodles and mushrooms finely.
Grate carrots and taro. Mix with ground pork, crab meat, chopped noodles, mushrooms, minced shallots, egg, fish sauce, and pepper.
Briefly dip a small rice paper wrapper in water until pliable. Place a tablespoon of filling near the bottom edge.
Fold the bottom up, fold in the sides, and roll tightly into a compact cylinder. Repeat with all filling.
Heat oil to 160C and fry the rolls in batches for 8-10 minutes, turning occasionally, until deep golden and crispy.
Drain on a wire rack or paper towels.
Prepare nuoc cham dipping sauce with fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, garlic, and chili.
Serve the rolls wrapped in lettuce leaves with fresh herbs and nuoc cham for dipping.

recipes.name: Bo Bia (Jicama and Egg Spring Rolls)
recipes.description: Light, refreshing Saigon street snack rolls filled with Chinese sausage, jicama, egg ribbons, and dried shrimp, wrapped in rice paper and drizzled with hoisin-peanut sauce.
instructions: Steam Chinese sausages for 10 minutes, then slice thinly on the diagonal.
Julienne jicama and carrots. Stir-fry together with a pinch of salt until just slightly softened, about 3 minutes.
Beat eggs and cook into thin omelets in a non-stick pan. Roll up and slice into thin ribbons.
Soak dried shrimp in warm water for 10 minutes, then drain.
Make the sauce by warming hoisin sauce with peanut butter and a little water until smooth. Sprinkle with sesame seeds.
Dip rice paper in warm water until pliable. Lay flat and spread a smear of hoisin-peanut sauce across the center.
Layer lettuce, jicama-carrot mixture, egg ribbons, sausage slices, and a few dried shrimp. Roll up tightly.
Slice in half on the diagonal and serve with extra hoisin-peanut sauce for dipping.

recipes.name: Banh Mi Thit Nguoi (Classic Vietnamese Sandwich)
recipes.description: The quintessential Vietnamese baguette loaded with cold cuts including cha lua (pork roll), head cheese, and pate, topped with pickled daikon and carrot, cucumber, jalapeno, and cilantro.
instructions: Julienne daikon and carrots, toss with rice vinegar, sugar, and a pinch of salt. Pickle for at least 20 minutes.
Warm the baguettes in the oven for 3-5 minutes until the crust is crispy.
Slice baguettes lengthwise, leaving one side as a hinge.
Spread pate on one side and mayonnaise on the other. Drizzle a few drops of Maggi seasoning.
Layer sliced cha lua, head cheese, and any other cold cuts inside the baguette.
Add a generous handful of pickled daikon and carrot, cucumber slices, jalapeno rings, and fresh cilantro sprigs.
Press the sandwich gently closed and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Banh Mi Thit Nuong (Grilled Pork Banh Mi)
recipes.description: A smoky, savory banh mi filled with charcoal-grilled lemongrass pork, bright pickled vegetables, fresh herbs, and a slick of butter and pate on a crispy baguette.
instructions: Mince lemongrass and garlic, then mix with fish sauce, sugar, and oil. Marinate pork slices for at least 1 hour.
Prepare pickled daikon and carrots with vinegar, sugar, and salt. Let sit for 20 minutes.
Grill the marinated pork over high heat or in a grill pan for 2-3 minutes per side until charred and caramelized.
Warm baguettes in the oven until crispy, then slice open.
Spread pate on one side of each baguette.
Load with grilled pork, pickled vegetables, cucumber slices, jalapeno, and plenty of cilantro.
Serve immediately while the pork is hot and the baguette is crispy.

recipes.name: Banh Mi Chay (Tofu Banh Mi)
recipes.description: A flavorful vegetarian banh mi with crispy pan-fried lemongrass tofu, pickled vegetables, fresh herbs, and a spread of vegan pate on a crusty baguette.
instructions: Press tofu for 15 minutes to remove excess moisture, then slice into thin rectangles.
Mince lemongrass and mix with soy sauce, sugar, and turmeric to make the marinade. Coat tofu slices and let sit for 15 minutes.
Pan-fry the tofu in oil over medium-high heat until golden and crispy on both sides, about 3 minutes per side.
Prepare quick pickles by julienning daikon and carrots with vinegar, sugar, and salt.
Warm baguettes until crispy, then slice open and spread with vegan mayonnaise.
Layer crispy tofu, pickled vegetables, cucumber slices, jalapeno, and cilantro inside each baguette.
Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Bun Cha Ha Noi (Hanoi Grilled Pork with Noodles)
recipes.description: Hanoi's signature dish of smoky charcoal-grilled pork patties and caramelized pork belly slices served in a bowl of sweet-sour dipping sauce alongside rice noodles and a mountain of fresh herbs.
instructions: Mix ground pork with minced shallots, garlic, 1 tablespoon fish sauce, and 1 tablespoon sugar. Form into small flat patties.
Marinate pork belly slices with fish sauce, sugar, and minced garlic for at least 30 minutes.
Make the dipping broth (nuoc cham) by dissolving sugar in warm water, then adding fish sauce, lime juice, rice vinegar, minced garlic, and sliced chili.
Grill the pork patties and pork belly slices over hot charcoal or in a grill pan until charred and caramelized, about 4 minutes per side.
Cook rice vermicelli according to package directions, rinse in cold water, and drain.
Place the grilled pork patties and belly slices directly into individual bowls of the dipping broth, along with pickled green papaya.
Serve with a plate of rice vermicelli and a large platter of lettuce, perilla, mint, and other herbs.
Diners wrap noodles and herbs in lettuce, dip into the broth bowl with pork, and eat.

recipes.name: Nem Nuong (Vietnamese Grilled Pork Sausage)
recipes.description: Bouncy, sweet-savory grilled pork sausages with a distinctive chewy texture from baking powder, served with rice paper, noodles, fresh vegetables, and fermented bean dipping sauce.
instructions: Combine ground pork, minced garlic, sugar, fish sauce, baking powder, cornstarch, and black pepper in a bowl.
Knead and pound the pork mixture vigorously for 10 minutes until it becomes very smooth, sticky, and bouncy.
Refrigerate the mixture for at least 1 hour to firm up.
Form the mixture onto skewers or into small sausage shapes. Lightly oil the surface.
Grill over medium heat, turning frequently, for about 12-15 minutes until golden brown and cooked through.
Prepare the dipping sauce by thinning fermented soybean paste with a little warm water and minced garlic.
Cook rice vermicelli and prepare fresh vegetables. Serve the grilled sausages with dampened rice paper, noodles, vegetables, and herbs.
Diners wrap nem nuong with noodles and vegetables in rice paper and dip into the sauce.

recipes.name: Thit Nuong (Vietnamese Grilled Lemongrass Pork)
recipes.description: Thinly sliced pork marinated in a fragrant blend of lemongrass, garlic, shallots, and fish sauce, then grilled until beautifully charred, served over rice or noodles.
instructions: Finely mince the lemongrass, garlic, and shallots (or blend into a paste).
Combine the lemongrass paste with fish sauce, sugar, oyster sauce, oil, honey, and black pepper.
Toss the thinly sliced pork in the marinade, making sure each piece is well coated. Marinate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Heat a grill or grill pan to high heat. Grill the pork slices for 2-3 minutes per side until charred and caramelized.
Alternatively, spread pork on a baking sheet and broil for 5 minutes per side.
Serve over broken rice with a fried egg (com tam), or over rice vermicelli with fresh herbs (bun thit nuong).

recipes.name: Ca Kho To (Caramelized Fish in Clay Pot)
recipes.description: A homestyle southern Vietnamese dish of catfish steaks braised in a rich, dark caramel sauce with fish sauce, black pepper, and shallots in a traditional clay pot.
instructions: Cut catfish into thick steaks. Marinate with 1 tablespoon fish sauce, minced garlic, and black pepper for 15 minutes.
In a clay pot or heavy saucepan, make caramel by heating sugar with a tablespoon of water until it turns a deep amber color.
Immediately add sliced shallots and stir in the caramel. Add the remaining fish sauce and coconut water.
Gently place the fish steaks into the caramel sauce in a single layer.
Bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and braise on low heat for 25-30 minutes, occasionally spooning sauce over the fish.
The sauce should reduce to a thick, glossy glaze. Add sliced chili in the last 5 minutes.
Garnish with sliced green onion and plenty of cracked black pepper.
Serve directly in the clay pot with steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: Bo Luc Lac (Shaking Beef)
recipes.description: Tender cubes of marinated beef seared at high heat in a wok until caramelized on the outside and rare inside, tossed with garlic and served on a bed of watercress with a lime-pepper dipping sauce.
instructions: Cut beef into 2cm cubes. Marinate with soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, and minced garlic for at least 30 minutes.
Make the lime-pepper dipping sauce by mixing fresh lime juice with salt and coarsely ground black pepper.
Arrange a bed of watercress on a serving plate with sliced red onion and tomato.
Heat a wok or cast iron skillet over the highest heat until smoking. Add oil.
Sear the beef cubes in a single layer without moving for 1 minute, then shake and toss the wok vigorously (the shaking motion gives the dish its name) for another 1-2 minutes for medium-rare.
Add butter in the last 30 seconds and toss to coat.
Immediately spoon the beef over the watercress bed.
Serve with the lime-pepper dipping sauce and steamed rice.

recipes.name: Ga Kho Gung (Caramelized Chicken with Ginger)
recipes.description: A warming, aromatic dish of chicken pieces braised in a ginger-infused caramel sauce until the meat is tender and coated in a sticky, savory glaze.
instructions: Cut chicken thighs into pieces. Julienne the ginger into thin matchsticks.
Make caramel by heating sugar in a pot until deep amber, then carefully add coconut water.
Saute sliced shallots, garlic, and half the ginger until fragrant.
Add chicken pieces and sear on all sides until lightly browned.
Pour the caramel sauce over the chicken, add fish sauce, and bring to a simmer.
Cover and braise on low heat for 25-30 minutes until chicken is tender and the sauce is thick and glossy.
Add the remaining fresh ginger and sliced chili in the last 5 minutes for a bright, spicy finish.
Garnish with green onion and black pepper. Serve with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Thit Kho Trung (Caramelized Pork Belly with Eggs)
recipes.description: A quintessential Vietnamese Tet (New Year) dish of pork belly slowly braised in coconut water caramel sauce with hard-boiled eggs until meltingly tender and deeply flavored.
instructions: Cut pork belly into large chunks about 4cm. Hard-boil the eggs, peel, and set aside.
Make caramel by cooking sugar in a dry pot until deep amber. Carefully add a splash of fish sauce (it will bubble vigorously).
Add the pork belly pieces to the caramel and toss to coat. Sear until the pork takes on the caramel color.
Add minced garlic, sliced shallots, remaining fish sauce, and coconut water. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to very low, cover, and simmer for about 1 hour until pork is very tender.
Add the peeled hard-boiled eggs in the last 20 minutes so they absorb the caramel color and flavor.
The sauce should reduce to a thick, mahogany glaze. Season with black pepper.
Garnish with sliced green onion and serve with steamed rice and pickled mustard greens.

recipes.name: Lau Thai (Vietnamese Sour and Spicy Hotpot)
recipes.description: A communal hotpot with a tangy tamarind-tomato broth simmered with lemongrass and chili, served with an array of seafood, meats, vegetables, and noodles for cooking at the table.
instructions: Make the hotpot broth by dissolving tamarind paste in 2 liters of water. Add bruised lemongrass, quartered tomatoes, and sliced chili. Simmer for 15 minutes.
Season the broth with fish sauce and sugar. The broth should be tangy, slightly sweet, and spicy.
Prepare all the dipping ingredients: peel and devein shrimp, clean and score squid, slice fish fillets, and arrange beef slices on plates.
Wash and prepare vegetables: cut morning glory into lengths, separate mushroom clusters, and halve tofu puffs.
Set up a portable burner at the table with the hotpot of simmering broth in the center.
Arrange all the raw ingredients on platters around the hotpot for diners to cook at the table.
Cook noodles separately, or add directly to the hotpot broth at the end of the meal.
Serve with individual dipping bowls of fish sauce mixed with chili, lime, and garlic.

recipes.name: Goi Ga (Vietnamese Chicken Salad)
recipes.description: A refreshing, crunchy salad of shredded poached chicken tossed with cabbage, Vietnamese coriander, fried shallots, and a tangy lime-fish sauce dressing topped with crushed peanuts.
instructions: Poach chicken breasts in simmering salted water for 20 minutes until cooked through. Let cool, then shred finely by hand.
Thinly shred cabbage and julienne carrots. Thinly slice red onion and soak in ice water for 10 minutes to tame the bite.
Make the dressing by dissolving sugar in lime juice, then whisking in fish sauce, minced garlic, and sliced chili.
Toss the shredded chicken, cabbage, carrots, and drained onion with the dressing.
Add torn Vietnamese coriander and mint leaves and toss gently.
Plate the salad and top with crushed roasted peanuts and fried shallots.
Serve immediately while the vegetables are still crisp.

recipes.name: Goi Du Du (Green Papaya Salad)
recipes.description: A vibrant, crunchy salad of shredded green papaya and carrots tossed with a pungent lime-fish sauce dressing, dried beef jerky, fresh herbs, and roasted peanuts.
instructions: Peel the green papaya, halve, remove seeds, and shred into fine strips using a julienne peeler or mandoline.
Julienne the carrots and toss with the papaya. Sprinkle with salt, let sit 10 minutes, then squeeze out excess water.
Make the dressing by dissolving sugar in lime juice, then adding fish sauce, minced garlic, and sliced bird's eye chili.
Shred or thinly slice the beef jerky.
Toss the papaya and carrot with the dressing until well combined.
Add torn Thai basil and Vietnamese coriander, toss gently.
Top with shredded beef jerky and crushed roasted peanuts. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Nom Hoa Chuoi (Banana Blossom Salad)
recipes.description: A delicate, elegant salad of thinly sliced banana blossom tossed with poached chicken or shrimp, fresh herbs, and a zesty lime dressing, finished with fried shallots and peanuts.
instructions: Remove the outer tough layers of the banana blossom. Quarter, remove the hard core, and slice very thinly crosswise. Soak immediately in acidulated water (water with lemon juice) to prevent browning.
Poach chicken breast until cooked, then shred finely. Boil shrimp until pink, peel, and halve.
Julienne carrots. Drain the banana blossom slices and squeeze out excess water.
Make the dressing by combining lime juice, fish sauce, sugar, and sliced chili. Stir until sugar dissolves.
Toss the banana blossom, shredded chicken, shrimp, carrots, and dressing together.
Add torn Vietnamese coriander and mint, toss gently to combine.
Plate the salad and top with crushed peanuts and fried shallots.
Serve immediately, as banana blossom browns quickly.

recipes.name: Banh Xeo (Vietnamese Sizzling Crepe)
recipes.description: A crispy, golden turmeric-coconut rice flour crepe stuffed with shrimp, pork, bean sprouts, and mung beans, named for the sizzling sound it makes when the batter hits the hot pan.
instructions: Make the batter by whisking rice flour, coconut milk, turmeric, a pinch of salt, and 200ml water until smooth. Rest for 30 minutes.
Soak and steam mung beans until soft, about 15 minutes.
Heat a large non-stick skillet over high heat with a tablespoon of oil. Quickly cook a few shrimp and pork slices.
Pour a thin layer of batter into the hot pan, swirling to coat the bottom. Add bean sprouts and mung beans to one half.
Cover and cook for 2-3 minutes until the bottom is crispy and golden. Fold the crepe in half.
Repeat with remaining batter and filling ingredients.
Prepare nuoc cham dipping sauce with fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, garlic, and chili.
Serve the crepes with large lettuce leaves, mint, and Thai basil. Diners wrap pieces of crepe in lettuce with herbs and dip in nuoc cham.

recipes.name: Banh Khot (Mini Sizzling Cakes)
recipes.description: Bite-sized crispy turmeric rice flour cakes from Vung Tau, each topped with a whole shrimp, cooked in a special cast iron mold and served with lettuce wraps and tangy dipping sauce.
instructions: Mix rice flour, coconut milk, turmeric, salt, and 150ml water into a smooth batter. Add sliced green onion.
Heat a banh khot mold (or a takoyaki pan) and add a small amount of oil to each well.
Pour batter into each well until about two-thirds full. Place one shrimp on top of each.
Cover and cook on medium heat for 5-6 minutes until the edges are crispy and golden.
Carefully remove the cakes with a spoon or small spatula.
Make nuoc cham dipping sauce by mixing fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, water, minced garlic, and chili.
Serve the hot banh khot with lettuce leaves and fresh herbs for wrapping, alongside the dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Banh Cuon (Steamed Rice Rolls)
recipes.description: Delicate, silky sheets of steamed rice flour batter filled with seasoned ground pork and wood ear mushrooms, served with fried shallots, herbs, sliced cha lua, and a side of dipping sauce.
instructions: Mix rice flour and tapioca starch with 500ml water and a pinch of salt to make a thin, smooth batter. Let rest 30 minutes.
Soak and finely chop wood ear mushrooms. Saute minced shallots, add ground pork and mushrooms. Season with fish sauce and cook until done.
Stretch a piece of tightly woven cloth over a pot of boiling water (or use a non-stick pan with a lid).
Lightly oil the cloth surface. Ladle a thin layer of batter onto the cloth, spreading quickly to make an ultra-thin sheet. Cover with a lid.
After 1-2 minutes, the rice sheet becomes translucent. Carefully peel it off with a spatula. Place a line of pork filling and roll up.
Repeat until all batter and filling are used.
Arrange the rolls on a plate, drizzle with fried shallots and their oil, and serve with sliced cha lua, bean sprouts, and fresh herbs.
Accompany with nuoc cham dipping sauce mixed with a touch of chili oil.

recipes.name: Bun Dau Mam Tom (Noodles with Fried Tofu and Shrimp Paste)
recipes.description: A bold Hanoi street food platter of fried tofu, rice vermicelli noodles, cha gio, fresh herbs, and cucumber, all dipped into pungent fermented shrimp paste sauce.
instructions: Cut tofu into thick slices and pat very dry with paper towels.
Deep-fry tofu in hot oil at 180C until golden and crispy on the outside, about 5-6 minutes. Drain on paper towels.
Cook rice vermicelli, rinse in cold water, and drain. Portion into individual bundles.
Make the shrimp paste dipping sauce by mixing mam tom with lime juice, sugar, minced chili, and a splash of warm water. Whisk until frothy.
Warm the cha gio (fried spring rolls) in the oven or re-fry briefly.
Slice cucumber and arrange all components on a large platter: fried tofu, noodle bundles, cha gio, cucumber, perilla leaves, and mint.
Serve with individual bowls of the shrimp paste dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Che Ba Mau (Three-Color Dessert)
recipes.description: A colorful Vietnamese sweet dessert drink layered with red beans, green mung bean paste, and yellow pandan jelly, topped with coconut cream and crushed ice.
instructions: Soak red beans overnight. Simmer in water with 40g sugar until soft but not mushy, about 45 minutes. Drain excess liquid.
Soak mung beans for 2 hours. Steam or boil until very soft, then mash with 40g sugar into a smooth paste.
Make pandan jelly by blending pandan leaves with 300ml water, straining, then heating with agar-agar powder and 40g sugar. Pour into a flat dish to set, then cut into cubes.
Make coconut sauce by warming coconut cream with a pinch of salt and sugar until just dissolved. Cool.
To assemble, layer in tall glasses: sweetened red beans on the bottom, mung bean paste in the middle, and pandan jelly cubes on top.
Top with crushed ice and drizzle generously with coconut cream sauce.
Stir everything together before eating to combine the three colors and flavors.

recipes.name: Che Chuoi (Banana in Coconut Milk)
recipes.description: A warm, comforting southern Vietnamese sweet soup of ripe bananas simmered in sweetened coconut milk with tapioca pearls and a hint of pandan.

ingredients.name: ripe bananas (chuoi su or chuoi gia)

instructions: Cook tapioca pearls in boiling water until translucent, about 10 minutes. Drain and rinse.
Peel bananas and cut into diagonal slices about 2cm thick.
Bring 200ml water, sugar, and knotted pandan leaves to a simmer. Add the banana slices and cook gently for 5 minutes.
Pour in the coconut milk and a pinch of salt. Bring back to a gentle simmer (do not boil vigorously or the coconut milk will separate).
Add the cooked tapioca pearls and stir gently.
Serve warm in bowls, sprinkled with crushed roasted peanuts and sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Che Troi Nuoc (Glutinous Rice Balls in Ginger Syrup)
recipes.description: Soft, chewy glutinous rice balls filled with sweet mung bean paste, served floating in a warm ginger and pandan-infused syrup with a drizzle of coconut cream.
instructions: Soak mung beans for 2 hours, then steam until very soft. Mash with 30g sugar and a pinch of salt to form a smooth paste. Roll into small balls.
Mix glutinous rice flour with warm water gradually until a smooth, pliable dough forms (similar to play dough consistency).
Flatten a small piece of dough, place a mung bean ball in the center, and wrap the dough around it, sealing completely. Roll into a smooth ball.
Make ginger syrup by simmering sliced ginger, knotted pandan leaves, remaining sugar, and 1 liter of water for 15 minutes.
Drop the rice balls into a pot of boiling water. They are done when they float to the surface, about 3-4 minutes.
Transfer the cooked rice balls into bowls and ladle the warm ginger syrup over them.
Drizzle with coconut cream and sprinkle with toasted sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Banh Flan (Vietnamese Creme Caramel)
recipes.description: A silky, egg custard dessert with Vietnamese coffee-infused caramel, a beloved legacy of French colonial influence with a distinctly Vietnamese twist using condensed milk and robust coffee.
instructions: Make the caramel by heating sugar with 2 tablespoons of water in a saucepan over medium heat until it turns a deep amber. Stir in the brewed Vietnamese coffee (it will sizzle). Divide caramel among 6 ramekins.
Whisk eggs gently (avoid creating too many bubbles). Add condensed milk, whole milk, and vanilla extract. Stir until well combined.
Strain the custard mixture through a fine sieve for a smoother texture.
Pour the custard into the caramel-lined ramekins.
Place ramekins in a deep baking dish. Pour hot water into the dish until it reaches halfway up the sides of the ramekins (bain-marie).
Bake at 160C for 40-50 minutes until the custard is set but still has a gentle jiggle in the center.
Cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 4 hours. To serve, run a knife around the edge and invert onto a plate.

recipes.name: Banh Chuoi Nuong (Vietnamese Banana Cake)
recipes.description: A rustic, custardy baked banana pudding cake made with layers of ripe bananas and coconut milk-soaked bread, a popular southern Vietnamese home dessert.
instructions: Peel bananas and slice lengthwise into halves, then cut into pieces. Pan-fry in a little butter and sugar until lightly caramelized.
Cut bread into cubes and soak in the coconut milk mixed with condensed milk for 10 minutes until softened.
Beat eggs with sugar, vanilla, and a pinch of salt. Fold into the bread-coconut mixture.
Grease a baking dish with butter. Layer half the bread mixture, then the caramelized bananas, then the remaining bread mixture.
Bake at 175C for 35-40 minutes until the top is golden and the custard is set.
Let cool slightly before slicing. Serve warm, optionally drizzled with extra coconut cream.

recipes.name: Sinh To Bo (Vietnamese Avocado Smoothie)
recipes.description: A rich, creamy Vietnamese avocado smoothie blended with sweetened condensed milk and ice, a beloved street-side treat that showcases the Vietnamese love for avocado as a dessert fruit.
instructions: Halve the avocados, remove the pits, and scoop the flesh into a blender.
Add sweetened condensed milk, whole milk, sugar, and ice cubes.
Blend on high until completely smooth and thick, about 30 seconds.
Taste and adjust sweetness by adding more condensed milk if desired.
Pour into tall glasses and serve immediately with a straw and a spoon.

recipes.name: Sinh To Mang Cau (Soursop Smoothie)
recipes.description: A tropical Vietnamese smoothie made from fresh soursop fruit blended with coconut milk and condensed milk, producing a tangy-sweet, creamy beverage popular throughout southern Vietnam.
instructions: Peel soursop and remove the seeds from the white flesh. This is easiest to do by hand.
Place the soursop flesh in a blender with coconut milk, condensed milk, sugar, and ice.
Blend until smooth and creamy, scraping down the sides if necessary.
Strain through a coarse sieve if a smoother texture is desired (optional).
Pour into glasses and serve immediately. The drink should be thick and frosty.

recipes.name: Che Dau Xanh (Sweet Mung Bean Dessert)
recipes.description: A nourishing sweet soup of slow-cooked mung beans with coconut milk and pandan, served warm or cold. A staple Vietnamese dessert enjoyed across the country.
instructions: Soak mung beans for at least 3 hours or overnight. Drain.
Bring 1 liter of water to a boil with the knotted pandan leaves. Add the mung beans and simmer for 30 minutes until soft and starting to break apart.
In a separate pot, cook the tapioca pearls in boiling water until translucent, about 10 minutes. Drain and rinse.
Add sugar to the mung beans and stir until dissolved. Add the cooked tapioca pearls.
Stir in the coconut milk and a pinch of salt. Heat gently without boiling.
Serve warm in bowls, or refrigerate and serve cold with crushed ice in the summer.
